Project Title: Using Vernacular Analysis to Enhance Women’s Participation in Local, Regional and National Peacebuilding Processes in Nigeria
Project Description:
This project aims to enhance women's participation, leadership, and representation in dialogues and discussions regarding security and peace in Nigeria. In an era marked by decline in the responsiveness of governments to the needs of society, devastating climate change incidents, and violent conflict, there is an urgent need to enhance the capacity of women to respond to these problems in ways that reflect their interests at all levels of society.  As the UN Sustainable Development Goals, Resolution 1325, and Nigeria and the United Kingdom’s  national women, security and peace agenda, in theory, emphasise the importance of women in development, security, peace, and conflict resolution, the question of opportunities and capacity building remains a major policy issue. How can Nigerian women’s participation in discussions, dialogues, leadership, and representation in decisions on security, peace, conflict resolution be enhanced?  Our project is intended to respond to this question on a vernacular analysis based on a theory of change that suggests more involvement of women in peacebuilding processes if they are supported with capacity building and learning opportunities.

In recent years, violent conflict and insecurity have increased across states and communities in Nigeria. Banditry, kidnapping, cultism, armed robbery, indigenous-settler disputes, intra- and intergroup conflicts, and farmer-herder conflicts occur to varying degrees across the country. Women are disproportionately impacted by these violent acts.  Too frequently, women are excluded from decisions regarding the prevention and management of such conflicts.  While women are present in the peacebuilding work of non-governmental organizations, cultural and government institutions continue to marginalize them on patriarchal grounds
Name of Call: Funding to support women’s participation in local, regional and national peace processes
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Time-resolved Electron Diffraction of metal redox enzyme crystals
Project Description: We propose to develop methods collect single images (stills) from many micro crystals that can be added to make full datasets. By scanning the electron beam over the grid and continuously collecting the frames, we can select those with diffraction for inclusion, similar to how crystal jets are used at XFELs. Almost zero dose data. This technique offers the potential to react micro crystal suspensions (which will have very short diffusion path) and cryo-trap short-lived states on the enzyme reaction pathway by using a device analogue to a the continuous-flow enzymology apparatus and projecting onto the grid before plunging into a cryo-bath. Overall this method shows promise in studying enzyme mechanisms with minimal disturbance to the structures utilising the increasing number of high-end cryoEM in UK.

Project Title: Hyperglycaemia contributes to hypertension by altering vascular contractility and promoting vascular remodelling
Project Description:
Coexistence of diabetes and hypertension exacerbates morbidity of cardiovascular diseases, indicating a
synergy/cooperativity between these pathophysiologies. Although multifactorial, hypertension is associated
with over-production of vasoconstrictors that mediate arterial hyper-constriction, and remodelling via their
cognate G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Under normoglycaemic conditions vessel hyper-contractility is
prevented by G protein-coupled receptor kinase 2 (GRK2)-mediated desensitization of vasoconstrictor-GPCR
activity. Our preliminary data show that acute hyperglycaemia blocks desensitization of vasoconstrictor-
stimulated vessel contractions, prevents vasoconstrictor-mediated membrane recruitment of GPCR-
desensitizing GRK2, and enhances signalling pathways that mediate vasoconstrictor-stimulated vascular
remodelling, suggesting glucose can modulate blood pressure. We will now determine: (1) how glucose
prevents the desensitization of vasoconstrictor-stimulated vascular contractions; (2) how glucose blocks
agonist-mediated GRK2 recruitment to vasoconstrictor GPCRs; (3) how glucose effects vasoconstrictor-driven
MAPK signalling; (4) and whether these changes underlie an ability of glucose to promote VSMC
migration/proliferation. This novel work will provide greater insight into how glucose promotes hypertension.
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)

Project Title: Under The Radar: The East Midlands, The Manorial Court Rolls And The Revolt Of 1381
Project Description: Whether looking at how rumour spread of uprisings, pardoning of rebels, or the more general popular participation, over the last two decades the events of 1381 have reawakened the interest of historians. However, there is still a strong tendency to accept geographical and temporal boundaries (south east, East Anglia, etc) set early in the modern study of the revolt, if not by the surviving chronicles themselves. This project examines the value of widening out both aspects of the revolt, looking at the East Midlands, an area from which there is much anecdotal evidence but limited hard empirical research, looking to a wider time frame (1360-1400) around the revolt than the usual focus on the  years immediately after the 1381 revolt (i.e. to understand background restiveness), and conducting  a statistical analysis of the little used, for the study of the revolt at least, manorial records when it comes to local restiveness.

Project Title: Supporting Decolonial Futures: Exploring the impact of the Museums Association’s Decolonisation Confidence and Skills Programme
Project Description: The research is designed to explore the impact of the first iteration of the Decolonisation Confidence and Skills programme within the wider context of decolonial thinking and practice, in order to support and inform future work and developments at the Museums Association. Project Title: Exploring the usefulness of online patient portals for the management of kidney disease: patient and health professionals' views and experiences
Project Description:
In this fellowship I will explore perceptions of online portals in kidney disease management. My aim is to evaluate these online portals and what affects usage and engagement of patients and healthcare professionals, resulting in recommendations to improve accessibility and kidney disease management for both groups.

The long-term management of kidney disease can be a challenging journey for patients and their healthcare professionals (HCPs), who often have to coordinate the management of symptoms, medication changes, comorbidities, and kidney disease progression to ensure holistic care. Online patient portals have been deployed with increasing reliance as a means of centralising this coordination, allowing those living with kidney disease and their HCPs to exchange information critical to disease management (e.g. blood test results, symptom tracking, medication changes) at a single online location (Irizarry et al., 2015).
 
Online portals designed to promote kidney disease self management, such as Patient View (PV) which has been superseded by Patient Knows Best (PKB) (UKKA, 2023) are widely used in UK kidney units to support kidney disease management. Other services use their own software or the NHS app which is used across conditions but is more restricted in terms of patient input due to patients not being able to add information directly (NHS, 2023). While such portals provide valuable support for disease management (Ancker et al., 2015a), widespread reliance on online portals may inherently disadvantage those who may be unable to access technology or who have low levels of digital literacy. User interfaces of portals may also unintentionally disengage segments of the population through flaws in usability. It is not known whether use of online portals impact how HCPs deliver care to people with kidney disease. Taken together, unless systematically addressed, these factors may propagate inequities in kidney disease management.
 
This Fellowship aims to define how the ongoing digitalisation of patient care through online portals may impact on shared management of kidney disease.
 
Objectives
 
Use descriptive survey methods to identify potential inequities in the usage of online portals 

Explore use and impact of online portals with people with kidney disease and kidney health professionals via in depth interviews
 
Produce a white paper detailing ways in which online portals might be improved to support the self management of kidney disease 
 
Three work packages are proposed to meet these objectives:
 
WP1: a descriptive quantitative study of uptake of online patient portal systems implemented in the West Yorkshire region, and among those with rare renal diseases across the UK, to provide an overview of how a sub-sample of the UK-kidney disease population currently use online portals. These data will be used to build a regression model to predict engagement.
 
WP2: an in-depth exploration of the views and experiences of people with kidney disease who use online patient portals using process evaluation (Moore, 2015) and qualitative methodology (Braun & Clarke, 2013), as well as exploring the views of those who have opted not to use or have stopped using portals.
 
WP3: in-depth interviews with kidney HCPs on views of online patient portals, their utility in supporting kidney disease management, and their role in their practise of managing kidney disease.
 
This fellowship is supported by the UK Kidney Med-Tech committee, and will represent a national collaboration between the Universities of Leicester, Nottingham Trent, Brunel University London, University College London (UCL) and University Hospital of Leicester, Leeds Teaching Hospitals Trust, South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, and patient involvement leads.
 
All work packages will recruit nationally to reduce regional bias, with sample sizes informed by Fugard & Potts (2015). This work will allow tangible proposals for improvements to the online portals, to improve their usability and minimise their risk of propagating inequities, which will also be informed by the NASSS framework (Greenhalgh & Abimbola, 2019). Results of these studies will inform development of a white paper outlining how digital patient support tools for kidney disease should be implemented, taking into consideration patient and HCP views on usability, risks and impact on delivery of care. Accessible resources, including patient-facing communication, will be developed dependent on patient and HCP needs identified during analysis.

Project Title: The Radical Eco-poetics of W. H. Hudson
Project Description: Critical engagement with the work of the Anglo-Argentine writer and naturalist W. H. Hudson (1841-1922) has never been more urgent. Hudson’s concern with environmental destruction and extinction, his immersion in South American Indigenous epistemologies, and committed belief in multispecies communities align with much twenty-first century environmental and posthuman thinking. This Fellowship would enable me to complete the first ever book-length ecocritical study of Hudson’s work, an important and timely undertaking, which would not only reveal the radicalism of Hudson’s eco-aesthetics, but the abiding relevance of his visionary ecological thinking 100 years after his death.

Project Title: Assessing the effectiveness of unidade de pronto atendimento (UPA), pediatric hospitals, and maternity hospitals in reducing the risk of COVID-19 related death and hospital-acquired COVID-19
Project Description: The recent COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented challenges to health management. Some lessons have been learned so special measures may be taken in the future to reduce the risk of death and hospital infection, such as prioritizing the use of specialized hospitals and unidade de pronto atendimento (UPAs). Against this background, this project aims to assess the performance of (i) pediatric hospitals, (ii) maternity hospitals, and (iii) UPA compared to the general hospitals in treating patients with COVID-19 and infection control of COVID-19. These are assessed by considering whether patients admitted to pediatric and maternity hospitals, and UPA were associated with a higher risk of in-hospital mortality and nosocomial infection. Patient data gathered from two nationwide hospital databases are analysed. Findings of the project will inform health management policies concerning the role pediatric and obstetric care can play in future infectious disease outbreaks as well as how UPA can provide additional hospital care.

Project Title: Functional Magnetic Cloaking & Shielding Metamaterials with Non-Isotropic Media
Project Description: Creating environments devoid of magnetic fields is a formidable challenge. This project seeks to design metamaterials capable of functional magnetic cloaking and shielding, offering applications in diverse sectors. The endeavour addresses the complexities of modelling superconductors and soft ferromagnetic materials within non-circular geometries and in non-isotropic magnetic cloaking conditions. We will establish functional relationships between cloaking/shielding effectiveness by the inverse parametrization of material properties in superconducting/ferromagnetic bilayers for a broad range of bodies within a single framework. These functional metastructures will improve magnetic sensing and reliability issues in electronics, healthcare, precision measurement, metal processing, and critical aerospace control systems.

Project Title: Genome control by cohesin ligands
Project Description: The organisation of mammalian genomes in 3D nuclear space is critical for genome function. The cohesin complex is a key player in this organisation. Cohesin extrudes DNA loops, accumulates at specific genomic sites, and adopts distinct structural and functional states that link genome topology to genomic processes. These include transcription, replication, repair, recombination, sister chromatic cohesion and chromosome segregation. How cohesin controls such diverse biological processes is a major question in genome biology. Addressing this knowledge gap is important because the processes coordinated by cohesin are central to human development, homeostasis and disease. Here we address how cohesin controls genomic processes and how cohesin function is regulated by a network of interacting proteins. We propose to address these aims by a collaborative, interdisciplinary approach that combines our expertise in structural biology, biochemistry, cell biology, model organisms and integrative imaging across scales. This will link atomic structures to molecular mechanisms and organismal functions.

Project Title: UKSA NSIP: Advanced Instrumentation and Control for autonomous operations of Fission Surface Power.
Project Description: Nuclear technologies have played a pivotal role supporting space exploration, their significance growing with ambitions for human exploration of the Moon and Mars. Development of Fission Surface Power and nuclear microreactors presents possibilities for meeting energy demands of future missions, but critical challenges in Instrumentation and Control (I&C) systems need to be addressed to ensure long-term operations. This project aims to identify these challenges while exploring opportunities to develop I&C systems for nuclear space technologies. A comprehensive analysis of user requirements and international best practice will underpin a roadmap guiding development of autonomous I&C systems crucial to future space missions.

Project Title: UKSA: NSIP Fission Thermoelectric Generator

Project Title: Understanding and Enabling women from ethnically dIverse backgrouNds with meTastatic brEast canceR to live with and beyond cancer through targeted physicAl aCtivity inTervention  (INTERACT)
Project Description: Despite the known benefits of physical activity (PA), approximately seven out of ten patients become less active following a cancer diagnosis, and one third of patients are inactive during treatment. We know that higher levels of PA are associated with a reduced risk for breast cancer and there is potential benefit of PA in improving survival for individuals. This project will assess levels of PA in women from underserved communities with metastatic breast cancer, working with them in focus groups to design culturally adapted and relevant PA interventions. Materials and outcome education programmes will be delivered in linguistically-appropriate, culturally sensitive and preferred formats to improve engagement and uptake.

Project Title: Changing values, changing identities: Reassessing public attitudes towards society and nation in Britain, c. 1939 to 1979
Project Description: This project will use secondary analysis of opinion polls hosted by the UK Data Archive and the ERSC-funded UK Gallup Poll Collection to test influential models of social change and national identity in mid twentieth-century Britain. Contemporary debates over the existence or otherwise of a ‘generation gap’, a ‘permissive society’ and ‘women’s emancipation’ continue to divide historians. Equally contested are the concepts of Americanisation, popular imperialism, post-imperial nostalgia that inform work on the evolution of national identity, and of the extent to which Britain evolved into a multicultural society. The recent release of full datasets for hundreds of Gallup polls from this period, when augmented by the NOP and wartime BIPO polls hosted by the UKDA, enables public opinions on youth, morality, gender equality, America, Empire, decolonisation and migration to be assessed afresh. The representative samples and chronological span of these polls offer more reliable measures of British attitudes over time than do individual sociological studies or the widely used Mass-Observation archive. Moreover, polling organisations’ systematic recording and sampling of demographic characteristics enable greater precision in identifying how these attitudes varied along lines of class, gender, age, nation, region, religion, education, voting intention and marital and parental status. By applying quantitative techniques to cultural history, the project will simultaneously broaden the methodology of contemporary British history and supply new answers to some of its most vital and intractable questions.
Name of Call: ESRC responsive mode: secondary data analysis round two

Project Title: Deviant deaths: research and methodological gaps in managing death at the border
Project Description: The complex issue of obligations towards irregular migrants has been debated for many years with results in topics such as asylum, integration and expulsion. Little if any attention has been dedicated however to the obligations towards irregular migrants dying during border crossing, especially when they do not carry any identification or other documentation. Relevant aspects of International Humanitarian Law (IHL) do not apply in migration while International Human Rights Law sidesteps the issue of migrant deaths, allowing for a diversity of practices at state level. As a result, these practices often fall short of the established dignified funeral and commemoration practices, varying from makeshift cemeteries to unmarked graves and bodies stored in fridges. My research project will conduct a scope review of the practices in the three Southern European entry points in Spain, Italy and Greece with an aim to provide recommendations for states to establish best practices around their duties to treat individuals with respect and dignity after death.

Project Title: Multimode attitude and orbit control system for in-orbit servicing
Project Description:
In this collaborative project between the universities of  Leicester and Surrey, relative attitude and orbit control systems and algorithms will be developed to control a chaser cubesat towards a non cooperative target cubesat for in-orbit servicing.

Multimode relative navigation and control algorithms will be developed to manage the close formations, rendezvous and magnetic docking modes and the safety and stability of the mode transitions. They will first be validated in simulation before being tested and validated in real time using air cushioned  cubesat  simulators floating over a granite table facility from the Surrey Space Centre, University of Surrey.

Algorithms will be developed to control the linear relative orbital dynamics and nonlinear attitude dynamics using relative motion feedback and using onboard propulsion for both attitude and orbit control, assuming realistic  relative orbit scenarios, such as the 2:1 ellipse, teardrop and drifting orbits.

Control algorithms will allow for the estimation and compensation of   disturbances on the attitude, including aerodynamic and magnetic torques due to magnetic docking equipment. Relative attitude and orbit estimation will be obtained by combining the fusion of relative position sensors and computer vision techniques.

At the requirements definition stage, low cost but sufficiently reliable technologies and software platforms that originated from the drones, robotics and nanosatellite system and technologies will be evaluated for the viability as cubesat systems. During the first 12 months, numerical simulations of the relative attitude control systems will be developed for realistic servicing missions scenarios and orbits, and the ability to run algorithms in real time will be tested on onboard computers with realistic capabilities. At the final experimental validation stage, algorithms will be implemented on the cubesat demonstrators, which will closely replicate systems used in cubesats.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes:
Collaboration with Surrey Space Centre, University of Surrey.

Project Title: Power Management for Radioisotope Dynamic Generator
Project Description:
My name is Mihails, I'm the CEO of Deep Space Energy - the private company based in Latvia. We design a new concept of dynamic heat-to-electricity converter based on a radio-isotope source. My company is awarded by ESA with the related contract, which is ongoing now.
 
I'm reaching out to you following the suggestion of Christophe Fongarland because your team were recently awarded by ESA to investigate the power management conditioning for the hybrid RTG-solar power system.
 
Although our contract on the dynamic conversion system is still ongoing, it became clear already that heat and power should be extensively managed in such the system - there are various power conversion scenarios that should be mitigated by the heat/power management system.
 
We would like to investigate whether we can adjust/supplement your work on the management of the hybrid RTG-solar power system with the conditions for the radioisotope dynamic conversion system?

Project Title: Contested Desires: Constructive Dialogues
Project Description: This is a European Commission funded project (1m euros)  – under the Creative Europe Programme (CREA) that explores contested colonial legacies and considers decolonisation, activism and resistance within the frame of imperialist European power structures and narratives. The multi-partner project explores the role that arts organisations, artist collectives, organised, community- and arts-based action and artistic outputs can play in addressing problematic retellings or erasure of our colonial past. In full recognition of the complex and contested nature of heritage and of the ways in which heritage can provide stability and rootedness for some, whilst generating alienation and trauma for others, Contested Desires will co-create spaces for difficult conversations using a bottom-up and collaborative approach. The project begins with heritage institutions and museums working in equal partnership with organisations working with artists, communities and partners. The research partners aim to develop an equitable methodology and create meaningful dialogue to extend the depth, shared understanding and approaches of cultural organisations who are thinking deeply about cultural heritage and how it is understood locally. They will compare how heritage institutions, artists and producers speak to this complex subject, and explore the role of contemporary art in questioning and opening up narratives of history and identity to scrutiny.

Project Title: Orbyts: Establishing researcher-in-school partnerships in the Midlands and North-East
Project Description:
The Orbyts programme aims to address chronic diversity issues and specialist teacher shortages by offering transformative researcher-school partnerships to students from groups that have historically been excluded from science. 
The Orbyts programme partners passionate science researchers with groups of school students to work on original science research projects. The researchers mentor school students on a research project in 10 weekly after school sessions throughout the academic year, empowering the students to have ownership of the research. 
During these sessions, the students explore complex science topics within STFC science areas in a supportive environment which challenges their knowledge far-beyond school level physics. The researchers provide relatable role models and humanise science research on an individual level. 
The Orbyts programme targets under-served communities to connect school students from all backgrounds with science.

Project Title: Copyright law and the mental health of creators: a case study of the music industry
Project Description:
Music has important economic, cultural, and therapeutic benefits for society. However, recent research has found high levels of self-reported anxiety, depression, and eating disorders in musicians, at greater prevalence than the general population. This highlights a conflict between the value of music and the demands placed on
creators. This project addresses this from an interdisciplinary legal perspective, particularly how it relates to copyright law’s goal of ensuring that creators are motivated to continue producing creative and innovative works. Going beyond self-reported findings, this project will carry out in-depth interviews with mental health professionals to test not only if but also why musicians may be at risk of mental health issues. This provides findings relevant to current debates on the ability of copyright law to protect the creator, including recent proposals on equitable remuneration provisions, and text and data mining.

Project Title: Leave No One Behind? Governing Global Futures
Project Description: Leave no one behind (LNOB) is the central, transformative promise of the 2030 United Nations Agenda for Sustainable Development and its Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In imagining the future, to 2030 and beyond, this project will look to the most marginalised and what they can tell us about the prospects for equality and non-discrimination. This project will explore multiple interactions and paradoxes in the governance of citizenship and noncitizenship, highlighting the scope and limits of the many and complex interactions between the local and the global.

Project Title: Early Prevention: Acid Violence and Changing attitudes Project
Project Description:
Acid Survivors Trust International (ASTI) are seeking an academic partner to evaluate a pilot intervention project. ASTI are proposing to develop a 'graphic novel', which will be rolled out to schools and YOTs in East London. The aim is to reduce acid violence and change attitudes towards survivors. The role of the UoL will be to develop the evaluation methodology for any future wider roll out.  With their experience of conducting research in relation to acid attacks and of evaluation methodology, academics from the School of Criminology, University of Leicester would be well suited to do this.  We would propose to frame the pilot study evaluation work around two key questions focusing on process and outcomes: 
1.	How has the pilot intervention been implemented and does this require any future refinement?  
2.	How might effectiveness be measured?  
With these questions in mind, the pilot evaluation work would comprise four strands: 
1.	Process interviews:  up to ten interviews would be conducted with delivery partners and trainers. The purpose of those interviews would be to understand how the pilot intervention is being implemented in their area and what challenges are being encountered. Specific themes for the interviews would include: 

•	Target recruitment –how participants are recruited;
•	How the intervention is being implemented - including where and when;
•	Collection of monitoring data – what data is being collected on number of and the characteristics of participants. 

 It would be intended to conduct these interviews online via Teams or Skype.  
2.  Target group views of intervention: a further set of interviews would be conducted with recipients of the intervention. The purpose of these interviews would be to obtain some qualitative insight relating to perpetrator views about the intervention. In particular: 
•	Their views about how the intervention is being implemented by partners;
•	Views about the content of the digital comic book;
•	How the intervention increased their knowledge and awareness about the long-term psychological/ physical and negative social impact of acid violence; 
•	How the digital comic book changed their attitudes to the dangers and risks of acid violence. 
We would aim to conduct up to twenty qualitative interviews. These interviews would be conducted online via Teams or Skype and would require the assistance of the delivery partners to arrange. 
3. Development and testing of an evaluation questionnaire: A project evaluation questionnaire would be developed that would aim to capture quantitative measures of (a) knowledge and awareness of acid violence and (b) attitude change about acid violence. A questionnaire would be developed from existing survey tools that have carefully constructed measures of beliefs about aggression, attitudes towards violence, beliefs about weapons carrying and use; and attitudes to weapons carrying and use (see Dahlberg et al, 2005).  Prior to the use of the questionnaire in the field we would complete some cognitive testing with young people in Leicester (this would aim to establish that young people could read/ understand the questions).  The fully tested questionnaire would then be used in the pilot evaluation. In order to establish impact; all recipients of the intervention would need to complete the questionnaire twice. First, before the intervention in order to establish a baseline measure. Second, after intervention in order to measure impact. There would need to be some discussion about how the questionnaire would be administrated in the field and the time frames between the pre and post-tests.  It is hoped that the questionnaires could be administrated by delivery partners. These could be made available in online formats if necessary.    
4. Development of longer term outcome measures: during the pilot evaluation consideration would also be given to the development of any future evaluation methodology if the project were to be rolled out. We would make recommendations as to whether the evaluation instruments tested in the pilot phase would require refinement and also whether it would be feasible to develop further indictors of impact – such as changes in numbers of corrosive subsistence crimes across impact areas (as measured against comparison group areas). 
The findings and recommendations would be presented in a succinct twenty page report. The pilot evaluation would also be subject to University of Leicester ethical clearance.

Project Title: Climate Adaptation In Superdiverse Cities: How Do Communication Ecologies Shape Knowledge Production In The 'Leicester Lab'?
Project Description: Scientists and policymakers emphasise the need for local community engagement with the increasingly urgent global problem of climate change. However, efforts to mitigate and adapt to a warming world most often either "preach to the choir" of community members already engaged with the problem or generate top-down communication strategies. The proposed project reaches out to a broad range of people living in superdiverse Leicester, a particularly instructful city -- the "Leicester Lab" -- for learning how diverse socio-cultural contexts shape "environmental citizenship." Applying the communication ecology framework to a focus group design, the project examines the communication spaces and resources -- interpersonal, cross-cultural, and institutional, including professional media and government communications channels -- that shape how people from different social and cultural groups engage with climate adaptation efforts. The project aims to enhance Leicester's communication ecology and communicate a diversity of perspectives to policymakers.

Project Title: Facilitating inclusion of people with intellectual disabilities in health research: working with funders and experts by experience to develop change
Project Description:
The aim of the project is to increase inclusion of people with intellectual disabilities (PwID) in health and care research. To reach this aim we will first bring together key stakeholders including, but not limited to, people with lived experience, academics, clinicians, commercial research organisations and funders of research (e.g., NIHR). 
Through this effective meeting of stakeholders, we will be able to understand and build a body of knowledge around what is currently happening in research organisations and what would support them to include people with intellectual disabilities. This will enable us to develop a resource to be used by commercial companies and research funders that will support and encourage inclusion. With support of stakeholders a plan for implementation will be created so effective change can take place.

Project Title: Professionalising ‘Museums in Health’ practice: care, emotion, and boundary work in the museum
Project Description: Museums in health’ (Chatterjee and Noble, 2015) describes a rapidly growing area of museum and art gallery work in the UK and internationally, whereby the cultural heritage sector is repositioned as a key partner in helping deliver health and wellbeing outcomes for individuals and communities. Museum engagement (including art galleries and heritage sites) is increasingly moving into formal healthcare, mental health and social care environments, and into ‘therapeutic relationships’ with patients and vulnerable individuals, but the sector has yet to fully understand the wide-ranging implications for the definition, organisation and development of this work. The project responds by exploring the processes of professional identity construction within ‘museums in health’ to gain insights into the responsibilities and demands of the work and its current professionalisation needs. The project aims to more fully conceptualise the nature of ‘museums in health’ practice as a distinct subfield of museum work to inform the development of sector support, training, guidance and frameworks for ‘museums in health’ careers.

Project Title: Tracking the coral Giants to predict coral reef health under anthropogenically warming oceans
Project Description:
="-multi-century old, often massive corals are true survivors of climate change due to their stress tolerant life history traits
-Species include Porites sp., Diploastrea sp. in the Indo-Pacific and Orbicella sp. in the Caribbean, with maximum ages in the range of 400-600 years of continuous upwards growth
-these massive and long-lived corals harbor unique genetically encoded strategies which allow them to withstand acute and chronic environmental stressors including those from variations in temperature, nutrient levels, suspended sediment concentrations…
-giant corals are supported by a strong scaffolding, their calcium carbonate skeleton, given them unique abilities to withstand high energy events like cyclones and storm waves
-the old giants are the elders of the global coral reefs and provide a structure for colonization by a variety of reef building organisms like anemones, sea fans (Alcyonacea), Christmas worms, sea urchins, bryozoans, soft corals, gorgonians and provide unique cryptic habitat underneath and in between their massive skeletal structures for sponges and a multitude of reef fish - all together they form super-biodiversity hotspots within a reefal network carefully spaced in particular habitats - (they may serve as geographical position markers for larger predators and turtles?)
-their massive size makes them easily extremely vulnerable to human fishing gear (nets and lines)  and boat engine and anker damage
-many fishing communities know about  the existence of some of the giants from their daily fishing excursions, yet often lack the knowledge of their immense age and value to the local biodiversity
-once fishing communities are made aware of their old age they suddenly achieve significance as natural and cultural heritage structures under the sea that are extremely worth protecting from anthropogenic stressors
-the giants can tell stories locked in their chemical, micro- and macro morphological and genetic makeup about the long-term climatic and environmental changes that have shaped the reef and the giants themselves over many centuries, often providing a direct link to human storylines of past experiences of climate variations by village elders passed down from generation to generation, making them extremely powerful adaptation tools in response to challenging environmental events and periods
-we aim to tap into this tight connection of fishing communities with their reef environment and their cultural heritage to map out the distribution of the true giants geographically to develop mapped out zones of protecting the giants from anthropogenic impacts, use photogrammetry to accurately measure their size and circumference and help species identification aided by micro- and macro morphological taxonomy, 
-furthermore we will characterize their genetic makeup incl. whole genome sequencing to specify regional genetic adaptations to environmental conditions to identify genetic traits that underpin their ability to have exceptional long life spans and sustaining stressful acute and chronic events - we aim to identify why certain regions harbor those giants
-we will develop long histories of skeletal growth and the geochemical composition of the corals at annual resolution for various proxies reflecting physical ocean properties incl. temperature, nutrient cycles (d15N), salinity, pH and sediment input (where appropriate) to develop environmental storylines that will resonate with fishing communities in providing solid knowledge for education and conservation measures 

-the project is urgent because current ocean warming and long-lasting marine heatwaves have started to affect some of those giants through coral bleaching potentially losing them before we understand the genetic adaptations that helped them survive up to now - those specific genetic adaptations may harbor untapped scientific information that would help to ensuring the survival of the giants and the species that surround and depend on them, including humans"

Project Title: Reactive Sulfur Species mediate oxidative stress in ageing and disease
Project Description:
While cellular oxidative stress is a fundamental driver of disease and ageing, reactive oxygen species (ROS) inhibition fails to alter ageing, disease initiation or outcomes. This suggests that other cellular oxidants may significantly contribute to oxidative stress. 

I recently discovered that reactive sulfur species (RSS), such as persulfides and polysulfides, are limited by superoxide dismutase (SOD1). This indicates that endogenous RSS, whose concentrations far exceed ROS, may contribute to cellular oxidative stress. I have also published that RSS are potent cellular oxidants that induce stress signalling. Therefore, RSS, which are not affected by ROS-targeting antioxidants, may be significant contributors to cellular oxidative stress. 

Our key goal is to determine if reactive sulfur species (RSS) drive the cellular effects of oxidative stress. Using in vivo and ex vivo models of ageing, cancer, and diabetes, the role of RSS in oxidative stress will be delineated. Specifically, protein oxidation and aggregation, genomic instability, and inflammation will be investigated. Collectively, these studies will determine if endogenous RSS contribute to cellular oxidative stress in ageing and disease. This bold programme will be paradigm shifting, as it will provide deeper understanding of, and potentially strategies to limit, disease and ageing.

Project Title: Family Court Reporting and Monitoring Mechanism Pilot
Project Description:
This project is being commissioned by the office of the Domestic Abuse Commissioner. The DAC have an inhouse team of two senior researchers but want an academic team to lead on a two part evaluation comprising, firstly, a scoping of existing data sets, and secondly, an in depth analysis at selected courts of a sample of cases, including focus groups/interviews with interested parties. The aim is to pilot the mechanism for roll out on a periodic review basis.

This project runs on from a previous design project undertaken by Mandy Burton and Rosemary Hunter (Kent University). It is intended that Mandy will lead on this project and Rosemary Hunter be included as a direct cost co I / consultant for the scoping element of the study. This collaboration began as part of their co-authorship of the Harm Panel report into family cases (MoJ, 2020).

This project builds on the Harm Panel report recommendations, part of a REF case study for REF 2021. It will generate fresh impact in this REF period, as it is piloting a mechanism which, if successful, will report on the operation of the family courts for years to come, resulting in greater accountability and oversight, and improvements in child arrangement cases in the family courts.

Project Title: Development and evaluation of an online FeNO-guided primary care asthma management intervention
Project Description: Background: asthma remains a big problem 5.4 million people in the UK have asthma, which costs the NHS £1.1 billion/year. 300 people/day are admitted to hospital and 3 people die daily. Most deaths and attacks could be prevented by better treatment. People can mostly control asthma by taking preventer inhalers every day to reduce inflammation and reliever inhalers as needed but for flare-ups (exacerbations), people may need steroid tablets, or even admission to hospital. Monitoring inflammation in asthma: using FeNO in general practice Asthma is caused by inflammation but how people feel does not always match how much inflammation is in their airways. Hospital clinics sometimes use a simple breath test called fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) to measure inflammation. This helps them ensure that patients are taking their inhalers properly and are on the right dose to prevent exacerbations. Measuring FeNO can also help show who can reduce treatment safely, potentially lessening side-effects, improving quality of life, and saving costs. 75% of asthma patients have an annual GP check-up. However, it is not clear yet whether FeNO measurement helps at these check-ups. At the moment, it's only done in people with severe asthma who attend a hospital clinic. It may be that using these tests more widely would cut asthma attacks and help decide when the inhaler doses need increasing or can be cut. NICE has asked for further research. Research plan: Our research will: -Produce an online training package for doctors and nurses in GP surgeries to help them use FeNO effectively -See if this package reduces exacerbations and improves quality of life. -Help policymakers make asthma services more efficient. We will work with asthma experts, GPs, nurses and patients. Professionals and patients at GP surgeries will try out our package and suggest improvements. We will do a research study involving over 2500 asthma patients from around 130 GP surgeries. Patient representatives will be involved at all stages, including helping to design study materials and information leaflets and making sure that the study is acceptable to patients. Working with the public and patients We have expertise in involving asthma patients and developing training packages for professionals. We are working with Asthma UK, who have helped us to plan the study and will raise awareness about our research. One of the members of our team is a patient with asthma who has contributed the patient perspective. We have also received valuable advice and support from our NIHR PPI advisor. We will go on to form a core group of 6 patient advisors who will be offered appropriate training and who will meet 3 times a year. We will invite 2 people with asthma to join the Trial Steering Committee. Research question Does implementation of an optimised FeNO-guided management intervention during routine primary care asthma reviews reduce acute exacerbations of asthma? Background Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are the cornerstone of treatment to reduce eosinophilic airway inflammation and prevent acute exacerbations. However, despite a 30% increase in spending on ICS treatment in England since 2007, annual asthma-related mortality, hospitalisation and exacerbation rates have not improved since 2000. Most monitoring of asthma occurs in primary care, where treatment decisions are based on symptoms and lung function. However, these measures do not reliably indicate eosinophilic airway inflammation or future exacerbation risk. Fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) is a simple, non-invasive breath test which is already extensively used to assess eosinophilic airway inflammation in UK hospital settings, but rarely in primary care. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) recognises the value of FeNO in diagnosis of asthma, but has highlighted the need for more robust evidence to guide its use in monitoring asthma treatment. Aims and objectives To iteratively develop and refine a complex online FeNO-guided asthma management intervention for use in primary care. To determine whether our intervention is more effective than usual care in reducing acute exacerbations of asthma. To assess the cost-effectiveness of our intervention. To investigate potential influences on implementation and outcomes of our intervention in primary care. Methods To develop and refine our intervention, we will conduct systematic theory, evidence and person-based intervention planning informed by consultation with stakeholders, qualitative interviews with health care professionals and patients, and small-scale implementation in general practices. We will then evaluate the effectiveness of our intervention by conducting a pragmatic parallel randomised controlled trial (RCT) in UK general practices. To optimise our recruitment strategy and procedures, we will perform a three-month internal pilot phase, proceeding to the main phase if pre-specified progression criteria are met. We will conduct an economic evaluation based on trial findings to determine whether our intervention is cost-effective and a mixed methods process evaluation of our intervention involving quantitative process outcomes and qualitative interviews with health care professionals and patients. Timelines for delivery We will produce our optimised intervention during the first 18 months of our programme and complete the internal pilot phase of our RCT by the end of year 2, progressing to the main phase in year 3. We will aim to complete recruitment by the end of year 3 and collection of follow-up data by the end of year 4. We will complete our analysis of RCT data, economic evaluation, and process evaluation by the end of year 5. Anticipated impact and dissemination Our findings will have strong potential to influence national guidelines and clinical practice within five years of this programme being completed. We will work with policymakers and guideline developers to incorporate our findings into BTS/SIGN and NICE guidance. We will also make our online intervention freely available to health care professionals and raise awareness of our intervention through scientific publications, conference presentations, educational workshops, and patient organisations including Asthma UK.

Project Title: Round Mounds of the Isle of Man Post-Excavation
Project Description:
Since 2016 Dr Rachel Crellin (University of Leicester) and Prof Chris Fowler (Newcastle University) have co-directed the 'Round Mounds of the Isle of Man' project, investigating Neolithic and Early Bronze Age burials and mortuary monuments on the Isle of Man (c. 4000-1500 BC). The work has included analysis of historic records and LiDAR imagery, geophysical surveys, osteological analysis of prehistoric human remains in the Manx Museum collection, radiocarbon dating, ancient DNA analysis, and stable isotope analysis of human remains. A brief summary of these results is presented below, but collectively they significantly enhance our ability to understand life and death in these periods of the distant past. The project also involved excavation of Neolithic occupation activity and an Early Bronze Age burial mound at Cronk Guckley, Berk Farm, Kirk Michael, the first such site to be excavated on the Isle of Man using twenty-first century archaeological methods, and the first on the island to yield an iconic jet spacer-plate necklace.

The current funding application is for a final phase of work which includes post-excavation analysis of the environmental evidence, artefacts and human remains found during the excavation and production of a monograph to complete the entire project. The funding is necessary to finish the archaeological research and present it for both a broad and specialist readership, and to archive all of the project data and the archaeological remains recovered from the excavation with Manx National Heritage. The monograph will tell the story of 2500 years of life and death on the Isle of Man long before recorded history, explore the identities, lives and deaths of those whose remains were buried at Berk Farm, and set the course of prehistory on the Isle of Man in its wider regional context.

Newcastle University and the University of Leicester have supported the project throughout and where possible staff time will again be provided with no cost to MNH.
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes:
This is a collaborative grant application with Newcastle University with Prof Chris Fowler. We have been working together collaboratively on this since 2016. This has included research in the museum and an extensive program of fieldwork and excavation. This grant application will be led by Newcastle who will submit the application and the funding will go to them. They will then forward on to us the items detailed in this worktribe outline. 

The application is going to Manx National Heritage - they have funded 4 seasons of excavation to date (2019 funds were held by Leicester). They are the national heritage body of the Isle of Man. We developed this project with them collaboratively and in conversation.

Project Title: Either here or there: A mixed method analysis of consultation modalities for epilepsy reviews with people with Intellectual disabilities
Project Description:
Around 400,000 people with intellectual disabilities (PwID) in the UK have epilepsy. PwID and epilepsy have worse health
outcomes than those without epilepsy or Intellectual Disabilities. There are also differences in health outcomes within the PwID
and epilepsy population. Older PwID and epilepsy (>40 years ), and those with more severe conditions are at greater risk of
preventable epilepsy related harm or increased emergency care use for conditions that could have been managed or treated in
the community.
During COVID-19 this patient population continued to receive routine care from specialist doctors, but it was often over the
phone or a video call rather than in person, face-to-face. Care continues to be provided using these various approaches, but
we do not know which ways of providing care work best for which patients, and when.
It is important to examine this for different groups of patients, particularly those who are most vulnerable and those most at risk
of reduced inclusion through hybrid approaches. Therefore, we will focus on three groups within the ID community:
1. PwID and epilepsy who are unable to engage in a consultation themselves and need their families and carers to
speak for them (usually have moderate to profound ID).
2. PwID and epilepsy who can engage in a consultation but not without the support of family or a carer(usually have mild
to moderate ID).
3. People with mild ID and epilepsy who self-manage their own health.
Aims
We want to know more about healthcare professionals, patient and carer preference for different types of appointments,
explore the benefits or disadvantages for different groups and examine views and issues about patient safety related to
consultation type (phone/video/face-to-face).
Design and methods
We will carry out surveys and interviews (co-produced with experts by experience) with the patient populations mentioned, and
their families and carers. In addition, we will conduct surveys and interviews with members of the clinical and administrative
teams involved with the delivery of care/consultations to find out about the experiences of participating in consultations inperson,
over the phone or through video-link.
PPI
Public advisor input from carers and also input from patient advisor(s) with mild ID and epilepsy have provided their views on
the importance of this topic area. They will be working with us throughout this study to provide their lived experience to our
understanding of the issues. They will co-produce study documentation, contribute to meetings throughout, and be involved
with the interpretation of the findings.
Dissemination
Workshops, peer reviewed publications, stakeholder and academic presentations and dissemination to target policy and
practitioner-based audiences via Applied Research Collaboration (ARC) newsletters, blogs and social media. We will
disseminate to lay audiences using lay summaries and our PPI and third sector collaborators.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes:
Please note that the lead unit at Leicester is Population Health Sciences, but the lead unit overall is University of Plymouth.
I am a co-investigator for this study; the lead investigator is Rohit Shankar at University of Plymouth.

Project Title: Cardiovascular Risk Detection, Intervention, and  Outreach in Sub-Saharan Africa
Project Description:
Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) are  rising in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), constituting 35% of deaths . Cardiovascular diseases (CVD), diabetes, and hypertension are the most common NCDs, with CVD leading the NCD-related death toll in SSA2. Over 75% of global CVD deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), with 3 out of every 4 adults of the world's 537 million diabetes cases are in LMICs. In SSA, approximately 4-5% of adults have type 2 diabetes, mostly undiagnosed, and 19-31% are overweight. Hypertension affects over 1.1 billion globally, with two-thirds in LMICs. SSA faces increasing average blood pressure levels and the world's lowest awareness, treatment, and control rates. These conditions  reduce life expectancy by about 6 years. Factors contributing to this surge include urbanization, changing lifestyles, healthcare system focus on communicable diseases, an aging population , low health literacy, healthcare disparities, underfunded systems, and complex socio-cultural beliefs. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) prevalence is also underestimated, with genetic factors like APOL1 playing a role. NCDs receive insufficient attention in public health programs, and prevention and detection strategies are often imported from Western models. There is a critical need to re-design CVD prevention strategies to be context-specific and co-created with local communities. 

Task shifting, exemplified by successful programs in Cameroon and South Africa, shows the potential of community health workers (CHWs) in CVD prevention. Established CHW models for communicable diseases can be adapted to enhance capacity in detecting  obesity, hypertension, and diabetes, bolstering prevention efforts, and monitoring to reduce CVD-related deaths .

Project Title: The Politics of Antibiotics: Who Should Govern Antimicrobial Resistance? (FORMAS)
Project Description:
International collaboration to investigate who bears the responsibility to govern antimicrobial resistance. 

We are interested in three aspects of (political) responsibility  - the who, what, and how, this will allow us to examine the following three questions that are rudimentary to politics: who should do it (govern or steer); what (substance) should be done; and how (procedure) should that be realized.

Empirical research will include surveys, experiments and interviews, conducted mainly in Sweden in Spain.

Project Title: UK SPF Growth Accelerator for Social Entrepreneurs
Project Description:
We are delivering a growth accelerator project for social entrepreneurs with accumulating and cascading benefits which are bigger than the sum of its parts. We will utilise: highly developed learning platforms; evidence of what works in both business growth and executive education; cutting edge approaches to developing peer support communities; leading consultants and expert management training to shore up and grow purpose driven businesses. Support will include: a Growth Masterclass Course; Growth Voucher for 1:1 support; and a Growth Ecosystem including peer group challenge sessions, co-working, and meet ups.
 
Onboarding will include the auditing of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats to match businesses to peer support super groups, tutors, consultants and fellow social entrepreneurs. Course content will be curated, consultancy tailored, and peer support focused to deliver multiple action-based impacts. We will create teams of peer entrepreneurs to crowdsource strategic development and the implementation of growth strategies.
 
We will amplify the expertise of Leicester’s leading social enterprise consultants, (CASE and CEE) with high level University resources including: Learning platforms; R&D support; library services, conference rooms, meeting rooms, co-working spaces, world class experts, and capacity through staff and student volunteering and projects.
 
This project will be delivered by three consortium partners:  The University of Leicester’s School of Business (ULSB), The Cooperative and Social Enterprise Development Agency (CASE), and Community Enterprise Engine (CEE).

Project Title: Unveiling the complexity of breast cancer by leveraging single-cell multi-OMICS: Analysis of circulating tumour cells for improved patient management
Project Description:
Breast cancer (BC) mortality rates have decreased in recent years, but recurrence remains a significant challenge. Improved prognostic and predictive tests for treatment response are needed, as current methods relying on tissue biopsies and imaging have limitations. Liquid biopsies, such as analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) and circulating tumor cells (CTCs), offer a minimally invasive and promising approach for tracking cancer progression. However, ctDNA may not be the optimal biomarker for studying disease progression, and CTCs hold potential for determining treatment resistance and guiding therapy.

CTCs carry comprehensive information about the parent tumor, including proteins, DNA, and RNA, making them valuable for analyzing tumor heterogeneity and relapse. Previous studies have shown that CTC counts alone do not predict survival outcomes in breast cancer. Therefore, understanding CTC biology at the single-cell level is crucial due to cellular heterogeneity.
New technologies have emerged to detect heterogeneous CTCs, including those undergoing epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT). These advancements aim to improve on existing systems like CellSearch, which only detect epithelial CTCs expressing EpCAM. However, these platforms are costly, and isolating pure single CTCs is challenging due to white blood cell contamination. Simplifying and cost-effective workflows are necessary for detecting and isolating individual CTCs while preserving their integrity for analysis.
In this research project, a collaboration with Thermofisher Scientific will be established to develop a novel workflow using the KingFisherTM Apex robotic system. This system aims to isolate CTCs with high purity, minimizing white blood cell background. The KingFisherTM Apex has shown comparable recovery rates to CellSearch and Parsortix systems but demonstrated superior background levels. The low white blood cell background allows for advanced analysis and sequencing of single cells.
The project will refine the KingFisher workflow and integrate it with the PhenoImager Fusion system for deep single-cell phenotyping and spatial analysis of CTCs. The evaluation of transmembrane glycoproteins like TROP-2 and HER2 will be conducted, exploring their potential as antibody-drug conjugate targets. The project will also investigate whether molecular profiling of CTCs enables the successful triage of patients for highly toxic antibody-drug conjugates.
The research will be embedded within the ongoing ATHENA study, enriching blood samples for CTCs using the KingFisherTM Apex. Deep-cell phenotyping and spatial analysis will be performed using the Akoya PhenoImager Fusion system. Additionally, CTCs will be isolated for transcriptomics, and single-cell gene expression analysis will be conducted using the 10X Genomics and Oxford Nanopore Technologies systems.
This ambitious fellowship aims to develop a liquid biopsy-based multi-omics workflow for identifying biomarkers in CTCs to guide treatment decisions in metastatic breast cancer (mBC). The research will contribute to expanding our understanding of CTCs and resistance mechanisms, potentially uncovering novel therapeutic targets to improve the management of mBC patients globally.

Project Title: Understanding the mechanism of IgAN progression
Project Description:
IgA nephropathy (IgAN) is a chronic kidney disease that occurs when an antibody called, immunoglobulin A (IgA) builds-up in the kidney. Normally, IgA plays a key role in the immune system in fighting against infections. However, in people with IgAN, a defective form of IgA antibody accumulates in the glomeruli (the blood filtration units of the kidney) prompting a series of adverse immune responses. This ultimately results in severe damage of the glomeruli, disruption of blood filtration processes and possible loss kidney function. 

IgAN is often diagnosed in young adults and due to its progressive nature, the life expectancy of affected persons is reduced by up to 10 years. It is a debilitating condition that not only imposes a significant burden on patients' physical and emotional well-being, but also strains healthcare systems due to the high costs associated with long-term treatment.

The severity of IgAN varies among patients. Some people have mild symptoms and may not need treatment, while others have more severe symptoms and may need medication or even a kidney transplant. About 3 out of 10 IgAN patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years of being diagnosed. 

My research seeks to understand why IgAN affects people differently. I would like to find out if the severity of the disease is related to the type of IgA proteins that are produced by the patient. I would also like to investigate the contribution of two types of cells found in the glomeruli (namely, mesangial cells and endothelial cells) to IgAN development. By carrying out these investigations, I hope to better understand which factors drive the progression of IgAN.

Project Title: Testing a Novel Proteomic Panel for Exclusion of Coronary Artery Disease: Internal and External Clinical Validation with a High Throughput Multiplexed Targeted Mass Spectrometry Assay.
Project Description: Coronary artery disease (CAD) poses an immense global health burden. Current risk stratification tools overestimate CAD prevalence, thus there is a need to refine risk stratification to minimise the often-inappropriate cascade of downstream imaging tests. We aim to clinically validate a novel biomarker panel of circulating proteins identified in our pilot study for exclusion of CAD in low-risk patients presenting with chest pain. Plasma samples will be processed using a high-throughput, automated proteomics protocol and the putative CAD panel measured using a targeted mass spectrometry assay. Models for predicting CAD based on the panel will be trained on an internal validation cohort and tested in external validation cohorts, prioritising high negative predictive value. Predictive gains of the panel will be compared to other CAD risk stratification techniques such as the Framingham Score, and will be assessed for sex and ethnic differences as well as discrimination of high-risk plaque features. On completion, a novel multi-marker protein biomarker panel for coronary plaque burden will be validated. Patients presenting with chest pain who are excluded from CAD using this blood test need not undergo further imaging tests, reducing costs, downstream intervention, and burden on the healthcare system.

Project Title: Effect and mechanism of PD-1 inhibitor on cardiac fibrosis remodeling
Project Description: China and the UK are both countries with a high incidence of cancer. PD-1 inhibitors such as Pabolizumab, Nivolumab, Sintilimab and Toripalimab have been widely used in cancer patients in both countries, but their significant immune-related adverse events, in particular, cardiac toxicity, needs to be addressed. The purpose of this project is to bring together Chinese and British researchers to find the mechanisms and key targets of cardiac fibrosis remodeling caused by PD-1 inhibitors, and to find the drug that promises to reduce cardiotoxicity caused by PD-1 inhibitors.

Project Title: Wordsworth in India: Recovering the Colonial Legacies of English Literature
Project Description: 'Wordsworth in India' explores the influence of Wordsworth's poetry and the activities of the Wordsworth family on the educational and administrative cultures of late nineteenth-century India. The project focusses on the activities of John Wordsworth (1837-1927), a soldier involved in the suppression of the First Indian War of Independence, and William Wordsworth (1835-1917), Professor of English Literature and moral philosophy at Elphinstone and Deccan colleges in the 1860s and Principal and Vice-Chancellor of Bombay University from 1875-1890, to show how ideas adapted from Wordsworth's poetry informed the governance and education of Indian colonial subjects.
Funder: THE LEVERHULME TRUST The Leverhulme Trust

Project Title: Calorie restriction and epigenetic ageing in an insect model.
Project Description:
An epigenetic clock measures ageing by counting chemical marks on DNA. There is evidence epigenetic age mirrors true biological age and its associated mortality better than chronological age. A large body of ageing research is based on simple model organisms. However, the current invertebrate models of ageing (fruitfly and roundworm)  lack these chemical marks, reducing their generality.

We  discovered an epigenetic clock in  a tiny wasp. We will use calorie restriction  to establish that  epigenetic ageing can be slowed. This will allow future research on  these epigenetic factors  which with known plasticity, are tempting targets for anti-ageing interventions.
Funder: THE LEVERHULME TRUST The Leverhulme Trust
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: AI-Thyroid-Cancer Early Detection System
Project Description: The main goal of this proposal is to create an AI-Thyroid-Cancer Early Detection System that can analyze thyroid ultrasound images for suspicious nodules using deep learning. The proposed system is designed to be a single-backend system with multiple front ends, which features both a desktop (Web-based) and mobile interface. It will be integrated with portal ultrasound devices and software platforms to facilitate access through a user-friendly interface for ultrasound image analysis by deep learning. There will be many improvements with the proposed system over the current methods. By detecting subtle features that may be missed by human eyes, it can increase the detection rate of Thyroid cancer malignant nodules, avoid the need for biopsies and surgeries, save time and lives, and introduce new opportunities for innovation and collaboration in healthcare. We anticipate that the implementation of such a system will have far-reaching consequences for UK and Egypt's technological sector. As well as accelerating the growth of AI and the demand for AI solutions in the healthcare sector, its enormous potential may increase Egypt's international reputation and competitiveness in the AI industry.

Project Title: Diabetes in times of COVID-
Project Description:
This will be a collaboration with Kaberi Dasgupta, McGill University, Canada.

Aims Among persons with prevalent or newly-diagnosed diabetes during the study period (2016-2022):
1) To (a) examine associations between lower income level and diabetes-related emergency department (ED) visits, hospitalization, and mortality during prepandemic and pandemic periods and (b) assess for an increase in the magnitude of this association during the pandemic period 
2) To (a) examine associations between lower income level and having insufficient ambulatory follow-up (< 2 diabetes-related ambulatory care visits/year; in-person or virtual) during prepandemic and pandemic periods and (b) assess for an increase in the magnitude of this association during the pandemic 
3) To evaluate for mediation of associations between material deprivation and ED visits/hospitalization/mortality by a) insufficiency of ambulatory follow-up and/or b) amenability of employment to working from home in the prepandemic and pandemic periods
Among persons with newly-diagnosed diabetes during the study period (2016-2022):
4) To (a) examine associations between lower income level and having a new diagnosis presenting as a hyperglycemic emergency (diabetic ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar state) during prepandemic and pandemic periods and (b) assess for an increase in the magnitude of this association during the pandemic period 
We will address the above aims within (a) a Canadian cohort that does not include Quebec, (b) a Quebec cohort, and (c) a cohort from England. We will compare findings between cohorts. We will assess for differences a) among females compared to males and b) in relationship to ethnocultural background.

Project Title: Drug&tag, a method to identify the DNA signatures of clinical and environmental substances
Project Description: Lifetime exposures that individuals can (e.g., diet, smoking, alcohol, and substance consumption) or cannot control (e.g., pollutants, therapeutics and occupational exposures) can impact the likelihood of developing disease. Besides substances directly causing alterations in the DNA sequence, the immediate effect of many exposures is altering how the information in DNA is accessed, i.e., they drive epigenetic changes. To understand the mechanisms underlying these effects it would be important to identify the exact DNA sequences a substance is likely to influence. However, this can be a long and challenging task that usually relies on first identifying the interacting proteins. Here we propose to combine in a new way currently available approaches to develop a novel method, Drug&Tag, that will identify the DNA sequences affected by clinically relevant or environmental substances without having to know which proteins they interact with. The method will use Tn5, a transposase commonly used in genomics due to its ability to cut and paste adaptor sequences in the DNA it is proximal to. Our proof of principle proposal aims to generate Tn5-compound conjugates to identify signatures for the compounds in cells, in a manner similar to the well-established Cut&Tag approach in which proteinA-Tn5 conjugate are used to tag the sequences bound by specific antibodies. Drug &Tag has two main advantages over two recently reported methods (Chem-seq and Chem-MAP) addressing the same problem: 1. the drug is directly linked to Tn5 making the method faster has it has fewer steps; 2. the compound is linked to the beads via different attachment points thus ensuring all the interactions are captured. We will first establish and validate the method using JQ1, a compound shown to work in Chem-seq/Chem-MAP; and then test the effectiveness of Drug&Tag using the dietary compound resveratrol. We predict that once establish, Drug&Tag will have a varied range of potential application and benefits. For example, it could be used to produce signatures that could help distinguish sensitivity and resistance to treatments; or to identify the targets of wide spectrum compounds (e.g., dietary, pollutants, etc); or by pharmaceutical companies to test off targets or toxicity potential of drugs. Finally, it would be generally relevant to scientists, e.g., those in the pharmaco-, neuro- and nutri-(epi)genomics fields.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Internationalisation of Hate Crime Policies (IHaC)
Project Description: IHaC offers a new global perspective on hate crime governance, questioning prevailing assumptions about states' adoption of hate crime policies. This ambitious project presents two bold hypotheses: that effective hate crime responses hinge on robust democratic institutions and internationally connected "change agents"; and that state-led hate crime efforts are increasingly influenced by multilateral organisations, despite traditional state’s exclusive competence to decide in matters of crime and policing. The research highlights a rising global push for hate crime policies which prompts states to meet international standards or risk criticism. This has led to widespread policies addressing hate crimes tied to race, religion, sexual orientation, gender, and disability. However, these new frameworks can sometimes conflict with deep-seated social and legal norms, sparking debates about freedom of speech, religious rights, and concerns like neo-colonialism and gender equality. Moving beyond Western-centric studies limited to states as objects of analysis, IHaC spotlights international organisations that shape global hate crime standards. Utilising a mixed-methods approach, IHaC integrates insights from theories on criminalisation, policy diffusion, and norm transfer, significantly enriching the Hate Studies domain where this research is anchored. The project will be implemented by the Dr Piotr Godzisz as the PI and three early-career researchers based in the Centre for Hate Studies at the University of Leicester.

Project Title: Reappraising Substance Use through Investigating the Development of Psychedelic Microdosing
Project Description: We shall radically reorientate research into drug use/addiction through a developmental study of the growing use of psilocybin, LSD and other substances via microdosing: the repeated consumption of sub-hallucinogenic doses of psychedelics. Investigating the hitherto under-researched inter-connections between historical changes in the use of such substances and individual trajectories of drug use, our research will provide a pathbreaking analysis of the emergence of microdosing as a socio-cultural practice. Moreover, our highly innovative analytical and methodological approach shall provide field-defining insights into how shifting cultural framings and social norms are interrelated to individual and historical developments in substance-using practices more generally.
