Project Title: The impacts and implications of de-sexing language in reproductive health communications in the UK.
Project Description:
Research question
What are the impacts and implications of de-sexed language in relation to reproductive health communications for service users in the UK?

Background
Desexing language, or new linguistic formulations that alter meaning from a biological to an identity referent, has been introduced across organisations concerned with reproductive healthcare. The use of de-sexing language is an untested intervention and has been inconsistently deployed by charities, professional colleges, and the NHS. 


Objectives
1. Conduct a scoping review about the extent and impact of de-sexed language in reproductive health communications, including innovative communication approaches.
2. Determine how the change to de-sexed language in public health information impacts service user comprehension and effects assessment of personal health risk.
3. Describe the views and attitudes of service users to de-sexed language in reproductive health, including trust and engagement with health workers and organisations.
4. Describe the views, attitudes, and self-reported practices of health workers about the use and drivers of sexed/ desexed language. 
5. Use qualitative and review data to develop, implement and evaluate an UK online survey for service users and health workers about the impact of de-sexed language.
6. Develop clear guidance about use of de-sexed language for future public health policy and practice in organisations providing reproductive health services.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes:
Request to join external bid led by Professor Jenny Gamble - Coventry University/University Hospitals of Coventry and Warwickshire. 

Co-Is Professor Emeritus Susan Bewley (obstetrician), Professor Karleen Gribble and Professor Alice Sullivan. 
Research question
What are the impacts and implications of de-sexed language in relation to reproductive health communications for service users in the UK?

Background
Desexing language, or new linguistic formulations that alter meaning from a biological to an identity referent, has been introduced across organisations concerned with reproductive healthcare. The use of de-sexing language is an untested intervention and has been inconsistently deployed by charities, professional colleges, and the NHS. 


Objectives
1. Conduct a scoping review about the extent and impact of de-sexed language in reproductive health communications, including innovative communication approaches.
2. Determine how the change to de-sexed language in public health information impacts service user comprehension and effects assessment of personal health risk.
3. Describe the views and attitudes of service users to de-sexed language in reproductive health, including trust and engagement with health workers and organisations.
4. Describe the views, attitudes, and self-reported practices of health workers about the use and drivers of sexed/ desexed language. 
5. Use qualitative and review data to develop, implement and evaluate an UK online survey for service users and health workers about the impact of de-sexed language.
6. Develop clear guidance about use of de-sexed language for future public health policy and practice in organisations providing reproductive health services.

Project Title: Gypsy, Roma, Traveller Youth: Mitigating Exclusion(s) Through the Digital
Project Description:
Digital developments and participation are increasingly
important to youth in UK society, and this includes Gypsy
Roma and Traveller (GRT) young people (YP). There is scant
research evidence examining how GRT YP are using digital
technologies, but GRT voluntary sector organisations state
that use of smart phones and social media are popular daily
activities. The digital world offers connection to public and
other services, and a place for meeting, sharing knowledge,
opportunities, friendships, and networks, but there can be
risks and obstacles too. This 30-month study examines the
experiences of GRT YP (aged 15-24) and digital participation,
focusing on how online connections and networks work for YP
and how this might help counter, or cope with, socioeconomic
exclusions.
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)

Project Title: Climate Adaptation in Superdiverse Cities: How Do Communication Ecologies Shape Knowledge Production in the 'Leicester Lab'?
Project Description:
Scientists and policymakers emphasise the need for local community engagement with the increasingly urgent
global problem of climate change. However, efforts to mitigate and adapt to a warming world most often either
"preach to the choir" of community members already engaged with the problem or generate top-down
communication strategies. The proposed project reaches out to a broad range of people living in superdiverse
Leicester, a particularly instructful city -- the "Leicester Lab" -- for learning how diverse socio-cultural contexts
shape "environmental citizenship." Applying the communication ecology framework to a focus group design,
the project examines the communication spaces and resources -- interpersonal, cross-cultural, and
institutional, including professional media and government communications channels -- that shape how people
from different social and cultural groups engage with climate adaptation efforts. The project aims to enhance
Leicester's communication ecology and communicate a diversity of perspectives to policymakers.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: SCALE-ENDO: Study of Communication and Adaptive capacity using in-situ Learning Environments in ENDOscopy
Project Description: The SCALE-ENDO project is a two-phase research project aimed at enhancing safety in gastrointestinal endoscopy, through the development and evaluation of multi-professional in-situ team-based simulations. The simulations will be grounded in real-world risks in endoscopy settings as identified through a mixed-methods analysis of a national database of endoscopy incidents and near-misses from England and Wales. Using video-based methods within a multi-qualitative-method data analytical approach, the project will explore team interactions and adaptive capacity in multi-professional in-situ simulations involving real-world risks, and evaluate the pedagogical value of the simulations.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Partner(s): London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust,University Hospitals of Leicester

Project Title: Sign the Manifesto: Examining Public Relations in the Negotiation of an International Plastic Pollution Treaty
Project Description: This media and communication research project seeks to document the potential pathways of a legally binding instrument to eliminate plastic pollution currently under negotiation at the United Nations Environment Assembly, examine the coalitions that form during the policy process, and map how commercial interests appear within the policy-making process. To do so, it treats the network of commercial interests and their civil society partners represented by the Business Coalition for a Global Plastic Treaty as an example of an epistemic community, a professional network of actors whose knowledge and expertise has the potential to influence policy. This project contributes to understanding the role of commercial actors in international governance processes, building on existing research on greenwashing, regulatory capture, and democratic deliberation, and adds to scholarly efforts to appraise how decades of pressure on companies to demonstrate corporate social responsibility have changed how commercial interests publicly communicate and advocate.
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)
Name of Call: British Academy/Leverhulme Small Research Grant Scheme

Project Title: The Digital Footprint Data of CryptoFinance
Project Description:
1 page Outline 

This project will establish an interoperable data framework, capable of capturing, analysing and extrapolating social media, demographic, and digital asset finance data, on investor motivations in trading cryptocurrencies and other digital assets. It is imperative that we have clear foundations and knowledge on how social media, and other economic, financial, behavioural, and demographic factors affect financial decision making processes in relation to digital assets, in order to safeguard individuals, build a more resilient economic system, encourage innovation, and inform regulators. This project will thus answer the research question as to whether public and private datasets related to new forms of decentralised finance and evolving social media influences can be amalgamated in an open format database to foster rigorous and timely multidimensional and multi-focused understanding of these interactions. 

In the last few years, cryptocurrencies and other allied digital assets like NFTs, stablecoins, etc. have become mainstream; this is mainly due to the lowering of the technical barriers for creation of digital assets, proliferation of a myriad of cryptocurrencies, a social media fuelled echo-chamber, and the rise of several unregulated digital exchanges. As per the recent estimates by a digital exchange (Crypto.com) around 425 million people worldwide are investing in digital assets, mostly in a variety of cryptocurrencies and stablecoins, which the UK government estimates to be worth a combined value of USD 929.51 billion. Although there is a huge data ecosystem around digital assets comprising of blockchain data (aggregated by private companies, although most of it is technically publicly accessible), centralised exchanges data (fragmented proprietary data on investors and extrapolated market data), and social media data (what users post, comment and do on platforms as Twitter, YouTube, Reddit, Discord, Telegram etc. in relation to digital assets), there has never been any meaningful attempt to collate and study this valuable digital footprint data (DFD). 

Furthermore, given the recent scandals like the spectacular implosion of FTX resulting in estimated customer losses at more than USD 8 billion, increasing regulatory attention has attempted to capture the social dimensions and digital footprints of these phenomena. There have been some attempts in conducting surveys (FCA ran 2 surveys in 2020 and 2021) to collect demographic and financial data, as well as to evaluate the risks in the sector and the level of investor knowledge. However, to date no common database harmonising these disparate datasets produced by different regulators, mapping onto the digital footprint data of the users, has been created.
We are an experienced team of sociologists, data scientists, behavioural finance analysts and lawyers, who aim to create an accessible and interoperable data framework, in partnership with the main industry data keepers, social media platforms, and the regulators, to capture the social dimensions of decision making process in relation to digital assets, to understand the investor motivations, prevent fraud, and influence relevant regulators on their future digital asset policies and strategies.

We will first consult with digital exchanges, regulators, trade bodies, investor forums, and other stakeholders to create a DFD framework capable of capturing multidimensional data points on digital social interactions, demography, and multi-level financial data.  We will then liaise with digital exchanges and data aggregators (like CoinMarketCap,  who have already pledged to grant access to their API for free for research purposes), social media platforms (like Twitter and Facebook, to extract relevant data), and regulators (FCA, SEBI etc.) to access and create an anonymized, open source, findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable DFD as per our developed framework. The database created in this project will allow social science researchers to study how varied social, economic, financial, demographic and behavioural factors effects may have contributed to the explosive growth and continued mutual faith in digital assets. It will also provide digital exchanges, third-sector organisations, policy makers and regulators with actionable insights to create adequate mechanisms, policies and strategies to combat fraud, by providing an assessment of the transparency in the crypto sector, training dataset for autonomous decision models, and providing reliable and granular data about the social engagements in digital asset trade.

 
Summary: 
The advent of cryptocurrencies and digital assets has substantially altered the way that many think about money and investing. However, despite their growing popularity, there is still a significant knowledge gap in this area, especially around the investor motivation in converting ‘real’ money into ‘virtual’ asset. Enormous data is being generated in this digital first arena of cryptocurrency and decentralised finance, however, little is being done to systematically catalogue and study this digital footprint. This project will create a comprehensive database that captures, analyses, and extrapolates social media, demographic data on investor motivations along with the price movements and trading volumes in cryptocurrencies and other digital assets. This will develop the knowledge base and enable further research in this important area.

Cryptocurrencies and other digital assets have become mainstream in recent years, thanks in part to the lowering of technical barriers and the proliferation of a variety of cryptocurrencies. As per recent estimates by a digital exchange, Crypto.com, around 425 million people worldwide are investing in digital assets, which the UK government estimates to be worth a combined value of USD 929.51 billion. However, despite this growing interest, there has never been any meaningful attempt to collate and study this valuable digital footprint data.
Our aim is to create an accessible and interoperable data standard, in partnership with the main industry data keepers, social media platforms, and regulators, to capture the social dimensions of decision-making processes in relation to digital assets, to understand investor motivations, prevent fraud, and influence relevant regulators on their future digital asset policies and strategies.

To achieve our aim, we will first consult with digital exchanges, regulators, trade bodies, investor forums, and other stakeholders to create a digital footprint data framework capable of capturing multidimensional data points on digital social interactions, demography, and more. We will then liaise with digital exchanges, social media platforms, and regulators to access and create an anonymized, open-source, findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable digital footprint database as per our developed framework. We shall also create APIs to ensure that the database is continually updated with minimal intervention.

The database created in this project will allow social science researchers to study how varied social, economic, financial, demographic, and behavioural factors may have contributed to the explosive growth and continued mutual faith in digital assets. It will also help digital exchanges, consumer bodies, policy makers, regulators, and other stakeholder groups with actionable insights to create adequate mechanisms, policies, and strategies to combat fraud. By providing an assessment of the transparency in the crypto sector, a training dataset for autonomous decision models, and reliable and granular data about the social engagements in digital asset trade, our project will contribute to building a more resilient economic system and encourage innovation.

Our project is a vital step forward in understanding the complex landscape of digital assets and cryptocurrencies. By bringing together digital footprint data from various sources, we can gain a more comprehensive understanding of the motivations behind investment decisions, the risks posed by fraudulent actors, and the regulatory environment. With this knowledge, we can work towards building a more transparent, trustworthy, and resilient digital asset market that benefits all stakeholders.

Objectives
Objective 1 (Society): 
The primary objective of this project is to aggregate and organize the user generated digital footprint data produced by transactions of cryptocurrency and digital assets and by social media in order to provide a comprehensive picture of the industry's impact on society. This data includes user activity on various blockchain networks, social media interactions related to crypto, and transaction data from crypto exchanges. By collecting and analysing this data, we can gain insights into how the use of crypto is evolving and impacting society, including how it affects the value of the underlying asset and is changing the way we conduct financial transactions, store value, and interact with one another online. The ultimate goal of this framework and database is to create a better understanding of the potential benefits and risks associated with the use of crypto, and to inform public policy decisions that can help promote its safe and responsible use. 
Achieving this objective will also involve developing open standards that can handle the massive amounts of data generated by the crypto industry and social media. It will also require collaboration with key stakeholders in the industry, including blockchain developers, social media platforms, and crypto exchanges, to ensure that the data is collected and organized in a standardized and secure manner.

Objective 2 (Academic Research):
Our project will create for the first time a systematic, interoperable data framework and a scalable, open-access database on social media interactions, demography, and cryptocurrency/digital assets.  The database will be designed to facilitate easy data exploration, visualization, and analysis, and will provide researchers with the tools and resources they need to conduct sophisticated research on the crypto industry. This will enable future researchers to answer a variety of research questions related to the use and impact of social media on cryptocurrency transaction value and volume. The database can also be used in the future to investigate the impact of various regulatory approaches on the adoption and use of crypto, or explore the potential for crypto to promote financial inclusion and economic growth in developing countries. 

Objective 3 (Industry):
Finally, this project has important implications for the crypto industry itself. One of the biggest challenges facing the industry is a lack of transparency and trustworthiness, which has made it difficult for mainstream consumers and institutions to adopt crypto on a large scale. This framework and database will provide a comprehensive and transparent view of the industry's digital footprint data, map it onto social media data, this this project can help build trust and confidence in the industry, and ultimately promote its wider adoption.
To achieve this goal, we will work closely with industry partners to ensure that the data collected and analysed is accurate, reliable, and representative of the industry as a whole. We will also develop collaborative and robust APIs to ensure continuity of the project. By promoting transparency and trustworthiness in the industry, this project has the potential to drive growth and innovation in the crypto industry and to unlock its full potential for the benefit of society as a whole.
Name of Call: Deliver foundations for a transformation in digital footprint data

Project Title: The landscape of DiabEtes-reLated sTigma in eArly-onset type 2 diabetes in the UK (the DELTA study)
Project Description:
Background: Whilst the psychological impact of living with type 2 diabetes (T2D) has been well documented, little attention has been given to the role of diabetes-related stigma which involves judgement for developing diabetes, self-management, and diabetes-related complications. Experience of diabetes-related stigma takes a
physical, psychological and emotional toll on the health of adults living with T2D. Although evidence highlights the negative impact of stigma on people’s self-care and overall well-being, the profile of stigma in younger adults (18-40) with T2D remains understudied. We conducted a series of local Patient and Public involvement (PPI)
group meetings, consisting of young people with T2D (18-40), highlighting a significant need to further explore issues around stigma for adults under the age of 40 years.
Aim: To better understand the experience of stigma in young adults with T2D.
Methods: We propose three mixed-methods exploratory studies involving: 1) Systematic Review; 2) Qualitative
study (interviews with young people living with T2D and Healthcare Professionals); 3) Quantitative study
(Survey).
Dissemination: In peer reviewed medical journal and conference(s). Presentation of findings to local Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) and other appropriate stakeholders. Presentation (written and oral) of findings to study participants and PPI community groups.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: A Social Lab for Disclosing Vulnerable People’s ‘Digital Good’
Project Description: The proposed research proposes a pilot Social Lab for exploring vulnerable people’s ‘digital good’. It will do so by examining three broad categories of vulnerable people - older people, ethnic minorities and people with disabilities (PwDs) - via the theoretically informed and empirically innovative study of their digital inclusion. Theoretically, the research proposes a theoretical construct that combines two controversial and seemingly unrelated theoretical approaches: intersectionality theory and Foucault’s social theory. Empirically, this construct will be utilised in the space of a pilot Social Lab where stakeholders and vulnerable people from the three broad categories in focus will engage in 3-staged progress work that will generate an interdisciplinary account of the digital experiences of vulnerable people and the related barriers to, benefits of, as well as tensions and complex dynamics in their relationships with digital technologies. The study of the complex parameters of vulnerable people’s digital inclusion will directly disclose their own perceptions and experiences of digital good.

Project Title: Minority Blaming in the UK:  Post-COVID-19 Insights from COVID-19 Tweets
Project Description: The first (substantive) aim of this research is to reveal public discourse on Twitter regarding minorities in the UK during a major public crisis. Project Title: Ultra-layered perception with brain-inspired information processing for vehicle collision avoidance (ULTRACEPT)
Project Description:
This is the existing EU Horizon 2020 project ULTRACEPT transferred to Leicester from Lincoln. 
The project started 1 Dec 2018 is to end 30 Sept 2024. 
ULEIC has taken over as the coordinator as of 15 June 2023.
Lincoln remains on the project.

Subcontract to be issued for Lincoln's project manager Colleen Mitchell  to continue the project manager role.


The primary objective of this project is to develop a trustworthy vehicle collision detection system inspired by animals’ visual brain via trans-institutional collaboration.  Processing multiple modalities sensor data inputs, such as vision and thermal maps with innovative visual brain-inspired algorithms, the project will embrace multidisciplinary and cross-continental academia and industry cooperation in the field of bio-inspired visual neural systems via neural physiological experiments, software simulation, hardware realisation and system integration.  The innovative brain-inspired collision detection system has the advantages of low-cost spatial-temporal and parallel computing capacity of visual neural systems and can be realised in chips specifically for collision detection, both in normal and in complex and/or in extreme environments.

This project brings together 18 world-class research teams and European SMEs each with specialised expertise:

invertebrate visual neuroscientists (UNEW and UBA on the locust and crab),
invertebrate vision modellers (UoL),
cognitive neural system modellers (XJTU, GZHU and GZU),
mixed-signal VLSI chip designers (TU),
experts in hardware/software systems and robotics (UHAM, HUST, TUAT, LNU),
robotics platform provider and market explorer (VISO, DINO),
image signal processing (UPM, NWU), and
brain-inspired pattern recognition expert (CASIA, WWU).
The specifically designed research staff secondments, joint workshops and conferences, will facilitate knowledge transfer between partners and generate significant impact in vehicle collision avoidance research with applications to not only on road safety, but also to other applications such as mobile robots, health care and the video games industry.

The project will cultivate concrete research connections between institutions in Europe, the Far East and South America, and will significantly enhance the leadership of the European Institutions in this emerging research field.

The European SMEs will have opportunities to access world-leading expertise in research and development and position themselves well as a market leader in automatic collision detection sensor and systems, which in turn also help to expand its market share in intelligent sensor systems.
HESA Funder Category: EU Government Bodies (inc European Commission but not UK)

Project Title: Recycling of Ti Alloy Swarf for Coatings
Project Description:
Our concept is to utilise titanium (Ti) alloy swarf (vast amount generated during machining: ~80-90 % of the starting material) to produce the feedstock materials (powder and wires) for processes such as thermal spraying and additive manufacturing. The success of our concept will enable the usage of waste material for the mainstream production of feedstock material and will support the objectives of the current call: sustainability and circular economy. A successful demonstration of the concept will help in the commercialisation of new and efficient manufacturing processes for foundation industries that will, in turn, support the goal of waste recycling - some of the objectives of the current call. The Ti global market is forecasted to grow by a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.5 % from 2023-2030 reaching a market size of ~6.5 billion pounds (8.4 billion USD) in 2029. The major usage (~60%) of Ti alloys is in the aerospace sector and as the UK aerospace industry is the second largest in the world, the requirement of Ti alloys is going to increase in the UK. However, the production of the primary Ti alloy is a highly energy-intensive task that leads to higher costs and higher amounts of carbon footprints. The usage of Ti alloy swarf to generate feedstock material will not only support the production of low-cost Ti alloys for the UK industries but will also support the goal of achieving carbon neutrality (by 2050); by reducing wastage and reducing the usage of energy for material production; hence, supporting the UK economy.

In order to fulfill the goal of collaborative R&D, we have already figured out the industry and academic partners in the UK and India. The success of the project will lead to new and efficient manufacturing processes that will support the goal of sustainability, circular economy, and recyclability of Ti alloys for foundation industries. A successful value-added supply chain from the waste stream will be generated with the success of the current project. The project will generate knowhow and the work will be published in open-access journals.
Name of Call: India – UK Collaborative R&D for industrial sustainability
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Development of Coatings for Mitigation of Ice Accretion
Project Description:
Ice accretion on surfaces is a serious concern leading to severe environmental and economic losses. It affects myriad of industries, including aviation, telecommunication, naval transport, energy harvesting and distribution, cooling systems, automobiles, etc. [1]. In aircrafts, there is a decrease in drag and at times may lead to dangerous loss of lift force, which may cause tragic crash accidents. For instance, the flight (AF447) from Rio to Paris met with an accident in June 2009 over Atlantic Ocean (killed 228 people) raised a concern towards the safety of human race in air travel. The cause of the mishap was ruled out from any on-board system failures, exception being the sensors (or pitot probes). As per the reports, the pitot probes faced severe icing conditions owing to which the non-flying pilot had to activate the wing anti-icing system, thereby consuming more power for flying.

While most of the studies focus on the macro-scale icing (millimeter-size droplets and bulk ice) some authors have shown promising performance of superhydrophobic laser-textured surfaces against atmospheric icing. The tests have been carried out on wind tunnels and airplane components and it is evident that the ice adhesion is reduced with smaller micrometric droplets. With regard to the deposition methods, spin coating, dip coating, spray coating, Physical Vapour deposition (PVD), Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD), etc. have been developed by the research fraternity for inducing superhydrophobicity. Their advantages are that the deposition parameters can be controlled, and the resulting coating will meet the specifications or required properties when it comes to surface structure, thickness, etc. However, these techniques are not possible to use in the case of upscaling. For real applications, most of the coating systems will behave like paint, and spray coating or brushing are techniques that are mostly used. Smooth surfaces may be the preferred surface structure rather than rough or hierarchical surfaces as their simplicity make them industrially feasible. Thus, the present context of research is a merger of forming hierarchical structures satisfying Cassie Baxter’s equation and then coating the surfaces through spray/dip coating technology. The coatings will be subjected to different characterization techniques, such as wettability, microstructure, topography, composition, tribo-corrosion, and functional studies to assess the icephobic surfaces. The introduction of artificial intelligence aspect for predicting the icephobic coating parameters will be reported. The work will also broaden the scope of incorporating icephobic coatings in large-scale manufacturing industries.

Project Title: Tackling Awarding Gap in Third Year Engineering Individual Project for the Advancement of Ethnic Minority Students - Interventions inspired and informed by students
Project Description:
The Higher Education sector has been trying to address Awarding Gap by introducing reforms at university or programme level but so far, HESA figures show very little improvement in the gap.  This project is using a different approach.  We have decided to tackle the problem closer to the root.  We dissected our engineering programmes’ awarding gap down to module level and realised that the biggest contributor to that gap is the third-year individual project; a module that is part of most engineering programmes.
This project is about taking action.  We are implementing changes in the delivery of the third-year project module; changes that have been informed by our BME students’ experiences, by research on inclusive assessments and by best practices in programme directorship.  We will execute a series of tasks as listed in our detailed project plan over the span of 15 months and use the momentum to continue our efforts even after the project has ended.  
Our project outcomes are Enhanced BME Student Learning, Reduced Module Awarding Gap, Socially Responsible Supervisors and Students, Higher Sense of Belonging for BME Students and Improved Confidence to Stay and Progress in Engineering.  We will gather qualitative and quantitative data throughout the project, analyse historical data on progression breaking down BME into Black, Asian, Mixed and Other as well as conduct thorough evaluations for each outcome.
The revelations from this project will benefit all engineering programmes across the sector and adapted lessons would also be applicable to any programme that includes student projects. Notification of successfully making it through the first selection round has been confirmed. Notification of successfully making it through the second round will be confirmed end of October '23.
Funder: ROYAL ACAD ENGINRG ROYAL ACADEMY OF ENGINEERING
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)

Project Title: Project Name:	NPWS - Provision of Service Leaver Support Programme
Project Description:
University of Leicester have been appointed by Bloom Procurement Ltd on behalf of the College of Policing  to deliver a Police Leavers’ Transition Path. This consultancy will involve creating a range of material that will be uploaded onto the College of Policing's training platform for them to deploy with their retirees. Ceri will lead the project with support from two subcontractors.  
The content may include: 
•	A transition pathway or timeline to leaving the organisation, including a checklist of what to consider at key points prior to exit.
•	A toolkit capturing practical advice, guidance, and resources.
•	Short videos, ‘talking heads or case studies (ideally, the PSP will be able to produce.)
•	Webinars, seminars, or training inputs.
•	CV writing and application forms.
•	Approaching the jobs market, interview tools and techniques.
•	Resettlement guides on topics such as early financial planning, transferable skills, online networking, further education, and self-employment.
•	Signposting to reference documents, further reading, resources, and organisation.

Project Title: Translating Children’s Literature into Arabic: Textual and Paratextual Framing Strategies
Project Description: This book investigates the development of the translation of children’s literature into Arabic, providing unique insights into the prominent role of Kāmīl Kīlānī in shaping its history as well as for the translation of children’s literature more broadly. The book reflects on Kīlānī’s importance to the translation of Arabic children’s literature as one of the first writers to specialize in adapting works for Arab children, charting his influence through the use of narrative theory and framing strategies in adaptations. The volume encourages cross-cultural understanding and the promotion of reading in minority languages. In particular, it calls attention to translation by adaptation as the main approach in many translations of children’s literature into Arabic and other languages in which cultural differences between source and target languages can prove challenging.

Project Title: InvestigAtion into the relAtionship between AortiC aneurysmaL disease and air pOllUtion using Intraoperative samples from live donors and cadaveric organ Donors
Project Description: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a significant cause of mortality and morbidity, responsible for over 3000 deaths per year in the UK. AAAs are usually asymptomatic until they rupture, an event associated with a mortality of over 80%. Risk of AAA rupture is related to AAA size, with surgery being offered when a AAA reaches a critical threshold size. There are no known strategies to prevent the development or growth of an AAA. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that air pollution kills 7 million people per year worldwide and it is the fourth leading cause of premature death. The role of air pollution in the development of cardiovascular diseases such as AAA is unknown. There is strong evidence that the small particulate component of air pollution plays a key role in pathological processes causing ill health. It is unclear if any of initiation, growth or rupture of AAA may be affected by air pollution exposure. The aim of this project is to investigate the relationships between air pollution and AAA incidence, progression and rupture using toxicological and experimental approaches. The study will involve the collection and laboratory analysis of samples of the aortic wall taking during aneurysm surgery and samples of ‘healthy’ aorta sampled during kidney transplantation to look for evidence of air pollutants in either specimen.
Funder: VAN GEEST FOUND The John & Lucille Van Geest Foundation

Project Title: Reactive Sulfur Species (RSS) mediate hypoxic oxidative stress and inflammation
Project Description: Oxygen, a component of the air you breathe, is crucial for your cells to produce energy and carry out various functions. Therefore, the absence of oxygen, or hypoxia, results in many negative outcomes for cells, tissues, and organs. Surprisingly, how hypoxia causes cellular problems is largely unknown. It is especially important to understand how hypoxia affects cells, as hypoxia is linked to many human diseases, such as cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disease as well as the ageing process. In this proposal, we will investigate a novel class of molecules made by cells during episodes of hypoxia. These molecules, collectively called “reactive sulfur species” can have negative consequences to cells and we will determine if these molecules are the primary reason cells function improperly during low oxygen conditions. By understanding the molecular reasons low oxygen is bad for cells, we can then design drugs to limit the effects of hypoxia-related diseases. This would benefit society by preventing or limiting the effects of cancer, heart disease and ageing.

Project Title: Does sleep disruption affect epigenetic ageing in an insect model?
Project Description:
Ageing is the combination of DNA, cellular and organ damage leading to a decline in function and increased chance of dying. Aging is a complex process influenced by many environmental and genetic components. The effects of these components influence each other making them difficult to investigate, especially in complex mammalian models. Therefore, a large body of ageing research is based on simple model invertebrate organisms. Advantages include easy to keep in a laboratory, short life span, genetic and molecular tools available and a sequenced genome. However, the current models are of little use in the study of epigenetics in ageing.
An epigenetic clock is a better measure of true biological age than chronological age. They are used widely through-out biogerontology. These clocks are based on analyses of the chemical tags called methyl
groups that are found on DNA and help to control gene activity. Current invertebrate models of ageing (Drosophila and C. elegans) do not possess DNA methylation, reducing their generality to understanding human ageing.

Nasonia vitripennis, a tiny wasp and emerging model, has a functional methylation system making it an ideal system to investigate epigenetics of ageing. It possesses all the other advantages of an insect model (see above). The Mallon lab has found it possesses an epigenetic clock.

This project asks does sleep disruption affect epigenetic ageing in an insect model. In general, older people sleep less, wake up and go back to sleep more often, and spend less time in deep sleep or dreaming than younger people. Reciporcally, numerous studies have shown that sleeping too much or too little is associated with mortality among older adults.

Project Title: Fatherhood in Early Medieval England, AD 600 - 1050
Project Description: Fatherhood, broadly defined, was a ubiquitous phenomenon in the Early Middle Ages. Many men of all socio-economic statuses would at some point fall into this social category. Fatherhood appears frequently in scripture, and the language of fatherhood was used by secular and religious authorities, notably abbots and popes. Despite the centrality of fatherhood to early medieval life, however, it has received a remarkable lack of scholarly attention.  Increasingly scholars in other fields are recognising the usefulness of fatherhood as a category of analysis, and its potential to reveal new insights into masculinity, gender, socio-economic status, and the foundations of power, yet the early Middle Ages have so far been absent from these historiographical debates. The aim of this project is to address this problem, through an analysis of fatherhood in early medieval Britain and Ireland. The project will bring to bear qualitative and quantitative approaches to a broad range of sources including legal material, letters, genealogies, hagiography, biblical commentaries, and poetry.

Project Title: Understanding and solving mucus dysregulation in severe asthma for better clinical outcomes
Project Description:
There is an unmet clinical need in severe asthma patients, who remain uncontrolled and prone to exacerbation even when using maximal existing medication. This leads to adverse impacts in morbidity and mortality. This programme of work aims to provide a major advance in understanding how mucins contribute to severe asthma and will reveal new insight and identify novel therapeutic opportunities for this challenging patient population.

The hypotheses underlying this programme of work are i) mucins make a major contribution to the pathology of severe asthma and offer new therapeutic opportunities, ii) genetic variants in the MUC5AC locus are associated with increased risk of moderate-severe asthma and are functional and alter expression and activity of mucins in the airways, iii) alterations in the levels and biophysical properties of mucins drive structural changes in the airways and lead to severe, uncontrolled asthma and iv) greater mechanistic insight of the molecular and cellular mechanisms regulating mucins, will identify new targets for clinical intervention.

Project Title: Adult and Community-Based Learning in Rural Uganda: Introducing a Mother Tongue Language and Basic Entrepreneurship Programme
Project Description:
This project focuses on Adult Learning and Education (ALE) and community-based learning in Uganda, a country whose education system and regulatory policies favour formal education. ALE presents opportunities for lifelong learning, which equips adults with literacy and basic skills and to become active citizens through community education (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization/UNESCO, 2006, 2015). 
We hypothesise that MT languages are effective mediums of instruction in the delivery of ALE and community-based learning in rural SSA. Accordingly, we propose to develop and implement a Mother Tongue Language and Basic Entrepreneurship (MTL/BE) programme to tackle the learning challenges. 
Focusing on two languages (Ateso and Lusoga) that are among the nine approved MTs used as mediums of instruction in Uganda, the project will involve interlinked Learning and Action Research components. The communities of interest are: Kumi (Ateso-speaking) and Busesa (Lusoga-speaking). 
We theorise that a hybridity of learning approaches is paramount in enhancing learning in rural communities. Through our partnership with LABE (Literacy and Adult Basic Education), the leading provider of MT-ALE in Uganda, we will introduce Home Learning Centres (HLCs) to concurrently deliver intergenerational learning programs.
Name of Call: ESRC responsive mode research grant round one

Project Title: UK Health Policy Outcomes Dashboard (POD)
Project Description:
The UK Health Policy Outcomes Dashboard (UK Health POD) will be a platform which enables academics, policy makers and NHS managers to visualise the impact of healthcare policies on diverse communities across different postcode areas, generating managerial options to facilitate decision making.

This project will focus on the visualisation data from policies implemented between 2013 and 2023 which aim to address health afflictions aligning with data collected from the Extended Cohort for E-Health, Environment and DNA (EXCEED) project, and research specialities at the University of Leicester: diabetes (type 2), cardiovascular disease, and respiratory disease. The aim is to use the developed platform to evaluate the impact of healthcare policies on a wider range of health problems beyond the lifespan of the project.

Three objectives were constructed to meet these requirements:

Objective 1: Descriptive (historical) health data map: Create a map showing historical health outcomes with options to view by demographics (age, gender, ethnicity, social deprivation), and time (specific year, before and after policy intervention).

Objective 2: Predictive health data map: Utilise machine learning to rank determinants of health problems before and after policy intervention to map how these vary across different demographic and geographic populations.

Objective 3: Augmented intelligence (managerial options based on projected outcomes): Generate managerial options for decision-makers to target specific demographic or geographic populations.
Name of Call: ESRC responsive mode: secondary data analysis round one

Project Title: Innovative packaging solutions for AI-driven clinical decision support tools
Project Description:
Better use of information and data in the NHS is critical for realizing significant improvements in clinical care and delivery. One area where this is important is using data to build computer-based clinical decision support tools to help healthcare workers make smarter decisions about patients. There is a growing interest in building such tools around Artificial Intelligence (AI) models. These AI models are trained to recognise patterns in data which allow them to make specific predictions when presented with new data about a patient. However, to be of practical use AI models need to be embedded into a clinical decision support tool - this provides the features required for the AI model to be used in practice. While the number of AI models and tools being developed is increasing rapidly, the number being used in practice remains modest.

A major reason for the lack of uptake is the cost and complexity of developing, evaluating and setting up such tools. This includes initially creating and testing an AI model and the clinical decision support tool in the first place. Then undertaking clinical trials - highly-structured, onerous and time consuming regulatory assessments which are required to determine how effective the tool is. The final stage is linking the tool together with real-life computer systems which provide the health data required for them to be used in the clinic.
 
In this project I aim to produce a modular technology for creating clinical decision support tools as customisable, re-usable and adaptable “packages” which can integrate AI models. This will simplify the development and implementation of these AI-based tools and expedite their use in clinical practice. To achieve this I will:

1)	Develop a secure CDS packaging framework which allows packages to be defined from a set of re-usable modules supporting predictive algorithms and AI models. A key strength will be the ability to switch the input and output modules to support data sources and features required for different development stages (research, testing, validation, clinical trials and implementation).
2)	Enhance the packaging technology with safe and responsible approaches for handling integrated AI models, to ensure packages are working correctly and include support for displaying appropriate information to healthcare workers to allow them to understand why and how the predictions are being made.
3)	Evaluate the technology by demonstrating its effectiveness for the entire process of clinical model development from initial evaluation, through a mock clinical trial and test implementation with existing information systems.

To achieve these objectives, my team and I will build on my own and others’ research and tools and collaborate with clinical and technical experts using both simulated and real-world data and computer systems to achieve our aims. Through a co-design approach we will develop and evaluate the exemplar project to test the effectiveness of the approach. We will also strengthen and develop new collaborations with appropriate regional and national academic and commercial partners over the course of the project.

This is an important and timely project which will produce key underpinning technologies to reduce barriers to the creation and uptake of AI-driven clinical decision support tools in healthcare environments and help facilitate the ‘digital transformation’ of the NHS.

Project Title: Laser-based measurement for multi-physical parameter distribution in combustion field
Project Description: A clear, reliable, and efficient aviation jet engine is desirable for safety, environmental protection, and accomplishing the UK’s long-term carbon reduction target. Key to achieving such an engine is developing a technique that could enable engineers to monitor everything going on in the engine’s combustion chamber. This sounds straightforward: the chemical reaction between the fuel and oxygen in the combustion chamber provides the driving power for the engine and constantly converts the chemical energy of the fuel into the heat/internal energy of the gas mixture which propels the engine. However, in practice, the process is extremely complex and difficult to monitor. In the combustion chamber, the liquid fuel undergoes a complicated process including spraying, evaporation, and combustion in a high-pressure, turbulent environment. Multiple quantities such as temperature, flow velocity, and chemical species concentration need to be measured to construct a full picture of the complex combustion process. Moreover, the delicate process is extremely fast with each step taking place within milliseconds and is very easily disturbed, so a quick response, real-time, and non-intrusive laser-based optical measurement method is the most promising candidate for realising the simultaneous measurement of the physical quantities mentioned above. This study aims to explore the possibility and advantages of combining three novel laser diagnostics techniques as a method to measure multiple physical quantities at the same time without disturbing the combustion process. Therefore, this project stands to benefit both research into in-chamber combustion and the UK’s efforts to develop more environmentally friendly aviation.

Project Title: Genetic basis of the evolution of insect hearing
Project Description: Insects have evolved auditory organs (ears) at least 19 separate times. All insect ears evolved from stretch-sensitive proprioceptors (joint-angle sensitive receptors) as the cell types are very similar. My research ambition is to understand how unique ear evolution is across insect orders and to establish the genetic scaffold on which ear specialisations evolved. This international exchange will allow me to interact with an emerging expert in cicada biology, Prof. Eberl (University of Iowa) and, with him, collect auditory organs and proprioceptive organs from cicadas during a dual emergence in the spring of 2024 in the field. Cicadas represent a unique order (Hemiptera), that I do not have access to in the UK, and will complement my RNA sequencing data from my two lab-based orders (Orthoptera and Diptera). I will travel to the cicada sites of emergence (Eastern Iowa) and collect cicadas and extract cicada auditory organs and cicada femoral chordotonal (proprioceptive) organ on liquid nitrogen. At least 100 individuals are required to extract enough biological material for RNA extraction and the emergence of millions of cicadas in spring 2024 is a unique opportunity to acquire this unique biological dataset. Biological material will then be transported by to the University of Iowa on dry ice for RNA extraction, before shipping the extracted RNA for sequencing.

Project Title: Large Language Models as Creativity Evaluation Judges for Inclusive Design in Cultural Spaces
Project Description:
Large Language Models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT have been recently in the news surprising people with its ability to mimic human conversations. More than that, they can explain programming code and do creative tasks such as writing song lyrics and poetry. In the field of Computational Creativity (CC), creative artefacts generated solely by machine or co-created with humans, such as stories and artworks, are considered creative if they present novelty (e.g., new compared to the existing ones) and value (e.g., aesthetic pleasing for artworks). There are two main strategies to evaluate creative artefacts: evaluation metrics and human judges. Evaluation metrics are commonly used to automatically guide creative systems towards creative candidate artefacts with high value and novelty. Then, the most creative ones are evaluated by humans, since they are the only reliable judges on creativity. This current approach poses some limitations in the research field and also in its applications: creative artefacts produced by CC-systems are rarely compared under the same criteria, human judges and benchmarks; creative professionals from cultural spaces cannot rely on traditional evaluation metrics to get feedback on their co-created artefacts during the design phase of museum exhibitions; most automatic CC-systems rely on creativity evaluation from a single perspective dictated by traditional evaluation metrics which might produce biased, non-inclusive and even non-creative artefacts.

I have been doing research in creativity evaluation since 2016, by proposing new metrics to guide generation and evaluation of value and novelty of creative artefacts, such as culinary recipes and digital games cards. My current pioneering research achieved promising results showing that GPT-4, the most advanced LLM to date, is able to evaluate creativity in two common creativity tests, the Alternative Uses Test and an adaptation of the Torrance Test of Creative Thinking (TTCT) for textual descriptions of images. In another study, I have showed that GPT-4 evaluation of jokes funniness has a positive correlation with non-expert human judges using a novel many-shot prompting to generate representative personality descriptions which in turn are used to configure the model to mimic the score rating by human judges. In another study with collaborators, we showed that GPT-4 is able to distinguish different poetry author styles by fine-tuning the GPT-3 model. 

My research hypothesis is that LLMs can act as an audience of human judges with multiple perspective views for the evaluation of creativity, for which creativity could otherwise only be reliably evaluated by a real audience of human judges. The main objectives of this project are: O1) To investigate and understand the reliability and limitations of LLMs in the creativity evaluation of artefacts; O2) To determine methods to create an audience of human judges with LLMs; and O3) To develop and test a framework to provide means to explore the collaboration between creative professionals from cultural spaces and LLM audiences to improve the evaluation of creative artefacts.

This project can significantly benefit the CC research community and creative professionals, in particular multi-modal cultural space ones such as museums designers and curators, by enabling real-time feedback, increasing productivity, faster design of creative artefacts and reducing biases in the co-created artefacts. Also, the novel proposed framework will predict creative artefact success to customized audiences, support inclusive design and provide a standard reference benchmark for CC researchers, accelerating progress in this research field.

Project Title: Bridging Cultures: People, Places, Peace and Prosperity
Project Description:
Buoyed by commitment and enthusiasm from the then world leaders, the United Nations (UN) was established to ‘reaffirm faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person, in the equal rights of men and women and of nations large and small’, ‘to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom’, ‘to establish conditions under which justice and respect for the obligations arising from treaties and other sources of international law can be maintained’ and ‘to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war’ (UN Charter, Preamble). People, places, peace and prosperity were central to the new UN in 1945, and reconfirmed repeatedly thereafter, not least in the 2015 roadmap for the organisation moving forward, Agenda 2030 and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Yet, the world is increasingly fragmenting, with conflicts, a rising number of authoritarian and autocratic governments, and global challenges including pandemics, food and energy supplies, global supply chain shifts and the climate emergency heightening insecurity.

Whilst most of these issues are, to some extent, considered in academic literature and in reports of international organisation and civil society organisations, this network plus aims to evaluate the current understanding then advance knowledge through crossing disciplinary boundaries and using a wide range of research methods and collaboration. The aim is to determine how the rising influence and power of China and Russia can be harnessed to promote stronger international cooperation, within the current multilateral architecture, focussed on addressing the growing number of international challenges impacting on people, places, peace and prosperity.

Engaging with researchers and practitioners from key states as well as those with indepth country knowledge then fostering new links with researchers with thematic expertise will expand and deepen understanding of theoretical models and the practical application of law and policy in different legal, political, economic, social and cultural environments. Drawing on national and international researchers also contributes towards the agility of the projects building inherent flexibility in the approach.

To understand the context, impact and opportunities, the objectives are

1. Developing understanding of the cultural, economic, political and social determinants shaping and influencing approaches of China and Russia to international law and policy;

2. Mapping their transnational influence on aspects of the international rule of law, governance and cooperation, the form it takes and how governments in East and Pacific Asia, Eastern Europe and Eurasia respond;

3. Analysing the disconnection and tension between these new approaches and the traditional structures and modalities of international governance epitomised by the UN;

4. Identifying practical pathways to strengthen positively the responsibility that comes with emergent global power; and

5. Drawing together findings to articulate a framework for productive international cooperation strengthening international human rights and development.

These objectives are ambitious, yet realistic given the wide range of networks and contacts of the core team and partners. Key is drawing on national perspectives and insights from those familiar with the local (national or UN) approaches, national insights are often missing from English language literature, fortifying claims that the UN or western/developed states do not understand the national situation, the national characteristics of law or are not familiar with local conditions impacting on the realisation of human rights.
Delivering on these objectives will offer empirically based, culturally sensitive and realistic insights into aspects of the global power shifts which impact on people and their rights, peace and security of place and prosperity of all. The findings can be used by policy makers shaping interventions on the international stage, researchers across disciplines and civil society.

Project Title: Synthesis of Mercury's crustal compositions for evaluation of BepiColombo exploration
Project Description:
Data for the surface of Mercury indicates a rocky surface with compositions unlike any on Earth. The planet appears to be a highly reduced (without oxygen) environment, with incredibly low FeO content (<~2 vs <14 wt % on Earth), despite an iron core that makes up ~85% of the planet. Enigmatic areas of high C are thought to have potentially formed during an early magma ocean stage, producing a graphite flotation crust. All in all, of only 4 terrestrial planets in the Solar System to understand, Mercury doesn’t fit the model set by the other three. 

No samples of Mercury have come to Earth as a meteorite, due to the proximity of Mercury to the Sun. And without the means to access materials here on Earth, quite like those on Mercury, simple observations such as mineralogy, grain size, scale of heterogeneity, or abundance of volatile elements, are hard to constrain. Lab testing and processing capability of instruments onboard the ESA-JAXA BepiColombo mission are currently being ground-tested in lab-based facilities, in preparation for the arrival in orbit around Mercury in late 2025. Without materials analogous to those likely to be encountered on the surface of the planet, measurements and spectra could be processed wrongly, leading to erroneous interpretations.

In a novel approach to examine the mineralogy and physical properties of the surface of Mercury, we propose to synthesize samples that match the major element chemistry extrapolated from the previous mission to Mercury (2011-2015 MESSENGER data). Five dominant compositions have been mapped to the northern hemisphere of Mercury. These compositions will be synthesized to form the first, fully crystalline samples of compositions analogous to the surface of Mercury.

Project Title: EASYSENS: Imprinted Polymers as a Sensing Platform for Clinical and Forensic Analysis
Project Description:
The availability of the effective analytical tools is an important prerequisite for a successful delivery of the healthcare, environment, security and a food safety missions.
Currently, biosensors play a key role in addressing the analytical challenges, however, despite considerable efforts, biosensors remain unavailable for many important applications due to the high price and poor stability of the biological components used in such devices. In an ideal world, recognition components used in biosensors would be robust, inexpensive, sensitive to relevant targets, capable of generating a sensor response, and suitable for integration with inexpensive and robust transducers. Since, neither enzymes nor antibodies are fully capable of meeting these expectations, the search began decades ago for synthetic alternatives to biological molecules, such as molecularly imprinted polymers (MIPs). 
The major breakthrough made by my team in the last five years in relation to the design and production of “monoclonal” robust MIPs as an alternative to enzymes and antibodies for sensor applications, has made it possible to consider the practical application of such devices. 
The aim of the proposed research is to revolutionise diagnostics by developing a new generation of completely abiotic, robust, easy to use and inexpensive sensors that explore the full potential of nanoMIPs as high-performance supramolecular receptors with integrated binding and signal generation.
By bringing together the modelling, nanotechnology and engineering expertise of my team, this vision could be delivered by addressing three high-impact scientific objectives. Objective one will include a development of the generic platform technology for creating MIP nanoparticles (nanoMIPs) specific for the important clinical and forensic target analytes and capable of recognising them in complex environments. Second objective will focus on a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms by which MIPs generate signals during interaction with analytes and use this understanding to create polymers with integrated binding, electron transduction and signalling functionalities. Objective three will include a development of printing technology for integrating nanoMIPs with electrochemical sensors.
The knowledge and protocols developed during the project will advance scientific methods, theory and applications across many disciplines beyond molecular imprinting. A key impact will be to make the use of animals for the production of antibodies obsolete. New effective and affordable sensors will improve the quality of life, health and safety of our citizens and change the way we conduct clinical testing, administer and monitor drugs, police our streets and protect our society.

Project Title: Right place, right practitioner, right time: development of emergency department triage to support the identification and management of drug related problems
Project Description:
About one third of people who visit A&E have a problem with their medicines. These medicines have been
prescribed by their GP or bought from a pharmacy/shop. For example, patients may have side effects that make
them feel unwell, like stomach upset, while other people feel their medicine may not be working and want to
try something else. In these examples, the people may be aware that they have a problem with their medicine,
but sometimes people may not even know their medicines are the cause of the problem. For example,
someone could visit A&E with bad stomach ache and not realise the ibuprofen tablets they have been taking
regularly could be the cause of a stomach ulcer. Sometimes, the healthcare professionals working in A&E might
not even realise that medicine might be the cause the problem! Asking questions about the medicines people
are taking is often missed when patients speak to a nurse or doctor because they are more concerned with the
problem at hand. This means that problems with patient’s medicines may not be resolved during their visit to
A&E and patients may have to put up with the problem and suffer longer. The first part of this project will help
A&E staff find any problems that patients might have with their medicines.
If a problem with a patient’s medicine is found then the problem should be fixed by a healthcare professional
who is an expert in medicine. This could be a doctor or nurse, but a pharmacist who works in A&E might be the
best person to help. Pharmacists do not usually work in A&E, but there are at least 20 hospitals across the UK
that do have one. They help with all things that involve medicines, for example, looking over doctor’s
prescriptions to check they are safe, or helping nurses understand how to give medicines to a person with
swallowing problems. While we know that pharmacists are experts in medicines, we do not yet know which
patients could benefit most from a pharmacist helping to care for them. The second and final part of this
project will help to make sure that patients who have a problem with their medicines are helped by
pharmacists.
For the project, we will talk to doctors, nurses and pharmacists in A&E to get their views on what would be a
good way to find patients who have problems with medicines, and how to ensure these patients get the best
care available in A&E.

Project Title: Resolving the Paradox of Stable and Accurate AI
Project Description:
According to National AI Strategy, AI is expected to transform the UK's economic landscape, improve people's lives and public services, and radically change industries. Modern AI technologies, paired with today's unprecedented availability of data and computational resources demonstrate exceptional capabilities across sectors. Most of this progress, however, has been made within a subclass of weak AI, including state-of-the-art deep learning models. Despite these technologies demonstrate great success in applications, they remain far from general AI. A general AI should be able to reliably learn any task that a human can.

An important barrier on the road to general AI, however, is the inability of the current deep learning methodology to guarantee that the neural networks it produces are both accurate and stable. Instability here means that small changes in the training data may result in unexpected and potentially undesired outcomes. 

In September 2021 Bastounis et al. proved that for any AI implemented by a neural network with fixed architecture, there are infinitely many tasks on which that network fails in the presence of arbitrarily small data perturbations. This phenomenon was shown to be fundamentally unavoidable, and cannot be overcome by better data or training. This barrier is extremely novel and it is not yet known if it can be overcome.

In this project, we will approach this key challenge by establishing a new theory underpinning the development a new class of AI models that can continuously adapt their architecture and keep learning with provable performance gains, completely avoiding the curse of AI instability. Our recent work reveals an unexpected approach capitalising on high dimensionality of modern AI systems. We will explore these new findings in their highest generality, with dependencies and guarantees of continuous learning, resolving the stability-accuracy paradox and paving the way for the general AI. As a part of the project's delivery, we will explore the application of the new theory in strategic UK sectors such as healthcare (with Trauma Audit Research Network \& NIHR Biomedical Research Centre Leicester), smart materials (Tangi 0), and security (Synoptix).

The theory and technology developed in our project will transform AI technologies by resolving the recently discovered stability-accuracy paradox imposing an imminent foundational barrier which limits the application of existing AI. Successful resolution of the paradox will enable creation of new AI systems which can reliably learn from vast amounts of knowledge that has already been accumulated in texts and documents produced by humanity.

Project Title: Host-centric metaviromics. Utilising minicells to answer: who infects who?
Project Description: In this work, we will assess if minicells of bacteria could be used to selectively separate host-specific phages from complex natural bacteriophage communities. Minicells are "mini" bacterial cells that are produced as a result of the asymmetric division of min mutant strains. They contain no chromosomal DNA but crucially contain membrane receptors for bacteriophage attachment. We hypothesise that it is possible to infect minicells with only host-specific bacteriophages from an environment and utilising metagenomics to sequence only the viral DNA contained within minicells. Thus, enabling direct linking of bacteriophages to their hosts. The approach would revolutionise our understanding of bacteriophage-host interactions, by allowing high-throughput identification of which bacteriophages can infect a particular host for the first time.

Project Title: Investigation of uranium occurrence in sedimentary phosphorite using synchrotron-X-rays
Project Description:
Royal society  Cost share programme aimed to support two researchers in collaborative research between UK and China. 
Abstract
Phosphate fertilisers used to enhance agricultural crop productively are commonly derived from phosphorite ore. China is one of the largest producers of phosphorite. Problematically, some global ores contain uranium (U), thereby rendering the extracted fertiliser undesirable. Where applied to crops or grass, U might accumulate in the soil, be consumed by grazing animals or leach into rivers that supply drinking water [1], thereby posing a threat to human health. Whilst natural U, as U-238, is mildly radioactivity, its radioactive decay products such as radon are more active. Uranium is toxic and affects the kidneys [2]. Such health threats have been identified as significant in the US [3]. Solving this problem requires the separation of U from phosphorite, yet little is known about phosphorite geochemistry. Uranium may reside within the ore, either bonded to phosphate or adsorbed to iron-rich minerals. Solving this quandary will help determine the most effective separation approach. Standard laboratory equipment can reveal a lot about an ore’s geochemistry, but using powerful synchrotron X-rays can reveal much more detail about how U is atomically bonded and spatially distributed. Collaboratively, though this proposal, and a parallel application for beamtime at the Diamond light source (DLS), the UK’s synchrotron facility, Cumberland and Zhang, aim to synergise their expertise in uranium geochemistry, ore geology and analytical techniques, and to analysis phosphorite samples from China. The potential benefits are enormous as this research can lead to safer fertiliser, uranium for low-carbon nuclear energy and valuable insights into environmental cleanup.

Project Title: Public opinion and the ‘Apostasy’ in Greece: The Centre Union party and the resignation of Georgios Papandreou in the July 1965 constitutional crisis
Project Description: The legislative elections of November 1963 and February 1964 were important for Greece, bringing to power the Centre Union party under the leadership of Georgios Papandreou after sustained centre-right government. But Papandreou left office in July 1965 amid political and constitutional acrimony, with continuing instability leading to authoritarian rule by a military junta between 1967-74. There has been no scholarly research into the responses of the public at this time of meaningful change in the Greek political system. This project will analyse an untapped collection of survey datasets from 1964-66 to analyse public opinion in Athens. The project will shed new light on evaluations of Papandreou’s leadership and the Centre Union government, a party with a strong appeal to the urban electorate. The project would make a major contribution to the study of the pre-junta period and to the wider literatures on party politics and voting behaviour in Greece.

Project Title: Exploring Marketplace Discrimination and Racism towards Roma in Romania: Understanding the Experiences of a Hyper-Marginalized Consumers
Project Description:
The Roma are the largest and more severely racially discriminated minority group in Eastern Europe, with the largest population of Roma living in Romania. Building on literature in areas such as marketplace discrimination and racism and Gypsylorism, this project aims to: (1) understand the socio-historical context and the structural relations that uphold anti-Roma racism in Romania; (2) understand the experience of Roma consumers as a hypermarginalised group in Romania and how they cope with the marketplace racism and discrimination that they are subjected to; (3) explore the perspectives of pro-Roma activists, NGOs members and marketing and communication practitioners on how markets and marketing activities should be administered in order to contribute to reducing the discrimination and racism against Roma individuals in Romania; (4) create evidence-based guidelines for marketing professionals on how to address and represent Roma consumers via their marketing actions and for policymakers on how to regulate marketing actions to ensure that they are inclusive and non-discriminatory towards the Roma population in Romania. To achieve these objectives, a qualitative study constituting of in-depth interviews with  Roma
consumers, pro-Roma activists and NGOs members, and  marketing and communication practitioners will be conducted. The project will promote societal inclusion of hyper-marginalized consumers.

Project Title: Towards a new power infrastructure development path for rural Africa
Project Description:
To tackle climate change and meet the increasing power needs efficiently by 2030, clean power is the most affordable and reliable option for all countries and especially the developing. The Breakthrough Agenda (Gov.uk, January 2022) however, declares the ambition of the COP26 world leaders to go beyond tackling climate change alone. The goal is to catalyse the growth of markets, jobs and economic development globally for clean technologies and sustainable solutions, support the achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, strengthen the climate resilience of societies and realise multiple co-benefits such as cleaner air, water and better health.

One of the key metrics in the realisation of this agenda is providing evidence that power systems can integrate very high levels of variable renewable energy (including up to 100%) in different geographies and climates whilst maintaining a cost-efficient, secure and resilient system. This challenge also includes addressing development challenges in low-carbon energy (supply), low-carbon societies (demand), and smart and flexible energy delivery and storage (Ayrton Fund, 2020).This is exactly the challenge that the PowerPath project aims to address in the context of sub-Saharan Africa. Through this work we aim to support both Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 7 (Affordable and Clean Energy) and SDG13 (Climate Action).

Lateral Electrification is an innovative electrification model for rural Africa. It is based on the collaborative building of smart power grids from the bottom up by diffusing and progressively clustering basic smart units of power production, storage and distribution called “nanogrids”. These are installed and operated by local entrepreneurs to answer off-grid households’ basic energy needs more rapidly, flexibly and affordably than individual Solar Home Systems (SHS) while participating in the progressive building of decentralized, decarbonized and smart power infrastructures able to support growing energy needs. This is a model that aims to build a horizontal industry organisation powered by local entrepreneurship. 

Since the objective of the progressive technological concept is to cluster smaller power infrastructures to be able to deliver more intense energy services, new appliances (comply with power output) have to be sourced and new services have to be defined at every step of the process.
