Project Title: Inequality and the Role of Work Hours: Understanding the Determinants of Work Hours Choices
Project Description: Income inequality and be viewed as the result of differences in both wages and work hours. Working part-time has important implications both for current and future earnings, as part-time work has been shown to limit career progression. As a result, it is important to better understand who works how much and why. In this project, we aim to contribute to this issue by studying two particular aspects relating to the work hours choice. The first is adjustment frictions in work hours; that is, to what extent individuals are able to quickly adjust their work hours when their circumstances change. Such frictions have important implications for the design of labour market policies, such as job search assistance. Second, we want to study the impact of early-career health shocks, which limit individuals' ability to continue in full-time work and thereby have implications for their future career. To study these topics, we want to draw on unique administrative data from the Netherlands which can be linked with survey evidence from the LISS panel, creating a rich dataset with both high-quality data on labour market histories and an extensive set of background variables for each individual.

Project Title: The Only Good Antibodies Project: BETTER ANTIBODY CHARACTERISATION, BETTER SCIENCE, BETTER TREATMENTS
Project Description:
Antibodies are one of the most important tools used in medical research. They are Y-shaped molecules that scientists use for their ability to recognise, and stick to, specific targets. They are used to identify which proteins and how much of these proteins are present in a biological sample, and whether there is more or less of a given protein  . This can help scientists to work out which proteins might be important in disease. Data from antibody experiments informs drug design, and sometimes antibodies themselves are used as drugs.
Unfortunately, a large proportion of antibodies used for research purposes are unreliable, meaning they either do not recognise the target they are meant to, or they also recognise lots of other proteins. Two large studies  suggest that this is a problem for more than half of available antibodies. Unreliable antibodies lead to expensive waste of resources, including human tissue, and failures of expensive research projects and drug development .
The reasons for the use of unreliable antibodies are complex. Contributing factors include a lack of awareness amongst researchers and the high costs (money, time and effort) of running experiments to test the quality of available antibodies. Our proposal aims to lay the foundation for eliminating the problem of inappropriate antibody use and improve the quality and reliability of biomedical research as a result.
The main things we will do are:  
•	Explore  ways to come to an agreement with all the main parties about how to fund the necessary quality control work, and how to make sure best practises are quickly adopted by the international science community.
•	Form an international community of data curators to rapidly share high quality data, using existing tools that can automatically inform research funders and publishers.
•	Produce new frameworks that researchers must adhere to if they want their research projects funded/approved or published.
•	Develop the necessary skills in the UK to take up some of the best practise internationally on this issue.
•	Produce tools to support researchers in best practises, considering their experiences and concerns.

Project Title: Evaluating balanced pathways to Net Zero
Project Description:
The project will develop and metrics for environmental condition, performance and suitability for agriculture and wider land use, e.g. a range of crops, biodiversity, carbon sequestration, soil health, ecosystem regeneration, and their statistical distributions for pilot regions, including the East Anglian Fens, and provide projections of their dynamic change in space and time over the next 30 years as they respond to policy, land use change and climate. 
The distributions will be derived from a digital twin of the land system (combining JULES, ECOSSE and DSSAT and an ecosystem services model) driven by climate ensembles for climate change pathways. These ensemble projections provide the transient carbon emissions over the next decades and their likelihoods and can be linked with socio-economic and other data. They provide information on the likelihood of achieving targets. The spatio-temporal projections provide for the evaluation of connectivity in the landscape e.g. for biodiversity. 
Pathways to net zero, will be co-produced with stakeholders to consider the economic, social and emotional impacts, include local knowledge and identities and explore potential conflict between local priorities and national policies.
Where there are no suitable metrics, artificial intelligence approaches may be used to determine useful metrics – potentially on-demand in a user driven system. 
The project will be able to respond to new policy priorities as the digital twin can incorporate new policies. Emphasis in digital twin development will be on co-design with policy makers and other stakeholders, usability by government and relevance for and complimentary with government modelling.

Project Title: CMHorizonte-DES applications in gold mining
Project Description: The processing of gold rich ores has traditionally been dominated  by potentially environmentally damaging processes such as smelting, cyanidation and mercury amalgamation. It is acknowledged that there is a great need for new processing technologies that achieve similar extraction rates but without the environmentally damaging waste products. Deep eutectic solvents (DES) are an innovative green technology with applications across primary and secondary materials processing. These solvents are composed of common, low cost,  low toxicity and environmentally well understood components and are able to achieve high metal solubilities and low temperatures and at ambient pressures. These characteristics make DES an ideal, potentially disruptive, technology for addressing the challenges associated with the extraction of gold from ores. This study, in conjunction with Consorcio Minero Horizonte (CMH), will investigate the application of DES to metal extraction from Peruvian orogenic gold ores, demonstrating the efficacy of DES in this context and to determine potential experimental factors that impact extraction efficiency.

Project Title: How do the Arabidopsis synaptonemal complex central element proteins ZYP2 and ZYP3 promote synapsis during meiosis?
Project Description: The aim of this proposal is to investigate how two novel α-helical proteins (ZYP2 and ZYP3) promote function and maturation of the synaptonemal complex in plants. We will test whether ZYP2 and ZYP3 are required to implement crossover (CO) interference and CO assurance and how they form filamentous structures along the central element of the synaptonemal complex in conjunction with ZYP1 and the recently identified SC protein ASY5. ZYP2 and ZYP3 possess similar properties to mammalian SC proteins Tex12 and SYCE3, so our experiments will determine if they are orthologous and gain further insight into the organisation and function of the synaptonemal complex across animal and plant kingdoms.

Project Title: Socio-Environmental Context for Older Adults' Well-Being:  A Multi-Country and Multi-Timescale Approach
Project Description: This 3-phase project aims to answer: which features of the life-environment are most impactful to the short and long-term maintenance of well-being across the days and years of old age? Project Title: K-AHEAD: Knowledge-Aware High-fidelity and comprEhensive Advanced air mobility Development
Project Description:
This initiative aims to develop unprecedented analysis and design methods and tools enabling the development of Advanced Air Mobility(AAM) vehicles.
AAM development brings transformative air ambulance and personal aerial vehicles into reality and into our daily lives. This transforms the current ground-infrastructure-based 2D transport to seamless 3D aerial connectivity. Such connectivity represents a critical and necessary technological advantage to improve emergency responses, address uprising global challenges, drive economic growth, and forever change our travel and lifestyles. With electrical propulsion, it substantially decarbonises while decongesting urban spaces, promising a seamlessly connected and sustainable future. As enabling technologies e.g. electrification and manufacturing steadily mature, AAM development has gained compelling global momentum[12,27] recently. 
However, AAM vehicle design, e.g. aerodynamic shapes and configurations, remains a major barrier. Current AAM prototypes often adopt radically unconventional designs, due to extraordinary scopes e.g. electrical propulsion and stringent safety/emission constraints. With existing design/analysis approaches developed for conventional aircraft, these prototype designs rarely succeed. This exposes 3 major challenges(Fig1.): 1.the lack of accurate multi-physics analysis ability, 2.the excessive problem dimensionality coupling multi-physics, design, and operation, and 3.the scarcity of reliable data and new knowledge.
This initiative delivers transformative design and analysis solutions to tackle these challenges. Instead of current sequential and simplified multi-physics analyses, this work formulates multiple physics as one comprehensive problem and solves it with first-principle-based modelling(Fig2), enabling more accurate and comprehensive analysis. 
Further, instead of relying on engineering experience/intuition, we will construct intelligent agents to manage the problem dimensionality(Fig3). These agents will establish quantitative knowledge correlations, and drive knowledge-aware adaptive analysis, delivering accurate results at reduced costs and providing intelligent models for digital twinning. 
Finally, with these pioneering methods/tools, this initiative will develop the world’s first benchmark AAM design cases for common R&D. All results will be publicly disseminated for widespread impact and excellence.

Project Title: ExCALIBUR HES - ARM Forge Software licence
Project Description:
The Objectives of this funding are:

1) ARM Parallel Debugging and Profiling Application: Resource Request £60K

This is an application that supports the debugging, profiling and optimisation of codes that use distributed resources, such as a cluster.   It is both CPU and GPU enabled.   This package will enable jobs that use up to 2048 cores to be analysed in terms of code efficiency.  Reports generated using ARM Forge are being used to improve system design, architecture performance and application performance.

The licence will be purchased on behalf of the ExCALIBUR H&ES programme for use at all ExCALIBUR sites. The cost is for one year (April 2023 to March 2024). This request was approved by the ExCALIBUR H&ES programme, to be funded at 100%. 

The funding for a 4-year licence was approved by ExCALIBUR H&ES in 2019 and a contract with ArmForge was signed at that point. This JeS form is a request to release the final year of the approved funding.

2) Over the next 12 months (the final year of the current ExCALIBUR licence) we will prepare a report on usage across the ExCALIBUR community which can be used to assess whether the licence should be renewed once the current contract expires in March 2024. This work will be carried out by the DiRAC HPC facility as an in-kind contribution to the ExCALIBUR programme.

Project Title: Talent for Hybrid Energy Storage systems
Project Description:
T4HESS programme will offer positions for doctoral researchers of any nationality in 8 international calls in order to develop individual and freely selected research projects at the recruiting organizations during a 36-48 months period. The programme will recruit the researchers through an open, informed, efficient and transparent, supportive, and internationally comparable selection process that will follow the administrative requirements of each country public administration and will be based on the principles established in the European Charter for Researchers and the European Code of Conduct for the Recruitment of Researchers. The researchers’ selection will ensure equal treatment for all candidates, facilitating in particular access of disadvantaged fellows, as researchers at risk or with disabilities.

T4HESS will be focused on generating in-depth knowledge and promoting excellent talent within a number of specific scientific and technological specialization areas in the field of Energy, in line with expertise and longterm priorities of the Implementing Partners that will recruit and host the researchers. The programme will involve
both academic and industrial participating organizations with strong expertise on energy technologies, guaranteeing this way an attractive, cross-sectoral and international ecosystem with a focus on energy storage, namely, on Hybrid Energy Storage Systems. This is a recent branch of energy storage that replies to current limitations of single energy storage system (ESS). A single ESS does not fulfil all the requirements for certain operations and has different trade-offs for overall system performance. This is mainly due to the limited capability of a single ESS and the potency concerning cost, lifespan, power and energy density, and dynamic response. To overcome the trade-off issue resulting from using a single ESS system, a hybrid energy storage system (HESS) consisting of two or more ESS appears as an effective solution.

The programme design relies on the objectives posed by the EC to demonstrate different battery technologies, including next-generation storage technologies. Furthermore, T4HESS is a demand-driven research programme addressing the significant challenges Europe faces in the fields of Renewable Energy.
HESA Funder Category: EU Government Bodies (inc European Commission but not UK)
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: APP7947: Adaptive laser-aided cold spray procedures for contoured multi-nozzle heads to achieve load-bearing additive manufactured freeform structures
Project Description: Conventional cold spraying generates metal coats with comparatively modest structural performance compared to high enthalpy manufacturing methods. This project aims to narrow the performance gap and enable additive layer manufacturing alternatives to superplastically formed titanium components, such as fan blades, and to welding of fatigue crack affected aluminium components, such as wing spars. This project brings together complementary expertise in contoured nozzle design from the University of Leicester,  additive manufacture layer design and deposition path design from Loughborough University, laser enhanced cold spray deposition and cold spray verification, validation, and testing from The Welding Institute, to deliver complementary tools that enable this transformative progress in design and manufacturing of metal alloys.

Project Title: Developing an SDE for projects of the future
Project Description:
The EM SDE needs to demonstrate how it can support meaningful high impact projects. There are several projects which are being led by Leicester which would enable this type of approach to be used and can enable regional collaboration. Through this they will help develop an SDE which is fit-for-purpose for several different research-scenarios, at a local and a national level.

Proposal:
Financial and operational support for two high impact projects is proposed:

Project 1
Leicester lead the NIHR Diabetes Health Informatics Collaborative - a repository of diabetes data from across the UK managed, collected and standardised both locally and centrally. This project requires an NHS-based SDE which is currently unavailable in Leicester. The resources to support this type of infrastructure are currently limited.

Project 2
Differential experience and outcomes for patients from more deprived communities and ethnic minorities has been a problem for many years, but came to the fore during the COVID pandemic. We propose to build a minimal data set (based on work at Leicester) from across the region that includes data by ethnicity and deprivation to allow in depth service evaluation and research to understand and address health inequalities. Through disaggregation of the data by ethnicity and deprivation and through better understanding of the situation we will be able to take proactive approaches to redressing health inequalities.

Project Title: Insects Inspired Small Targets Motion Detection (inSTMD)
Project Description: Ability to perceive small moving objects in distance is critical for autonomous robots and vehicles to spot hazards. On the other aspect, small moving objects, or targets like drones, which pose potential threat to public safety, should be detected automatically for further inspection. Detecting moving objects in distance with limited resources on board a robot or a vehicle is challenging, however it is significant to safety. In this project, we propose to take inspiration from insects’ small target motion detection (STMD) neural circuits for small moving targets detection and to build compact sensor systems for robots or vehicles to detect small moving objects automatically. We will build new STMD models inspired by insects’ visual pathway, to explore methods to hardware realization of the model with the most advanced visual sensors such as event camera and high-performance chips for modulization and miniaturization. We will build demonstrator systems to test, verify and demonstrate the performance of the insects’ inspired STMD system.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C

Project Title: NbS for Improved Climate Resilience (NICE): Water storage for equitable drought and flood resilience in Nigeria and Malawi
Project Description: Nature-based solutions (NbS) that provide distributed water storage have the potential to (i) decrease and attenuate local and downstream flood waves during intense rainfall, (ii) provide additional water storage for local household use and livelihoods, (iii) provide mechanisms for groundwater recharge potentially increasing catchment-scale drought resilience and (iv) provide additional ecosystem and cultural benefits. However, the success and value of these NbS depend on skilful placement of these features to optimise benefit for all users and effective management of potential risks and trade-offs associated with the NbS (e.g. disease, drowning, displacement). Therefore, a transdisciplinary approach is required to first understand the value of multiple NbS benefits to all users across appropriate spatial scales, to then inform implementation of water storage NbS that are equitable, provide net-benefit, and are sustainable in the long-term. Two case study locations, one in Nigeria and one in Malawi will be used to examine NbS for safe water storage across rural and urban locations and to investigate the contextualisation of feasibility, benefits and value of similar NbS.
Funder: UKRI UK Research and Innovation UKRI

Project Title: Epidemiology and costs of childhood developmental delays and poor educational performance in the context of pre-pregnancy multimorbidity
Project Description:
The overall aim of this project is to establish the associations between maternal pre-pregnancy
multimorbidity and the risks of childhood developmental delays and poor educational performance
and determine the related economic costs. The specific objectives are as follows:
1. Assess the prevalence and the risks of childhood developmental delay and poor
educational performance among the children of multimorbid pregnant women compared to
their counterparts i) with no morbidity, and ii.) with a single chronic condition.
2. Determine changes in the magnitude of risks and excess risks of childhood developmental
delay and poor educational performance due to the number and clustering of chronic health
conditions referent to a single chronic condition.
3. Determine global and domain-specific developmental delay trajectories (i.e., evolving,
resolving, constant or fleeting) among the children of multimorbid pregnant women and
associated determinants of group membership.
4. Estimate the health and social costs associated with childhood developmental delay and
poor educational performance due to maternal pre-pregnancy multimorbidity.

Project Title: Are early life environments effects on ageing mediated by the epigenetic clock?
Project Description:
This project will help understand the proximate causes of life history evolution by establishing the effect of larval diapause on insect epigenetic ageing. This extends our discovery of epigenetics’s role in several insect life history traits (1). Why individuals and species age so differently is one of the biggest unanswered questions in evolutionary biology (2).
Environments can be variable and organisms can be selected to sense the state of their environ- ment early in life and to adaptively adjust their life history in response to these changes (3). The ability of one genotype to produce different life-histories depending on the environment is known as a life-history polyphenism (3). We ask could epigenetics and specifially the epigenetic clock be a proximate mechanism of these life-history polyphenisms.
An epigenetic clock is a biochemical test based on measuring the accumulation of chemical marks (DNA methylation) to DNA molecules (4). There is evidence epigenetic age mirrors true biological age and its associated morbidity and mortality better than chronological age (5). The rate at which an epigenetic clock ticks is strongly affected by the environment. This seems especially true in the early stages of life (6). This gives rise to the idea that an epigenetic clock can be developmentally tuned as part of an adaptive response to environmental variables experienced during development (6).
Aging is a complex process influenced by many environmental and genetic components. The effects of these components influence each other making them difficult to investigate, especially in complex mammalian models. Therefore, a large body of ageing research is based on simple model invertebrate organisms (7, 8). Advantages include easy and cheap to keep in a laboratory, short lifespan, genetic and molecular tools available, and a sequenced genome. However, the current invertebrate models of ageing (Drosophila (9) and C. elegans (10)) do not possess detectable DNA methylation, reducing their generality.
The jewel wasp, Nasonia vitripennis, an emerging model system (11) has a functional methylation system (12) making it an ideal system to investigate the epigenetics of ageing. We therefore mea- sured chronological ageing and changes in the epigenome using whole genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) in order to discover if Nasonia vitripennis possessed an epigenetic clock. The epigenetic age of each replicate is the weighted average of each genes’ methylation state. This epigenetic age does indeed correlate with chronological age (13). This is similar to results found in many vertebrates (6). However, this is the first time an epigenetic clock has been discovered in a tractable insect model.
An example of a life-history polyphenism in Nasonia is larval diapause, an overwintering stage where development is arrested and adult lifespan is increased (14). DNA methylation is involved in Nasonia diapause (15). Using published RNA-seq datasets (16), we have found an increase in the expression of DMNT1a (the enzyme responsible for DNA methylation maintenance) and a decrease in TET (the enzyme that removes methylation) in diapaused versus non-diapaused larvae. This suggests a maintenance of DNA methylation during diapause.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Towards Co-produced Resilient Futures: Equitable Nature-Based Solutions in Forest and Pastoral Systems
Project Description:
Our research focuses on (linked) pastoral and forest landscapes and livelihoods in Kenya and Senegal. Through in-depth transdisciplinary research with local community actors, academics, NGOs and policymakers in these important socio-ecological systems we address all key themes of the call: contexualisation and scalability of NbS and the role of community governance and knowledges therein. We do so through i) comparative analysis of current & future climate impacts on ecosystems, livelihoods and communities in our study areas and as part of a suite of wider global challenges, ii) evaluation of the role of specific NbS therein, under current and future climate scenarios; iii) examination of the scalability and place-specificity of these solutions; iv) our focus throughout on diverse, indigenous, local and gendered, knowledges, knowledge recognition & mobilisation.
We identify pastoral and forested landscapes as critical to rural livelihoods and ecologies, and as exemplifying some of the challenges and potentials of NbS in SSA, particularly for climate resilience and adaptation. In Kenya, unprecedented recent drought events have highlighted both the importance and limitations of diverse pastoralist NbS, often linked to community-based rangeland governance and recognition of knowledges and rights. Similarly in forested ecosystems, remote sensing (RS)-based technologies are enabling key actors such as Kenya Forest Service (KFS) to forge new partnerships with Community Forestry Associations (CFAs) to develop and recognise NbS for deforestation-free livelihoods, with downstream impacts on critical ecosystem services (ES) and pastoral systems.  In Senegal these key ecosystems and communities are facing comparable challenges, with the recent emergence of a range of adaptive, NbS.
These innovations merit, urgent critical attention – a challenge to which our project responds. For example, for both countries, diverse future climate scenarios, in conjunction with land surface and ES models, can be used to project the potential evolutions of particular NbS and facilitate enhanced community adaptive capacity and risk management.
Specifically we ask:
1.	What NbS solutions exist in our case study sites and what is their efficacy and limitations in relation to livelihoods, ecologies and climate adaptation?
2.	How are these NbS evolving and with what implications under diverse future climate scenarios?
3.	What elements of these NbS and local knowledges are scalable to other contexts and geographies?
4.	How can climate forecasts be fused with local knowledge to increase the efficacy of NbS for climate adaptation?
5.	How can local knowledges and values be mainstreamed in development and support of NbS in policymaking, for just, equitable practices and outcomes?
We thus address both the scientific and non-scientific objectives of this call through providing new analyses of the nature, efficacy and scalability of NbS in two critical, linked socio-ecological systems in SSA.

Project Title: Artificial intelligence in predicting Diabetes reMission following barIatric surgeRy in patients with type 2 diabetEs using multi-ethnic population databases in the United Kingdom (ADMIRE)
Project Description:
Background:
Bariatric surgery, a very clinically and cost-effective treatment for obesity, has shown promising outcomes in inducing diabetes remission or significant improvement in glycaemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes. However, factors influencing diabetes remission after bariatric surgery are multiple and interconnected, presenting a challenge for healthcare professionals to accurately use them to predict individual-patient outcomes. Albeit several predictive scoring systems – such as DiaRem, Ad-DiaRem, DiaBetter, individualized metabolic surgery (IMS) score, and the ABCD score – have been proposed, notable heterogeneity still exists in outcomes after the surgery. Additionally, they have either been developed using small sample size, or have been shown to have limited predictability for long term remission. Successfully identifying factors that contribute to both short- and long-term diabetes remission would optimize the patient selection process and improve the likelihood of successful outcomes after bariatric surgery.
 
Objective:
This study will explore the use of machine learning methods in predicting diabetes remission using large-scale electronic health records in the United Kingdom (UK).

Study Location:
The project will be based on the Real World Evidence Unit (LRWEU), Leicester Diabetes Centre (LDC) at the University of Leicester. The LDC is a renowned institution dedicated to diabetes research, education, and patient care. The LRWEU is recognized for its expertise in analysing real-world data from clinical settings and patient records. This data-driven approach will provide valuable insights into diabetes management, treatment outcomes, and patient experiences in real-life scenarios.

Data Source:
We will analyse routinely collected and de-identified electronic healthcare records from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD), for which we have an active user licence. This is a large UK-based database that contains patient information such as demographics, lifestyle factors, clinical diagnoses, medication history, and laboratory test results. CPRD will be linked to Hospital Episode Statistics admitted patient care, Office for National Statistics death registry and Index of Multiple Deprivation.
 
Study population and methods:
The study cohort will include adults (age ≥18 years) with type 2 diabetes who underwent bariatric surgery. Bariatric surgery will be identified from both primary care and hospitalisations records and will be categorised into four types:  Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, gastric band, sleeve gastrectomy, and other. Diabetes remission will be defined as the HbA1c level consistently remaining below 6.5% for at least three months within the follow-up period after the surgery, without being prescribed any glucose-lowering medication or insulin (reference: https://www.diabetes.org.uk/about_us/news/remission-new-definition).
The next step in the study will be selecting relevant predictors that may influence diabetes remission, such as age, gender, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, BMI, HbA1c, diabetes duration, medication usage (including oral glucose-lowering drugs, insulin, GLP1-RA, antidepressants, antihypertensives), comorbidities, blood pressure, lipids, and lifestyle factors (e.g., alcohol intake, smoking status). Data pre-processing techniques will be applied to handle missing values, normalise numerical features, and encode categorical variables.
Three supervised machine learning (ML) algorithms, such as logistic regression, random forests, and gradient boosting will be employed to build predictive models for diabetes remission after bariatric surgery. These algorithms are chosen due to their ability to handle both linear and non-linear relationships within the data, and their potential to reveal complex patterns that might influence diabetes remission. The dataset will be split by time period at the patient level into training and testing sets, and the ML models will be trained on the training data. Hyperparameter tuning and cross-validation techniques, such as k-fold cross-validation, will be employed to optimise the model's performance and ensure the robustness of the models and to minimise overfitting. Model performance on the test set will be evaluated using various metrics, such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC). Additionally, feature importance analysis will be conducted to identify the most influential factors contributing to diabetes remission. We will also evaluate the predictive capability of these new models with existing scores listed above.

Practical Implications:
The predictive models that will be developed in this study will have practical implications in clinical settings. They can aid healthcare professionals in identifying patients with type 2 diabetes who have a higher likelihood of achieving remission, enabling targeted interventions and personalised treatment plans. Our findings will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, presentations at both national and international conferences, and reports directed towards healthcare professionals and patients.

Project Title: Novel Mathematical Methods for Modelling in Ecology and Evolution
Project Description:
We propose a conference at UoL  on mathematical modelling in environmental sciences with the title 'Mathematical Models in Population Dynamics, Ecology and Evolution'.

The conference dates: April 15-18, 2024


The main aim of the conference is to bring together leading researchers in mathematical biology who explore processes and mechanisms in various biological systems ranging from a cell to the human society. A special focus will be on incorporating the complexity of biological systems in mathematical and computational models by linking processes on micro- and macroscales (in space and time). The meeting is also expected to explore similarities between modelling techniques traditionally applied in ecology and evolution and those used in other research areas (applied mathematics, physics, engineering) with the purpose to enhance interdisciplinary approaches and to stimulate further advances. The meeting will be an open forum for interaction between theoreticians, data scientists and empirical biologists with the main goal of enhancing communication between them.

The expected number of participants is 60-70 including  about 20 PhD students. The conference will consist of plenary talks, contributed talks, and a poster session. We expect that the large number of participants will be postgraduate research students.

The invited plenary (keynote) speakers  and their main research areas:

Maira Aguiar (Bilbao, Basque Center for Applied Mathematics (BCAM), Spain) 
Modelling infectious disease dynamics, non-linear dynamics stochastic processes, chaos and predictability

Elaine Crooks (University of Swansea, UK)
Differential equations (PDEs and ODEs), mathematical biology

Vasilis Dakos (University of Montpellier, France) 
Modelling regime shifts, statistics, mathematical biology, predictability and early warning signals

Ivana Gudelj (University of Exeter, UK) 
Evolutionary game theory, nonlinear dynamics, biomathematics

Valerie Livina (National Physical Laboratory, London, UK)
Stochastic processes, data science, time series analysis

Jean-Christophe Poggiale ( Aix-Marseille University, France) 
Model reduction, dynamical systems, fast-slow systems

Valerio Lucarini (Leicester, UK) 
Climate Dynamics, Statistical Mechanics,  Dynamical Systems, Extreme Value Theory

Davide Valenti (University of Palermo, Italy) 
Stochastic modelling, statistical mechanics across time and space scales.

Sebastian Wieczorek (University of Cork, Ireland)
Dynamical systems, non-autonomous differential equations, bifurcation theory.

Alan Hastings (University of California at Davis, USA)
Applied mathematics, complex systems, mathematical ecology

Rachel Norman (University of Stirling, UK)
Mathematical ecology, mathematical epidemiology.

Project Title: Repurposing the past: community heritage and archaeology in Jaffna, Sri Lanka
Project Description:
Exploring the archaeology of the last 500 years, and focusing on material remains from ordinary people and everyday activities is a powerful means of directing the concepts of archaeology and heritage away from the elite and monumental remains and sites that dominate Sri Lanka’s cultural heritage narratives, and allowing new, community-driven ways of thinking about archaeology and heritage that resonate with the Tamil minority in the Jaffna Peninsula.  Emerging from five years of discussions, workshops, field visits between the Jaffna, Colombo and UK team members, the project has been co-designed in order to use archaeologies of the everyday and of the recent past to investigate identity, belonging and place, and to find ways to re-evaluate how archaeological and cultural heritages are understood.  
The current archaeological and cultural heritage of Sri Lanka was developed during British rule and privileged elite, monumental sites that showcased Sinhalese and Buddhist histories.  These systems have persisted since Independence and as a result, members of minority communities in Sri Lanka feel alienated from a version of heritage which does not represent them.  This is the case in Jaffna, where the Tamil community feels at best indifference towards archaeology and state-supported heritage, and at worst active distrust of the people and systems who work within these areas.  The ways in which the archaeological heritage of Sri Lanka were used to support claims of ethnic primacy and rights to land were a contributing factor in the long-running civil war (1983-2009).
This project will use historical archaeology of the recent and contemporary past (c.1500 CE to present) to explore the everyday and ordinary material remains of life in coastal Jaffna, and then find ways to translate this material record into relevant heritage that not only engages local communities, but is driven by them and has value for them.  An explicit project aim is to work with communities to find innovative ways of producing heritage (e.g. pop-up museums, festivals, exhibitions) alongside more conventional academic outputs.  
This project will be of benefit to communities in Jaffna (and potentially other parts of Sri Lanka) who do not recognise themselves in the state-approved archaeological and heritage narratives.  This is particularly challenging for the communities that were displaced during and after the civil war; recognition of the rich everyday practices and heritages which are so evident in the north will help people to re-think what their heritages may be in this region, and how to present them in ways they find meaningful.  This close interaction between the project team and communities will result in a transfer of curatorial, community and archaeological skills so that communities can continue to create their own narratives. This in turn will give communities the agency to create their own counter-narratives that might resist and challenge the current dominant hegemonic views of archaeology and cultural heritage identities in Sri Lanka.  By using archaeology and heritage to address issues of identity, belonging and place, this project has the potential to contribute to dialogue within and between communities in Jaffna.

Project Title: Developing a neurological qualitative toolkit
Project Description:
Neurological qualitative toolkit
The use of qualitative methods within neurological health research has increased the quality and scope of the published literature, leading to greater understanding of diagnoses, explored life with an incurable condition, informed the creation of complex health interventions and provided the context for (un)successful delivery of such interventions. MRC guidelines recommend interviews and focus groups be used throughout the development of complex interventions.
However, the use of qualitative methods for people with neurological conditions (pwNC) can be challenging. Common neurological symptoms include behavioural changes, speech difficulties, loss of mobility and fatigue, which hinder the time intensive nature of qualitative data collection and require adaptations, which are not always adequately planned for. It can be confusing for researchers to choose between data collection methods, such as interviews, focus groups, ethnography, and qualitative surveys. There is also no guidance on the support researchers require when conducting qualitative research, which often involves practical as well as emotional challenges. 
This project aims to create a research toolkit for researchers who are conducting qualitative research with pwNC. The toolkit will contain a range of resources for researchers, providing guidance for how to conduct high quality, inclusive, qualitative research, taking into account the aspects outlined above. Three interconnected workstreams will complement one another to collect information and develop the guidance. 
First, a scoping review will explore what qualitative methods have been used previously with pwNC, highlight any positives and negatives to these approaches reported by researchers, and identify any adaptations that were made to data collection procedures. 
Second, semi-structured interviews involving pwNC, their families, and both novice and expert qualitative researchers will collect in-depth information on the experiences of engaging in qualitative research. Early findings from the scoping review will also be integrated into interviews. 
Third, pwNC, their families, and qualitative researchers will be invited to three co-production workshops to co-develop and refine the final guidance. This will adopt an iterative process, considering the data gathered during the other two workstreams. 
The toolkit will  be widely disseminated, to ensure that the recommendations are accessible to researchers, pwNC and other groups who would find them useful. This methodological toolkit could be beneficial in multiple areas. For example, due to the intensive data collection process, pwNC may not feel able to participate in qualitative research. By providing guidance on how to adapt common data collection processes, the recommendations we produce will increase the equality, diversity, and inclusivity of future research. Overall, the toolkit can increase the quality of neurological qualitative research, which will produce more impactful publications resulting in a higher profile for qualitative research and the increased use of this important methodology.

Project Title: Understanding how to rationalise ambulance use at the very end of life
Project Description:
This project seeks to understand how end of life care can be manages to make the most appropriate use of the emergency ambulance service at the very end of life (defined within this project as the final 30 days)

In order to do this, this project seeks to understand:
- the scale and patterns of conveyance of patients at the very end of life )
- how decisions are made which lead to conveyance
- the context in which decisions are made
- the role of specialist palliative care units in ambulance settings in caring for people at the very end of life

The project will be comprised of a number of work-packages, including:
WP1: Examining linked data with regards to patient outcomes following conveyance to hospital
WP2: Analysis case notes from instances where a patient has been conveyed to hospital within the final 30 days of their life
WP3: Qualitative interviews with a range of stakeholders, including family carers, healthcare professionals, care home staff, ambulance staff and emergency department staff 
WP4: Mapping / scoping existing models of ambulance service provision for people at the very end of life

Project Title: The contribution of proteomics to multi-morbidity
Project Description:
The overarching research question of this project is to evaluate the extent to which circulating proteins contribute to an individual's risk of developing multiple diseases - with a current focus on Type 2 Diabetes and Osteoarthritis, a common co-morbidity. To answer this question a variety of aims must be met, including (but not limited to):
1.	Identify circulating proteins that correlate genetically with type 2 diabetes and osteoarthritis.
2.	Using local genetic correlation techniques to tease out both 'cis' and 'trans' correlations.
3.	Perform causality analysis using Mendelian Randomisation. 
4.	Test the extent to which circulating proteins account for genetic correlations between diseases.
5.	Assessing the 'druggability' of proteins identified evaluate potential further development and public health impacts.

Project Title: Perceived Causal Relations of Determinants of Health: Adapting Network Analytic Approaches
Project Description: Determining views of causality is important because causal intuitions inform views about appropriate interventions. Studying causal intuitions can help understand why structural or social determinants of complex constructs such as health, are often overlooked in favour of biological or lifestyle causes. Whilst qualitative approaches to lay intuitions are rarely scalable or generalisable, existing quantitative methods drastically over-simplify people’s representations of causality. An alternative solution is offered by network analysis, a set of statistical techniques that enable analysis and visualisation of relational data, and which accords better with the notion that lay representations are viewed as networks of events. This programme will apply recent advances in network analysis to develop a new method for assessing perceived causal relations, focusing on the social determinants of health. It will develop UK academic expertise in this burgeoning area and enable a much richer understanding of perceived causal relations of health than heretofore.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Guidance for primary teachers on teaching mathematics to children in care
Project Description:
Governments in the UK and elsewhere have raised concern about the low average levels of educational attainment reached by children in public care, with subsequent limiting effects on each child’s life chances. Care-experienced children’s prospects in school and beyond are particularly harmed if they have difficulties in reading and mathematics, but mathematics has received relatively little attention, compared to reading or classroom behaviour.

The number of children coming into care is increasing, but they still comprise a small percentage of all children. Many primary school teachers with a child in care placed in their class may not realise the damage that the child’s previous experience is likely to have done to their capacity to learn, making the task of assessing and teaching them much more complex than for a child with a more settled start.

This project will develop guidance for primary teachers on how to support children in care to make progress in mathematics, particularly in number and arithmetic. We will design a professional development package with three aims: 
•	to improve teachers’ understanding of barriers to learning faced by a child in care;
•	to advise on ways of assessing key aspects of number, in a manner that may help the teacher build a stronger positive relationship with the child; 
•	to develop the teacher’s repertoire of effective and engaging activities for children, which can be used for individual support, small group work, and at home. 

The materials will also be useful with a wider range of vulnerable children, providing much-needed research-based advice in an accessible way.

Project Title: Our Memory in Your Language: Translating Taiwan’s Museums in Transition
Project Description: This project explores the dynamic role of translation in communicating the memory and heritage of Taiwan to international audiences through its museums. Building upon my experience in translating and studying personal memory narratives, the fellowship will enable a “discipline-hopping excursion” into the mediation of memory in and through translation in the public sphere. Taiwan’s museums, particularly the NMTH and the NMTL, are undertaking significant steps in re-narrating national memory and heritage to suit the projection of its identity in a critical historical moment. Therefore, this project will develop pertinent case studies for mapping and theorising translation in the museum as a site of memory, particularly in the context of contested identity and nationhood.

Project Title: AI-Assisted Community-Driven Nature-Based Solutions for Climate-Resilient Coffee System in Sub-Saharan Africa
Project Description: The research centres on establishing a sustainable and climate-resilient coffee system in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), with a focus on southwest Ethiopia and Uganda. This research addresses the challenges confronting coffee farmers in the context of climate change. Coffee arabica is exceptionally vulnerable to climate variations, including shifts in temperature, precipitation, humidity, and light. The prevailing global warming trend intensifies concerns that suitable coffee cultivation land will significantly diminish. Additionally, the social and economic landscapes are expected to become increasingly unpredictable, potentially leading to instability in local markets and supply chains. This poses considerable risks and pressures for coffee farmers, particularly those at lower altitudes, to seek adaptive and sustainable solutions. To respond these challenges, our project adopts community-driven solutions informed by data and AI technologies.

Project Title: Schizophrenia and Type 2 diabetes: incidence, life expectancy, safety/efficacy of antipsychotic therapies and the role of ethnicity
Project Description:
Background

People with schizophrenia have an increased risk of developing Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) due to a combination of genetic, medication and lifestyle factors. People from ethnic minority communities are particularly disadvantaged: Both Black and South Asian communities are individually more likely to have schizophrenia or T2DM, but we do not know if there are further risks of developing T2DM if schizophrenia is present. There are no recommended first-line antipsychotic treatments for people with schizophrenia who are at risk of developing T2DM. We need more information on this to inform prescribing, monitoring and targeted prevention strategies.

Aims and objectives

Among adults with and without schizophrenia, to investigate:

1) Incidence of developing T2DM in our cohort of people with and without schizophrenia by ethnicity. 
2) Life expectancy in people with schizophrenia and T2DM, compared to people with schizophrenia alone, T2DM alone, and neither condition, also stratified by ethnicity.

Among adults with schizophrenia only, to investigate:

3) Describe first-line prescribing of antipsychotic agents by ethnicity, BMI, gender, age and socioeconomic status.
4) Model the risk of T2DM, psychotic events, suicide/self-harm, cardiovascular events and all-cause mortality by the antipsychotic agents prescribed, also stratified by ethnicity.

Methods

This electronic health record observational study will use data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD), linked with hospital episodes, mortality and deprivation data. All adults with schizophrenia and a 1:1 propensity-score matched (gender, age, ethnicity, body mass index, socioeconomic status) sample without schizophrenia in England will be included from January 2010 to the latest date available. Descriptive and time-to-event approaches will be used to calculate incidence of T2DM, life expectancy, and first-line antipsychotic therapies prescribed for schizophrenia, also investigating the effects of ethnicity (Aims 1–3). Flexible parametric approaches will be used to follow up people with schizophrenia by antipsychotic therapies prescribed to explore their effect on outcomes related to T2DM (cardiovascular disease, T2DM, deaths) and those related to schizophrenia (self-harm/suicidality, psychotic episodes, deaths) (Aim 4).

Timelines for delivery 

Months 0–3: Scientific approval submission
Months 3–10: Incidence and risk factors for T2DM (Aim 1)
Months 7–15: Life expectancy and life years lost due to T2DM (Aim 2)
Months 12–18: First-line antipsychotic agents (Aim 3)
Months 16–24: Analysis of antipsychotic agents and outcomes (Aim 4)
Months 10–28: Dissemination of findings

Anticipated impact and dissemination

The findings will be presented to clinicians, researchers and policy makers via academic publications, conferences and existing national networks at the Royal College of Psychiatrists, NIHR Global Health research centre and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence. We will work with the PPI group to produce accessible communication about the study to members of the public and people with lived experience, including a video of involvement and an infographic to publicise the findings on social media.

Project Title: Curating Antiquities: National Trust collections and constructions of the ancient past in Britain, 1700-1939
Project Description:
This is a 5-year project to identify, catalogue and celebrate the antiquities collection of the National Trust, and shed light on the people behind their arrival in Britain.

Our aim is to reconnect the public with a key feature of British heritage: the influence of imported Greek, Roman, and Egyptian antiquities in the National Trust’s collections on British domestic and social culture. We are a team of researchers from different UK universities and the National Trust with particular interests and specialisms related to the ancient objects in the National Trust collections.

Project Title: Innovative Hybrid Energy Storage Systems
Project Description:
To advance the European scientific basis, technological leadership, and global role in novel storage technologies, the project has 8 specific objectives (SOs) that will be achieved through interlinked tasks defined in the project work packages. HibEST follows the HORIZON-CL5-2023-D2-01-05– Hybrid electric energy storage solutions for grid support and charging infrastructure call’s scope and Destination: Cross-sectoral solutions for the climate transition as a focused project involving technology development and emphasizing the role of longer-duration technologies, as well as showcasing and validating solutions in relevant environment (electrical grid and EV charging infrastructure, TRL 7). The SOs of HibEST are described as follows:
SO1. Development of a novel cost-effective HESS, going beyond conventional individual storage solutions, providing the best-fit in form of CAPEX, OPEX, efficiency, sustainability, and capable of long duration storage and provision of multiple services for supporting the electrical grid and EV charging infrastructure. The operational objectives will achieve this: a) To identify the various settings (e.g., optimal HESS dimensions and dynamics) so that power and energy density with respect to single electrical energy storage system increase at least 20%, storage system losses decrease 20%, extended cyclability (> 15%), and within safe conditions of operation. b) Optimise levelized cost of storage supported by design optimisation and optimal service stacking, putting the cost of storage on the path to fall below 0.05 €/kWh/cycle by 2030 (for storage durations > 12 hours); c) To undertake a cradle to grave life-cycle analysis to validate sustainability gains through the whole value chain.
SO2. Reduce the use of critical raw materials. a) Develop a redox flow battery resorting to non-CRM materials; b) Reduce the environmental impact of HibEST system by a factor between 4 and 9 with respect to conventional LIB fabrication .
SO3. Use of new advanced materials and designs to deliver a 3D printed Supercapacitor and a metal-ion flow redox battery. a) Test 3D graphene macrostructures as part of a super capacitor with increased performance. b) Study the effect of varying the electrolyte, evaluating the properties for various hydrophobic, ion mobility, and viscous properties, of the electrolytic solution.  c) Deliver capacitive testing through polarisation, voltametric experiments and structure assessment through SEM, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS analysis.
SO4. HibEST system physical integration and the development of a simulation platform. a) Production of redox flow components, assembly of the whole system and its interfacing. b) Production of the 3D printed supercapacitor components, assembly of the whole system, and its interfacing. c) Proceed with the physical integration of the HibEST system on electrical grid and EV charging infrastructure via an Energy Management System. d) Develop a modelling and simulation platform enabling a faster development and optimal use in grid applications.
SO5. Test and validate HibEST integrated system at 3 relevant environments (electrical grid and EV charging infrastructure, TRL 7). a) Proceed with an extensive training and testing campaign (measurements of voltage/power output of the system and its subcomponents, energy use, and environmental conditions) over the prototype system for pitfall detection and last improvements/modifications. b) Verify the dynamics of the integrated system in situ and validate the simulations in a real time environment. c) Determine the HibEST system performance, ensuring energy efficiency >90%, extended cyclability (> 10,000 charge/discharge cycles), levelized cost on the path to fall below 0.05 €/kWh/cycle by 2030, limited use of CRMs, and other outputs of significance
SO6. Identify HibEST performance in terms of sustainability, technical performance, lifetime, use of CRMs, space footprint and/or cost in existing and emerging energy markets a) Quantify the benefits from HibEST in respect of expected future investment and operational costs in existing and emerging markets. b) Develop an appropriate intelligent management system. c) Deliver a detailed techno-economic assessment of HibEST technology under different scenarios to understand the routes for economic growth and reduce CAPEX and OPEX in different industries. 
SO7. Prepare the HibEST concept for a large-scale exploitation a) Design a sustainable exploitation strategy based on strong market analysis and business plan. b) Make use of partners and the project’s advisory board channels to create a large network capable of supporting the project continuity. c) Make use of this network to create a strong market analysis and retrieve user feedback to design a sustainable business plan. d) Have strong Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) management and technology transfer strategy to better define an exploitation strategy. 
SO8. Promote effective dissemination and communication activities to consolidate HibEST technology among European Battery Systems and contribute to the BRIDGE initiative. a) To undertake a broad range of events (webinars, workshops) and activities to demonstrate HibEST technology to industrial stakeholders and potential users thereby facilitating further investment and commercial take-up but also to politics, KOLs and other influencers to stimulate policy making. b) Actively participate to BRIDGE activities and contribute to other relevant initiatives and clusters.

Project Title: Digital Innovative testiNG of BATteries
Project Description:
The current battery test technologies are useful only when used longer term. They require long-term testing to give useful data. The data collected is often analysed using models that are emperically incorporated into a computer programme. This makes data analysis time consuming. The diagonostic tools must recognize the battery conditions and provide reliable results, even if the charge is low. This is a demanding request as a good battery that is only partially charged behaves in a similar way to a faded pack that is fully charged. Test methods range from taking a voltage reading, to measuring the internal resistance by a pulse or AC impedance method, to coulomb counting, and to taking a snapshot of the chemical battery with Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS). Capacity estimations by deciphering the chemical battery are more complex than digital monitoring by coulomb counting. Digging into the chemical battery involves proprietary algorithms and matrices that function as lookup tables similar to letter or face recognition. It is a necessity now to develop a robust and more efficient BMS with a reduced hardware to provide a more accurate useful life as well the second life data of the battery. 

Objectives of this project are to provide 

 1) To develop advanced SoX and End of Life Evaluators, capable of improved lifetime prediction by 15% over the current SoA.
2) To develop advanced algoirthms that can emulate a fully-instrumented battery pack (every cell) with reduced instrumentation and modelling without compromising accuracy. Based on first at cell level, then module level and then pack level.
3) To develop the hardware required for implementing the extra improved features; with enough interfacability to cater for most existing BMSs, based on FPGA+EIS.
4) To develop the framework necessary for constant updating and upgrading of the models, based on inputs from the  vehicle and the cloud arrangement.
5) Aiming to deliver full-scale TRL 6 demonstration of the DingBat add-on programme on two case-studies.

Project Title: DEvelopment oF tEchnologies CriTical fOR future offshore wind farms
Project Description: The world's first offshore wind farm was installed of the coast of Denmark in 1991, over 30 years ago. In the past 30 years or so, the cost of installation per MW of power has steadily fallen. In terms of the Levelized Cost of Energy, an almost 55% drop is anticipated from 2018 to 2030, and 37% to 49% declines in production costs by 2050, making the offshore wind sector increasingly competitive with fossil fuels. Currently, offshore wind enery is considered a mature technology with large-scale adoption providing energy for millions of home around the world. This is considered the rich path towards carbon neutrality. The 2030 climate target plan outlined the strategy for greenhouse-gas emissions reduction by at least 55% by 2030 compared to 1990. This will require a scale up of the offshore wind industry, which is estimated to require less than 3% of the European maritime space and can therefore be compatible with the goals of the EU Biodiversity Strategy [offshore renewable energy strategy (COM(2020) 741 final)]. The decarbonisation of energy production is the key to overall decarbonisation as this would support other technologies that could aid for the society to become fossil-fuel independent. Such technologies include, Hydrogen based economy (use of renewable electricity for hydrogen production). In cases where CO2 emission is inevitable such as cement production, the decarbonisation of energy generation can also aid with reduction of CO2 footprint by allowing CCS for such systems. In summary, development and deployment of large-scale offshore wind farms could accelerate decarbonisation.

Project Title: High performance and stable LARGE area peroVskite PhotoVoltaic modules
Project Description:
Currently, c-Si solar cells dominate more than 90% of the PV market share because of cheap raw materials, long stability, and well-established technology. However, the limitation of c-Si PV is the complex fabrication process as well as high and therefore affect the commercialisation. As an alternative, single-junction PSC has reached 25.7% of its PCE at the laboratory scale, comparable to the first-generation monocrystalline silicon solar cell, which takes about 40 years for this level to achieve similar PCE and can be a potential low-cost alternative to c-Si. In addition to that, the perovskite-on-silicon tandem solar cell has achieved a PCE of 29.52%, with a device area of 30 cm x 30 cm and the all-perovskite tandem solar cell achieved a certified efficiency of 26.4%. However, although the efficiency and cost of PSCs are ideal for materialization, the lifetime and scale up process to fabricate the large scale module (15 cm x 10 cm ) of PSCs is yet to meet the requirements of a regular PV product.
Despite of its high efficiency form small cell (25.7% for 0.095 cm2 cell, 23.7% for 1 cm2 cell. And 22.4 for 26 cm2 minimodule), the overall stability and the cell-to-large scale module (at least 15 cm x 10 cm module) efficiency gap remains large, and a key hurdle for its commercialisation. Therefore, scaling up the device area to fabricate efficient perovskite solar modules is the necessary next step for PSCs commercial applications. To minimise this cell to module efficiency gap and to enhance the stability of module scale PSC, this proposal will bring together the key expertise and particularly focus on the

1) Development and the demonstration of a scalable method for the deposition of high-quality large-area perovskite films. Our contacted partners have already developed a very highly sable 15 cm x 10 cm PSC module with an efficiency of nearly 15%. 

2) The proposed PSC module showing a very high stability but the cost of efficiency sacrifice. Therefore, this proposal will focus on the sacrifice points to improve the efficiency uo to 25% and simultaneously will develop the fabrication process for large-area charge transporting layers and electrodes (key challenges for large area perovskite efficiency and stability). So, our contacted project partner already has the large-scale module structure. Proposal objective will be to develop and fine tune the fabrication process because we need to add the new layers to the existing structure to improve the efficiency without affecting the stability of the PSC module structure.

3) Development of more cost effective and environmental friendly substrate/electrode (alternative to ITO because that contains indium) materials for the fabrication of  PSC module 


4) In addition to improving the efficiency for commercial development of Perovskite PV, lifetime is another challenge that need to be addressed for these large-scale structures.

5) This project will develop updated test protocols and perform outdoor field performance testing of the perovskite modules as per the requirement. 

6) Overall, the project will focus to identify and tackle complex PSC module development issues related to materials (active, charge transport and electrode materials), module fabrication process, encapsulation, testing, commercialisation and circularity.

We will be developing large scale fabrication process and achieved an efficiency of ~ 15% for 15cm x 10 cm PSC module. That process will the base line for us to develop an industrial scale  method for the deposition of high-quality large-area perovskite films and electrodes.

Project Title: Zoonosis and the evolution of host genomes
Project Description: This study will address the role of the host genome in zoonosis by using abundant knowledge of the primate malarial parasite Plasmodium falciparum.  It is clear that malaria is a recent zoonosis, as the closely-related parasite P.praefalciparum has been found in wild gorillas with no pathological effects. Therefore, the parasite jumped from wild gorillas into humans approximately 10,000 years ago, and became pathogenic (1).  P.praefalciparum infects gorillas, and related Plasmodium species of the Laverinia family infecting other apes, show host-specificity in the wild, but human P.falciparum can infect chimpanzees and bonobos in captivity (2) without malarial symptoms, suggesting that genetic changes in the host genome, in addition to the parasite, underly reduced sensitivity to malaria (3, 4). Little is known about how these apes evolved resistance to malarial symptoms despite chronic and widespread infection with P.falciparum-like (Laverinia family) parasites. This project aims to answer this question.

Project Title: Investigating the Role of Host Stress in Pneumococcal Pathogenesis
Project Description: When inside their host, bacteria encounter a variety of host signals including fluctuations in temperature, oxygen level and nutrient availability. One of the most prominent host signals are catecholamine (CA) stress hormones, including dopamine (Dop), epinephrine (Epi) and norepinephrine (NE) In our breakthrough study, we showed that NE-treated Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn) efficiently translocated from the nasopharynx into the lungs and increased its virulence potential. We also found that the regulatory protein TCS09 plays a role in Spn response to stress hormones. In this study, we will build upon our existing work and test the hypothesis that pneumococcal translocation from the nasopharynx into the lungs is triggered by stress hormone recognition via a complex genetic network under the environmental conditions of the respiratory tract. The objectives of this project are to 1.) Determine how chemical and nutritional factors intersect with stress hormone responses to enable a shift from commensal to an invasive phenotype. 2.) Identify the effector and regulatory mechanisms responsive to stress hormones. 3.) Evaluate the impact of stress hormones on host response to Spn and determine the in vivo importance of the pneumococcal effector and regulatory mechanisms.

Project Title: The effectiveness and implementation of a walking exercise behaviour-change intervention: A hybrid 2 randomised controlled trial with health economic analysis (Motivating structure walking activity in intermittent claudication (MOSAIC2))
Project Description:
Many older people suffer disabling leg pain due to poor circulation, called intermittent claudication. This can be treated simply by walking regularly, which few people do. This is because increasing walking exercise independently is difficult without guidance and support and supervised exercise treatment is not often available. and starting or increasing walking exercise independently is difficult without guidance and support. Working with patients and practitioners, we designed a walking exercise treatment programme that was delivered by a physiotherapist trained to help people start and continue walking at home. This treatment improved people’s walking ability and ability to do everyday activities. The treatment was liked and welcomed by patients and physiotherapists and was easy to provide in a hospital. But we do not know whether its effects last a long time, whether our treatment can be easily provided in any health care setting, such as General Practices, by any trained practitioner (e.g., nurse) and if it is good value for money.
This study aims to
a)	test whether our treatment improves walking ability, participation in everyday activities and quality of life in the longer term 
b)	investigate whether our treatment can be delivered as intended in hospitals or general practices by any trained practitioner and understand the factors that may influence it being taken up by the NHS
c)	work out if our treatment is value for money for the NHS
Our treatment, called the MOtivating Structured walking Activity in Intermittent Claudication (MOSAIC) programme, includes 2 in-person or video call meetings and up to 4 more telephone or video meetings over 3 months. In these meetings a practitioner will discuss the causes of the leg pain, benefits of walking, agree walking goals and plans, and provide a step counter, manual and exercise log. In between meetings, the patient will complete walking exercise at home.
370 people aged at least 50 years with poor leg circulation who are not walking sufficiently will complete a walking test, blood pressure, weight and height measures and questionnaires about daily activities, beliefs about symptoms and treatment, quality of life and costs with one researcher. Then, they will be allocated by play of chance, i.e. randomly, to either complete our new treatment alongside their usual care or continue with their usual care alone. The measurements and questionnaires will be repeated after 3 months and 12 months. 
All treatment meetings will be recorded, and some recordings will be assessed by researchers to see if the new treatment was provided as intended by practitioners. Patients, practitioners, and managers will complete some questionnaires about whether and how the new treatment may be included in routine care. Some patients, practitioners, and managers will be interviewed to discuss the new treatment and talk about the things that might influence the treatment being included into routine care. 
We will collect the costs of the new treatment, usual care and other patient out of pocket expenses and identify if the new treatment is value for money for the NHS.
Alongside the main study, we will also investigate (a) if a computer programme can accurately assess if the treatment was delivered as intended as well as researchers and (b) compare different ways to disseminate and mobilise the knowledge from our research with patients.
Patient representatives were involved in identifying the research topic, designing the new treatment and this study. They will be involved in every aspect of the trial including the management, practitioner training and presenting the findings and their own related experiences. We will share study updates on social media and websites and present our findings at academic, practitioner and patient forums and publish them in academic journals and magazines using different formats (e.g., videos, pictures). We will share our findings with patients using written summaries and in person events.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: Open Educational Resources (OERs) to improve access to Secondary Education through Open Schools in the Global South
Project Description:
An abstract of the proposed project:
Abstract

Increasing access to, and achieving equity in basic education has been a continuing issue for many resource-poor contexts in the Global South. Several global level proclamations, most especially since the 1990s, have been made by the international agencies lead by the United Nations agencies to achieve education for all. United Nations’ declaration of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in 2015 include a specific target on education (SDG4) which stipulates that school-age children receive free education at primary and secondary levels by 2030. However, recent estimates suggest that this target is unlikely to achieve by 2030. High costs associated with building new schools and maintaining them, and educational resources are some of the challenges for increasing access to education through conventional schooling systems.

The proposed research project aims to explore the potential of alternative approaches to providing access to education at the secondary level in the Global South. It builds on the knowledge developed and experience gained to-date on Open Educational Resources (OERs) and Open Schooling (an alternative approach to providing access to learning for those who are not able to attend formal schools for a variety of reasons) in a selected number of countries in the Commonwealth. The project is relevant to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially SDG4 on education. Working with advice and guidance from the Commonwealth of Learning, and other stake holders in Global South who are interested in improving access to education in resource-poor contexts, the outcome from the project is expected to contribute to addressing inclusivity in education from a global South perspective.

Project Title: Perineural Local Anaesthetic Catheter aftEr Major lowEr limb amputatioN Trial (PLACEMENT)
Project Description: This study will test a method for  reducing painafter  leg amputation.  It involves  the surgeon placing a tiny tube, called a ‘perineural  catheter’, next to the main nerve  which is cut during surgery. Local  anaesthetic  is slowly pumped  into the tube  for  five  days. Putting  it in and  taking it out is easy and problems  are  rare.  It can replace  some  (or  all) of  the morphine  usually needed.  It may also reduce phantom pain. The study will be a ‘randomised’  trial. This means patients will be randomly chosen to either  have  surgery  with, or  without, the  tube. Everything  else will be the same. The  amount of pain will then be compared  between  those who did and those who did not have  the tube

Project Title: iDAH- Consolidating the Museum Data Service as research infrastructure
Project Description:
November 2023 will see the beta launch of the new Museum Data Service (MDS) that will, uniquely, provide the raw material for anyone wanting to work at scale with collections data from UK museums large and small. 
Most of this data is currently not online and, where it is, it rarely meets the requirements of the FAIR principles. 
Within five years, the MDS aims to bring together online – as FAIR data – the object records of at least half the country’s museums, and almost all of them within a decade.
MDS is a collaboration between Art UK, Collections Trust (CT) and the University of Leicester (UoL), with start-up funding (via Art UK) from Bloomberg Philanthropies to the end of May 2024. 
The Bloomberg grant is building the core technical infrastructure and providing staff time from Art UK and CT to manage the project and ingest collections data from the first 100 institutions. 
By the end of the start-up phase, the founding organisations will have jointly established a new non-profit company capable of taking long-term responsibility for MDS

Project Title: Business Takes Two: The Interaction between Self-Employment and Marriage Patterns
Project Description:
The economic literature on self-employment has emphasised that self-employment plays an important role throughout the income distribution. At the bottom of the distribution, self-employment opens up an opportunity to leave unemployment, whereas at the top of the distribution very successful starts contribute to innovation  and economic growth. The literature has typically analysed self-employment from the perspective of the individual entrepreneur while ignoring their family context.

In this project, we want to use rich administrative data to document the relationship between self-employment and marriage/partnership status in the data and use these empirical patterns as inputs to build a new macroeconomic model of self-employment from a family perspective. We expect that there are several dimensions which could play a role. First, as self-employment is associated with substantial risk about business success, the income of the partner is an important source of insurance. Second, the presence of a partner could ease credit constraints, which helps individuals start their business in the first place. Marriage has been documented to make wealth accumulation easier, and the partner of the entrepreneur also brings some own wealth to the relationship, which makes it easier for households to obtain credit. Third, couples may decide to start a business together and pool their assets and labour.

The data that will be used is the Dutch administrative microdata, which contains a lot of information on earnings and assets and allows to link individuals to other family members. The data is provided by Statistics Netherlands, who charge fees:

1) There is an initial setup cost to create a new project and for each researcher to gain access to the data.
2) In addition, there is a monthly fee for each register which is added to a project. Our project will require the following registers: wealth, jobs, basic register, income tax, unemployment benefits, self-employed income
3) Finally, exporting the data, for example for internal presentations also comes with a cost.

More details on the costing can be seen in the corresponding section of the Worktribe project.
