Project Title: BBSRC FoF APP14836: Establishing the YCharOS Inc. antibody characterisation pipeline for immunohistochemistry and flow cytometry applications
Project Description:
Commercial antibodies are key reagents in academic, biotechnology, and pharmaceutical research, with global sales estimated at $2-3 billion USD/ann. 20-60% of antibodies on the market do not perform as required1– leading to billions of dollars of wasted funding and a crisis of experimental reproducibility. While the pharmaceutical industry tends to characterize their antibodies internally, they usually work with 1-2 antibody manufacturers, and their data remains confidential.
Despite the size of the market and the importance of the product, YCharOS Inc., a Canadian Open Science company, is the only independent, state-of-the-art quality assessment body for antibodies for use in western blotting, immunofluorescence and immunoprecipitation. YCharOS have launched a unique, robust, independent, and scalable antibody characterisation platform with community-accepted standards and viable open science business model. They currently perform antibody characterisation with 11 commercial antibody manufacturers representing ~60% of antibody manufacturing globally, and two knockout cell line manufacturers. The estimated total in-kind contribution from all YCharOS partners has reached $2.5 million since 2020. So far YCharOS Inc. has received $800,000 CAD in fee for service contracts. Their current pipeline does not include immunohistochemistry (IHC) or flow cytometry (FC), commonly used applications in all research sectors. There is demand from the pharmaceutical sector for these services to be provided.
Aims and Objectives
This project will work to expand the YCharOS pipeline to include robust, independent, and scalable antibody characterisation for IHC and FC applications. This will be the first milestone towards expanding YCharOS Inc. to the UK, with the Leicester team focussed on protein targets of interest to the respiratory science community. Our medium-term aim is to establish workflows for all commonly used antibody/affinity reagent-based applications in Canada and UK, providing a commercial service to the biotech and pharmaceutical industry. 
The team in Leicester host facilities that are currently used in fee-for-service contracts and clinical trials for human IHC and FC studies with the pharmaceutical industry. Virk, Biddle and Bradding have experience in antibody validation/characterisation by IHC and FC. Virk and Biddle will be spending 1 month at YCharOS Inc. as part of an industry exchange funded via a BBSRC Impact Accelerator, and have been collaborating with the group in their academic work. This exchange will take place in January 2024 with the aim of developing technical and business skills, and strengthening the relationships, to expand the YCharOS Inc. pipeline.
In this phase of expansion, the Leicester team will receive knockout and control cell lines and antibodies from YCharOS Inc., that have been characterised for the other applications. They will use the facilities based in Leicester to optimise high-throughput antibody characterisation process, with trusted protocols and standards, for FC and IHC. They key output of this phase will be industry partner accepted protocols and high throughput processes.
The FC protocol will be adapted from existing workflows in Leicester and the immunofluorescence protocols already established by YCharOS Inc for intracellular targets. The IHC protocols will utilise formalin fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) cell-pellets, which has been established by YCharOS Inc. This will be supplemented by staining of FFPE human tissues utilising independent antibodies that demonstrate selectivity in FFPE cell-pellets. Once protocols are optimised and approved, the Leicester team will begin adding FC and IHC data to their open data ecosystem via Zenodo reports, F1000 gateway and the Antibody Registry/ RRID.
Once these applications are established within the open science business model, they will represent high value services/data for industry and the wider scientific community. The business model is designed to maximise value for all stakeholders and  global discovery research.

Project Title: Functional investigation of a PKN2 as a potential novel drug target for progressive lung fibrosis
Project Description:
Hypothesis - PKN2 contributes to abnormal epithelial repair and fibrotic disease progression in IPF.
This interdisciplinary project will integrate bioinformatics, genetic epidemiology, structural biology and cellular- and molecular biology to define the role of PKN2 in lung fibrosis and it’s potential as a new drug target for IPF

Aim 1 – Discovery
Bioinformatic validation of PKN2 as the causal gene driving the association signal GWAS 
Aim 2 – Structure 
To use cryo- EM analysis to reveal the common mechanism and diversification in the activation of PKN2 in epithelial cells.  
Hypothesis – The unique structure of PKN2 in epithelial cells determines the proteins pro-fibrotic function. 
Aim 3 – Mechanism
Investigate the expression of PKN2 in human lung epithelial cells, cillated cells and human IPF lung tissue
Aim 4 – Translation
Define the role of PKN2 in HLMF pro-fibrotic function using established human lung models of fibrogenesis and mouse knockout model. This will enable us to probe the complex pathways involved in PKN2 activation and por-fibrotic function

Project Title: A randomised controlled trial of carotid endarterectomy vs medical therapy for people with recently symptomatic carotid artery stenosis.
Project Description:
Background:

A carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is an operation to clean out narrowed arteries in the neck to prevent people having a stroke. Around 4000 CEA operations are performed in the NHS every year. CEA is usually offered to people who have had a minor stroke or experienced some other warning sign for a major stroke. People having a CEA also have medical (drug) therapy to help reduce the risk of stroke further. Medical therapy aims to keep people’s blood pressure low, thin the blood and reduce cholesterol.

The alternative to CEA is to offer people just the medical therapy. Research from the 1980s showed that surgery with medical therapy was better than medical therapy alone at preventing stroke. Medical therapy has greatly improved since the 1980s. There are new, better blood thinning and fat lowering tablets. The National Health Service (NHS) is now better at providing guidance and supporting people to take the correct tablets. This has reduced the risk of stroke in people who get modern medical therapy. We don’t know whether modern medical therapy alone is now good enough to avoid the need for CEA surgery. If it is, then continuing to offer CEA might be of no benefit or even leading to more strokes, surgical complications, and wasting NHS resources.

Aim: 

To find out if, in people who have had a minor stroke or other warning sign of a major stroke, medical therapy alone is as good at preventing strokes as CEA surgery combined with medical therapy.

Design & methods:

People who would normally be offered CEA will be asked if they want to take part in this research. They will then be randomly allocated to either get CEA and best medical therapy (standard treatment) or best medical therapy alone (new treatment). These people will be followed for at least two years. The number of people who have a stroke or die during follow up will be compared between those who were offered surgery and those who were not. Quality of life, psychological wellbeing, and NHS costs will also be compared. This research will be carried out in NHS hospitals across the UK and involve up to 1600 people. Over the course of the study the results will be regularly checked to confirm the safety of the new approach and the study stopped if there are any concerns.

Patient and public involvement:

To plan this study, we talked to people who had experienced a stroke or undergone surgery. We also ran a survey of people with strokes or narrowed neck arteries, to find out what outcomes were important to assess in the research. Two-thirds found this research acceptable and would join the study if they were invited. They advised us that providing good information to trial participants would be essential and that it would be important to compare the psychological impact of each treatment. We have included these suggestions in our research plans. We will expand this preliminary work by forming a public advisory group during the study. This group will advise the research team and provide ongoing input.

Dissemination:

Our patient group will assist with writing a plain language summary at the end of the project. We will talk to expert NHS groups, both when we are doing the study and when it is complete. At the end of the study, we will organise an event to publicise the results. The final results will be published in a medical journal and will be free to access. Results will be shown to NHS decision makers to decide which treatments are best for patients.

Project Title: Infection dynamics and relapse of Staphylococcus aureus in a human organ model
Project Description: In this research project we want to understand the interaction of S. aureus with immune cells in human organs and how these interactions shape staphylococcal infection dynamics including bacterial dissemination and infection relapses. Several studies showed the importance of professional phagocytes such as macrophages and neutrophils to eradicate S. aureus in vivo infection. However, clinical infection relapse, even after antibiotic therapy, is not uncommon for S. aureus infections. This suggests that S. aureus can survive in certain niches in the human host where it is protected from the immune systems as well as antibiotic treatment. This study is designed to provide novel experimental insights into S. aureus infection and relapse at the organ level.

Project Title: Development of new methodology to address the impact of poor-quality studies on meta-analysis through a research wastage perspective
Project Description:
Meta-analysis of RCTs has become the default methodology for summarising quantitative effects of healthcare interventions. Under such a framework, extensive searches for all relevant RCTs are conducted through a desire to minimise publication biases, and a common belief that combining as many studies as possible will lead to more precise results.
Tempered against this inclusivity is the concern that not all trials are conducted with equal rigour, and including poor quality trials will introduce bias into a meta-analysis. This is widely acknowledged and assessment of the quality of RCTs in a meta-analysis is recommended. However, identifying potentially biased studies, and even downgrading recommendations as a result, is only a partial solution to the problem, especially when the empirical effect estimates from a meta-analysis are of primary interest; such as when used in clinical or economic decision-making frameworks, or for justifying and designing future trials. Methods for adjusting for such biases directly in the meta-analysis do exist, but they are under-developed, time-consuming, difficult to implement and thus rarely used.
When trials with biased treatment estimates are included in a meta-analysis this can induce between-study heterogeneity and random-effects models are recommended. Somewhat counterintuitively, when heterogeneity exists in a meta-analysis, the inclusion of a future RCT will usually have very limited impact since, irrespective of size, a single study only has limited impact to influence the degree of heterogeneity. Further, when heterogeneity exists, all trials in a meta-analysis will get less weight compared to when results are homogenous.  Whilst this is accepted, the implications it has for research wastage are potentially huge. For example, consider the scenario where a limited number of (potentially small) initial RCTs are conducted with poor methodological conduct (potentially along with other good quality studies), resulting in exaggerated biased treatment effects, causing a meta-analysis including them to have induced heterogeneity. It can be shown that any new study will have little impact on the evidence-base and thus be poor value for money.  
The overall aim of this project is to quantify the negative impact biased studies can have on meta-analysis, and evaluate and further develop accessible approaches to mitigate it..
Part 1 will use simulation and the impact of precision metrics, outlined above, to establish when problems exist, and quantify and demonstrate its impact in different scenarios. 
Part 2 will then apply and compare alternative analysis approaches to the simulated datasets to quantify their ability to mitigate the problems. These will include the use of alternative synthesis approaches (based on various evidence exclusion criteria including extremeness of effect, contribution to heterogeneity or effect precision) and applying model diagnostics(such as impact per patient randomised calculated in terms of improved effect precision) 

Part 3 will consider some existing meta-analyses datasets and apply the approaches which perform best in Part 2. Whilst the “truth” is unknown for these datasets the illustration to real data will be important to motivate future further evaluation and uptake.

Project Title: Patient Education and behaviour change interventions for people with cardiometabolic comorbidities and low educational attainment, a systematic review
Project Description:
Cardiometabolic disease includes a number of interlinked conditions, including cardiovascular disease, obesity, cholesterol problems and type 2 diabetes. People with low educational attainment are more at risk of these conditions, and if they are diagnosed with them, tend to do worse. 

One of the most important parts of the treatment of these diseases, is adopting appropriate lifestyle changes including maintenance of a healthy weight, dietary adaptions and regular physical activity. In order to make such changes, a person first has to learn about them. Our work so far has suggested that people with low educational attainment may prefer to learn in different ways to the population as a whole and might benefit from having resources designed with them in mind. 

This study aims to use a systematic process to review the use of educational lifestyle change interventions in the population of interest to date, Understand what they have consisted of, and whether they have been beneficial. The results of this study will be used towards informing the development of an intervention specifically for this group

Project Title: AF Virtual Ward & AliveCor
Project Description:
The AF Virtual Ward,  developed by clinicians based at the Glenfield Hospital provides clinicians the ability to monitor patients remotely.  Patients are provided with equipment to record blood pressure, amount of oxygen in the blood  (pulse oximeter)  and their heart rhythm (ECG) from the comfort of their own home. The ECG data is recorded on a device called Kardia provided by a company called  AliveCor https://www.alivecor.com 

The information collected is then uploaded to an app called 'MyDignio'  provided by Dignio https://dignio.com/uk/mydignio.   The app provides the interface for clinicians in the hospital to access the data collected by the patient at home. 

The AF Virtual Ward project is expanding  which requires further interactions with both AliveCor and Dignio.   Consultancy agreements are required.

Project Title: LSTM L2: LSTM Level 2 Processor/Product development and associated Cal/Val
Project Description:
AWARD: Lead is in negotiation with ESA 
The main aim of the project is to develop and to deliver the L2A operational processor which will be deployed in the LSTM ground segment and be used by the Agency to generate the L2A products.
To achieve this the project has the following objectives:
1. To select and define the algorithms used for the retrieval of the various parameters (LST, LSE, aerosols, TCWV…) and to improve these algorithms over the whole duration of the project,
2. To develop a prototype used as a precursor and to test any evolution of the algorithms prior to their implementation into the operational processor,
3. To define the cal/val activities, before the launch, during the phase E1 (commissioning) and during the Phase E2 (routine operations), needed to assess the performances and the quality of the operational LSTM L2A products.
4. To support the engagement of a community of users and facilitate their use of LSTM products, develop open-source library modules allowing them to process the products themselves (the prototype will also be made available to users)

Project Title: Proteomic analysis of plasma for diagnosis and therapeutic monitoring in Alzheimer’s Disease
Project Description: This study will identify protein biomarkers in plasma and explore their potential use as diagnostic markers of AD, and as biomarkers of therapeutic effectiveness. The outcome could facilitate an earlier initial AD diagnosis, enabling commencement of anti-dementia treatment to start sooner, and more rapid decision-making regarding effectiveness of anti-dementia treatment, potentially reducing the rate of cognitive decline. The results of both parts of the study would eventually form the basis for the development of a rapid blood test for use in primary and secondary care settings, which would aid AD diagnosis, and facilitate decisions regarding therapeutic treatment, potentially reducing the rate of cognitive decline.

Project Title: Enhancing crossover formation and gene introgression in Barley
Project Description: Barley is a major worldwide crop but breeding new varieties is constrained by the frequency and distribution of genetic crossovers that underpin crop improvement. This project aims to utilise the phenotype of barley pachytene checkpoint 2 mutants that delay the timing of meiotic recombination thus enabling crossovers to form in chromosomal regions that rarely or never recombine. We hypothesise that the mutant perturbs the stringency of DNA sequence monitoring thereby allowing recombination to take place between chromosomes from divergent species. This will enhance introgression between barley and wild relatives, thus unlocking a wider gene pool of important agronomical traits.

Project Title: Using real world evidence to supplement paediatric RCTs
Project Description:
Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) have long been considered the gold standard for evaluating the effectiveness of health care interventions. However, besides being expensive to run, they sometimes fail to adequately answer the research questions they were designed to address, for example because they were under-powered or were terminated early. Real-World Data (RWD) in the form of routinely collected datasets provide an alternative information source, but inherent biases are a drawback to their usage in this context. The recent development of target trial methodology aims to mitigate the biases common to RWD by applying the study design principles of randomised trials to observational data. In addition to offering a valid alternative to RCTs, there is the potential to combine target trial data with RCT data making use of all available data sources to better answer important clinical questions. This is particularly attractive when an RCT alone provides insufficient data, and there is the prospect of wasted information and patient resource, with accompanying ethical issues. To our knowledge this use has yet to be explored.

The aim of this project is to demonstrate the viability of supplementing RCT data with target trial data derived from large health care datasets, using a case study where the RCT has insufficient information to answer its research question as intended and whose interventions are already given in clinical practice. This approach will be more generally applicable to a wide range of settings where increased information can improve health care decision making.

We will take a Bayesian approach, which naturally facilitates modelling complex data from multiples sources and allows direct estimation of the probability that a health care intervention is beneficial. We will produce target trial data emulating the RCT using existing frameworks: this entails producing a study protocol that emulates the RCT protocol, within the constraints of the available observational data. A key challenge that we will address is how relative weights of the differing data sources should be derived and applied. We will assess the ease of implementation and performance of different modelling strategies: including building a joint model through linking multiple sub-models and a multi-stage modelling approach which incorporates information from the previous stage through the prior distribution.

Our case study will use RCT data from the FIRST-line support for Assistance in Breathing in Children (FIRST-ABC) study, previously conducted and successfully completed at the Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre (ICNARC). The RWD will come from the Paediatric Intensive Care Audit Network (PICANet). An early closure of FIRST-ABC will be simulated, so we will use only part of the FIRST-ABC data for our combined modelling of the RCT and RWD data. The RCT results based on the full data will then be used to assess the performance of our proposed method.
This research will be undertaken at ICNARC.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Lead Organisation: Intensive Care National Audit & Research Centre

Project Title: NIHR Senior Investigator Award (Second Term)
Project Description:
The NIHR Senior Investigator award is a personal award in recognition of support for NIHR and an outstanding contribution to applied health, public health or social care research.

As the NIHR’s most prominent and prestigious researchers, Senior Investigators are fundamental to the NIHR. They provide visible leadership and support the strategic priorities of the NIHR and are expected to contribute significantly to NIHR as senior leaders, and act as ambassadors and role models for the NIHR.

NIHR Senior Investigator awards are 4 years in duration. Award holders receive a discretionary award of £20,000 a year, payable to their employer or linked institution, which can be used to fund activities that support the applicant’s research (see the section Scope of Funding further on in these Guidance Notes for further details). https://www.nihr.ac.uk/documents/nihr-senior-investigator-round-17-guidance-notes/33818

Project Title: Improving quality of life for people living with dementia and their care partners: the development, intervention and evaluation of a dementia specific narrative-based intervention: LEND (lived experiences narratives in dementia)
Project Description:
Dementia is a progressive and disabling condition usually with loss of memory and other thinking abilities. In the UK 850,000+
people live with dementia supported by 700,000 informal carers. The diagnosis of dementia and the associated stigma can
seriously undermine a person’s sense of identity including self-esteem, social engagement, and quality-of-life. So often people
with dementia are functioning way below their potential. This is known as 'excess disability' and is linked to increased care
costs. Lack of information and support is a particular concern for people from disadvantaged groups including ethnic minorities
and the variety of LGBT+ communities. It is an NHS, service user and global priority to improve post-diagnostic dementia
support and quality-of-life so people with dementia and carers can better understand dementia symptoms and have improved
coping strategies.

Research shows people with mental health conditions find viewing, reading or listening to peers personal stories ('narratives')
helps their own well being. The NEON study collected a series of online stories from people with lived experience of mental
health problems who contributed first-person accounts of their life events, struggles, and strengths. The NEON results showed
positive benefits and good value for money. We will adapt the NEON approach and collect a large and diverse range of
people's own stories of their experiences of dementia either personally or as a carer, and then develop a way for people to find
helpful stories so creating the Lived Experience Narratives for Dementia (LEND) Intervention. We will ensure the online storysharing
is safe and accessible. Stories will be categorised for easier navigation so that people with dementia or carers can use
a filtering system to identify personally meaningful stories from text, audio or video recordings. Then we will carry out a two
studies comparing the LEND approach with usual care, the first for people with dementia, and the second for their carers.

Our consultations from a variety of family carers and people with dementia indicated that online narratives would be very
helpful to both groups. During the consultations, people from diverse backgrounds noted the lack of suitable culturally tailored
and appropriate information after dementia diagnosis. Our previous work found that people with younger onset or rarer
dementia may find such shared stories especially valuable Our Lived Experience Advisory Panel (LEAP) will be provided with
training and support in patient and public involvement (PPI), research skills and cultural competence training to
support involvement. LEAP members will include include a representatives who self-identify as Black, South Asian and
LGBT+.The research team and LEAP will work together to collect data, interpret results, help develop: the LEND Intervention,
recruitment strategy and dissemination/implementation plan.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Name of Call: NIHR Programme Grants for Applied Research - Competition 41

Project Title: Karger Ambassador Programme
Project Description:
The program is designed to help connect researchers, healthcare industry professionals, and their respective communities, show support and appreciation for them and their work, and raise awareness of Karger and scientific publishing.
Ambassadors will share information about Karger and publishing within their professional networks, whether online or in person, collaborate with Karger on events such as webinars, and be active in the network of Karger Ambassadors.
Karger will support Ambassadors in doing so by providing information and assets that can be shared. Karger will, when feasible, provide other (non-monetary) benefits such as access to publishing insights and networks, and use of Karger Campus courses.

This program creates opportunities for students I teach, as they are willing to support a journal club that I am organising to support students in the transnational (UK-China) BSc Clin Sci programme. Additionally, ECRs like me will potentially benefit from the different training resources they provide, access to journal articles/books and discounted publication charges if we choose to publish with them. Project Title: Accelerated Knowledge Transfer To Innovate (AKT2I) With MONUMO
Project Description: This project is to fill the gap between motor design and motor-drive control for transportation applications. Conventionally, motor design and optimization mainly look at the geometry sizing, magnetic and thermal analysis, and material selection, according to the optimization objectives (e.g., weight, loss). The potential control performance is usually not considered during the optimization process. This issue could increase the re-design/re-work probability, especially when the designed motor cannot satisfy the control requirements, for example D-Q inductance is too high.

Project Title: Wordsworth in India: Understanding the Colonial Legacies of English Literature
Project Description: 'Wordsworth in India' explores the influence of Wordsworth's poetry and the Wordsworth family on the educational and administrative cultures of late nineteenth-century India. While recent research has shown how closely the poet's family was linked with Indian affairs (Bergsen, 2019), and how Wordsworth's poetry played a role in the history of India's colonial administration (Kennedy, 2020), an important story that remains to be told is the contribution of Wordsworth's grandsons to this history. Drawing on untranscribed documents in the Wordsworth Museum, Grasmere, in the British Library, and in private collections in the UK, USA and India, the project focusses on John Wordsworth's (1837-1927) role as a soldier involved in the suppression of the First Indian War for Independence and William Wordsworth's (1835-1917) work as Professor of English Literature and moral philosophy at Elphinstone and Deccan colleges in the 1860s, and his services as Principal and Vice-Chancellor of Bombay University from 1875 until his retirement in 1890. Through consideration of John's letters and his sketches of Indian subjects, the project will examine how his depiction of colonial India was influenced by his grandfather's writings, how his duties as a soldier were understood by his family and social circles, and how attitudes to British involvement in India were reconfigured following the collapse of the East India Company and the formation of the British Raj in 1874. The project will then go on to consider how William drew on his grandfather's work to inform the content and design of the college and university curriculums and the development of his support for the cause of Indian independence. To address these aims, the PI will need time to read and transcribe a selection of handwritten documents and consult a range of primary and secondary materials with a view to completing a c.10,000-word article for submission to the international Wordsworth Circle journal in the summer of 2025. As a majority of the documents are held in the Wordsworth Museum, the project will assist in the museum's efforts to decolonise its collections and will form a valuable adjunct to the museum's current AHRC-funded research network 'Addressing the Histories and Legacies of Empire in Literary House Museums: Dove Cottage and Beyond', of which the PI is a member. By examining the Wordsworth family's complex history of military, administrative and educational involvement in India, the project will advance understanding of the colonial and postcolonial legacies of English literature. Liaison with Corinne Fowler, whose Colonial Countryside project is an important touchstone for the project, as well as with Jeff Cowton at the Wordsworth Museum, along with academics and librarians in Mumbai and Pune, will bring significant benefits in terms of creating the conditions for further collaborative work exploring the relations between English literary culture and the maintenance and dissolution of Empire. The potential for development of the research will be explored in an online interactive workshop at the project's close, with key findings disseminated via short pieces offered to The Conversation and the Times Literary Supplement.

Project Title: Talking Animals: Teaching Human and Animal Relations in the Middle Ages
Project Description: How did medieval people think and feel about the animals they lived and worked with? What can we in the twenty first century learn from attitudes towards non-human organisms before the industrialisation of farming and advent of mass transportation? This project sets out not to answer these questions, but to provoke discussion of them. It will make available a series of valuable but neglected Middle English texts in a freshly-edited, open-access edition. These pieces have been selected for their complexity and the range of ways with which they engage with the animal world, showing how profoundly creatures were entangled in the emotional, material, philosophical and moral lives of premodern people. It will also be accompanied by a pack of teaching materials, including classroom exercises and lesson-plans involving the texts, in order to facilitate reflection on the important questions they raise about how we conceive and approach the animal world today.

Project Title: Labour Markets under Strain: UK Employment and the Pandemic
Project Description: Covid-19 brought to the fore debates about contemporary employment. Understanding labour markets is central to this discourse. Labour markets feature at least tacitly in discussions surrounding the precarious nature of work deemed “essential” in the pandemic; state interventions that ensured the continuity of employment relations for many firms and workers; the high profile of the “gig economy”, characterised by apparently novel forms of self-employment; and debates about a supposed “great resignation” or a rise in “quiet quitting” in the wake of the pandemic. Through a quantitative analysis of Labour Force Survey data, this research will explore the evolution of labour markets in the UK before, during and after the global health emergency associated with the pandemic. The research will add to debates on the political economy of labour markets and the extent to which the pandemic has transformed employment or accelerated existing trends.

Project Title: AISP: AI Empowered Social Prescribing: impact-driven personalised care and wellbeing
Project Description:
There is an increasing need to provide home and community-centred approaches to healthcare, such as Social Prescribing (SP) which ameliorates the recent UK government's efforts1 to address health inequalities by bringing together healthcare and community services to respond to patients' non-medical needs. Technology and AI-empowered solutions including machine learning of personal preferences have the potential to tackle these issues by expanding the use of community-based preventative and direct interventions, reducing health inequalities within a local area by reaching out to vulnerable individuals with deteriorating conditions that keep them in continuous care and often experience exacerbations.  

The vision of this CDT is to foster a regional AI community across key East midland (EM) organisations together, to co-develop and implement AI-empowered solutions for SP at both the personal and community levels with real-life impact. To ensure the adoption of solutions derived from CDT research output, we propose a unique configuration that each of our CDT projects will have a co-sponsoring organisation, that will 1) act as the “problem owner” to co-define industry challenges with the CDT core team; 2) appoint a staff member as the industry advisor for their CDT project(s); 3) Contribute 25% financially to the co-defined project; 4). Provide the testbed to launch, test and feedback on the research output. With such configuration, each CDT project will be considered as a lean start-up team, led by the doctorate candidates (as CEO), with a core team containing a main academic adviser, an industry advisor and a secondary academic adviser.
Funder: UKRI UK Research and Innovation UKRI
Name of Call: UKRI Centres for Doctoral Training in artificial intelligence

Project Title: Gaze and memory for real-life episodes in older and young adults
Project Description:
We rely on visual information to navigate safely and memorise landmarks to orient ourselves in the world. As
we grow older, changes to our visual system and mobility mean we interact differently with the environment.
Investigating how these changes impact memory of natural scenes is challenging. This project will integrate
the use of eye-tracking and artificial intelligence (AI) to test people’s short-term memory of the episodes they
just experienced. We will measure where young and older adults look as they walk on the street and test their
recollection of events. Measuring visual memory during natural behaviour will help us understand how different
groups of people interact with their visual environment and remember its features. This project will significantly
advance our understanding of the effect of ageing on visual memory during natural behaviour and will provide
a proof-of-concept for the use of AI in next-generation cognitive testing.

Project Title: Nation Building and Female Stars in the Chinese Revolutionary Film Industry:  Body, Voice, and Mind
Project Description: As public figures, film stars function as open texts through which various social, political, and cultural values are negotiated and contested.  Through a detailed examination of historical documents about six female film stars, this project investigates how Chinese women negotiated their subjectivity during the first phase of the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Focusing on the Mao era (1949-1976), this project researches a crucial period of Chinese history when the country’s cultural, economic, and political systems were steered towards a new direction by the governing Communist Party. This project sets out to challenge the male-centred discourse of Chinese film history and uncover the root of the marginalised and suppressed voices of women in the state-sanctioned Chinese film industry.

Project Title: Roman Era Worldings: Rethinking the Everyday in the Roman Period
Project Description: This project is an investigation of the archaeology of the Roman world through a critical analysis and evaluation of the everyday in the Roman past through the use of archaeological datasets. The discipline of archaeology concerns the study of people’s lives in the past but whilst the ‘everyday’ constitutes perhaps 95% of our lives it has received little critical study and is simply a natural background to ‘grander’ themes such as the economy, death and burial and identity. Understanding the ‘everyday’ however is fundamental in Roman archaeology for addressing key issues relating to the impact of the expanding Empire on the provinces and evaluating the nature of social continuity and change. A critical ‘everyday’ emphasises another Roman past with a different set of relationships between the mundane and extraordinary compared with our lives in the present. There were also different attitudes to the people living their lives including slaves, provincial peoples and elites. The analysis of archaeological data allows us to move away from established assumptions on the everyday and will be organised around three scales and based on the northwest provinces of the Empire. The first scale will concern a critical evaluation of ‘mundane’ objects in the study region: pottery and coins. The next scale will concern public, domestic, work and religious space and activities in urban and rural contexts. These activities and, the lives and experiences they represent, have tended to be taken for granted in the past. The next scale will relate to the everyday in wider landscapes examining the context of settlements through landscape archaeology. This will all come together in the largest scale to evaluate the meaning of this activity – exploring the social and economic context through the Roman period; continuity and change through the Roman period through the issue of the everyday. This approach to the everyday, a major component of people’s lives in the past, will be discipline-transforming and establish new priorities for studying and interpreting Roman archaeology.

Project Title: Self-management support to enhance work ability in people with long-term health conditions and disabilities.
Project Description:
This award will look at how workers with long-term health problems and disabilities, including cancer, arthritis, hearing loss, and
poor mental health, can be supported to self-manage at work. Self-management describes the actions people take to help them
stay well. For example, taking medication, exercising, or getting help from friends or family when required. Our aim is to carryout workshops and other activities to understand how employers can support self-management to improve health and quality of
working life. This information will be used to develop a larger funding bid for the NIHR Research Collaboration Award scheme.

Background
There are 13 million workers in the UK with long-term health problems or disabilities. To help people stay well at work, the UK
government and professional groups want employers to support workers to self-manage their health. Yet, there is no specific
advice for employers to help them achieve this goal. Our own research has shown that workers want employers to provide self-management support, but they do not receive it. This is because employers do not know about self-management or how to
offer it.
We have developed a guide (or model) that outlines how workplaces can offer self-management support. The model was co-developed with employers and workers with long-term health problems. The model includes key areas of self-management
support, such as how workers can tell their employers about their health needs and how employers can be prepared to meet
these needs. This model now needs to be turned into tools, such as web- or paper-based information resources, to help people
with long-term health problems and disabilities self-manage their health so that they can maintain or improve their work ability.

Design and methods
Through workshops, we will bring together different groups of researchers, employers, civil servants, healthcare professionals,
and workers. These workshops will help us work-out the best ways to turn our model into tools that can help improve workplace
self-management. These workshops will also help us bring together a team of people who will work together on the Research
Collaboration Award.

Patient and public involvement
The research team will include 12 workers with diverse lived experiences who have different long-term health problems and
disabilities. This will make sure the research meets their needs and is easily understood by everyone. They will be involved in
all parts of the research project, including writing reports, leading workshops, and planning the future funding bid.

Dissemination
We will share a report from our project, including how employers can best offer self-management support with other workers,
employers, the government, professional groups, and researchers. This work will also inform our NIHR Research Collaboration
Award, which will involve projects that aim to develop and assess workplace self-management support tools
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Digital Food: Health and Efficient Food Supply and Consumption (TBC)
Project Description: This project will support the UK food industry’s progress towards a circular economy by reducing household food waste, supporting balanced and healthier diets for individuals, and reducing the need for carbon intensive food production processes. This ambitious project will achieve this by applying novel data acquisition and artificial intelligence (AI) based processing techniques to characterise and optimise nutritional intake and wastage, health requirements, food availability (domestic and supply chain), costs and environmental impacts. This informed understanding of consumer behaviour towards food will facilitate systems strategies to bring consumers into the organised food supply chain. This in turn will underpin the development and demonstration of specific economically viable interventions that will encourage, support and enable behaviour change resulting in greater food security, public health benefits and improved environmental sustainability.

Project Title: Why look back? Contemporary Art & Institutional Memory
Project Description:
This seminar aims to identify, draw together, and critically reflect on a growing field of practice -namely, non-collecting contemporary art institutions working with their pasts to generate new exhibitions, projects, public programmes and historical narratives. 
An ‘institutional memory’ - formed by archives, recollections, and wider collective knowledge - has distinct importance for art institutions whose longevity, value and stake in history are not secured by a permanent collection. The potential of institutional memory as a resource for new activities has become apparent over the past decade: organisations across Britain – for example 198; Arnolfini; Bluecoat; Chisenhale; CCA; Ikon and Modern Art Oxford - have taken collaborative doctorates, funded projects and significant anniversaries as opportunities to emphasise the significance of previous exhibitions or projects and activate this past by recovering marginalised histories, commissioning new work, confronting prior connections to regimes of power and violence, and inviting former publics to share and discuss their own recollections and archives. 
Despite this, there has been no collective or open consideration of what innovations, limitations and further debates have arisen through practices of reflection, retrospection, and re-activation. The seminar will thus re-group artists, curators and researchers engaged in and concerned with the ethics, practices, and potential of institutional memory, to focus on the following questions:  

•	What is the potential of institutional memory as a basis for public engagement, curatorial innovation, and organisational development within non-collecting institutions?

•	To what extent has engagement with institutional memory broadened our understanding of histories of contemporary art and revealed the historical conditions under which art and creative practice is valued? 

•	What are the benefits, limitations, and constraints of establishing memory practices as a consistent area of work, especially within non-collecting contemporary art institutions?
Scheme: Funder not listed - UK Charity Default Scheme
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)

Project Title: Copy of Contrast-free evaluation of scarring within the heart using cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging
Project Description:
Heart disease costs the NHS over £9billion annually.  Each year, over 100,000 people suffer a heart attack, resulting in permanent scarring of their heart. Survivors are at increased risk of sudden death or developing heart failure, a debilitating condition. Currently, doctors do not have very good tools to predict who will and will not develop complications.   

Pictures of ‘scarring’ within the heart can be obtained using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), after giving patients a ‘dye’ (a gadolinium compound). This provides an accurate method to identify even small heart attacks. However, giving this dye adds cost, and it is not safe in some people (with advanced kidney disease or allergic reactions); its long-term effects are also currently unknown. Moving ‘cine’ images of the heart are routinely acquired, and do not require any dye to be given. Hence, it would be advantageous to use these dye-free images to identify scar. This project aims to develop and test a fully automatic computer program using artificial intelligence (AI) to ‘convert’ the dye-free images into scar images. Hence, a new method to identify scarring within the heart will be developed and validated.
Funder: UKRI UK Research and Innovation UKRI
Name of Call: Artificial intelligence innovation to accelerate health research

Project Title: Confirming and embedding patient value within an AI-enabled nAMD treatment monitoring intervention for implementation
Project Description:
Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the commonest cause of blindness in the UK and improving monitoring is a priority for the James Lind Alliance. It can be divided into ‘wet’ and ‘dry’ subtypes and since 2008 there has been an approved treatment for wet AMD, involving a series of injections into the eye at clinician-led intervals. Some patients do not receive the full potential of these injections due to inadequate ophthalmology service capacity to deliver timely treatment. With increasing clinical demand, this avoidable sight loss is set to increase, along with AMD’s significant impact on health care resources within the NHS.

To improve capacity and efficiency for AMD care, new health care technologies have come to market. These include an artificial intelligence (AI) tool to monitor disease activity in wet AMD and streamline clinical decisions on injection intervals. A recent single-centre NIHR-funded mixed methods study found that such independent AI-enabled treatment decisions appeared superior to observed real-world clinic decisions. This superiority was regarding patients’ stated priority of sight preservation.

The same mixed methods study also analysed interview transcripts from patients, carers and other stakeholders to draft an AI-enabled intervention for wet AMD treatment monitoring, and strategies for its implementation. Broad acceptance and opportunities to improve patients’ equity of access to care through AI emerged, but their exploration was limited by low participant diversity at the single site. We will address this through focus groups in varied settings across the UK, recruiting diverse individuals with wet AMD and those close to them. These focus groups will seek to confirm and extend our understanding of the value proposition of AI for wet AMD patients, and intervention features which best deliver it. Consultant medical retina specialists hold central influence in local implementation success. Interviews with these clinical leaders in diverse AMD services across the UK will be performed to help shape an intervention that is not just patient-centred, but nationally implementable.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: HORIZON-HLTH-2023-DISEASE-03-07:Relationship between infections and non-communicable diseases
Project Description: The body responds to infection by altering its metabolism to support energy intensive immunological protective pathways, this response should return to normal as infection is cleared. In Mtb infection, the bacteria are not cleared but are contained locally and continue to drive immunological and inflammatory responses with the potential to disrupt metabolic homeostasis. This is an important issue because one quarter of the world’s population is latently infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb)(latent TB), and 5% of these are at risk of developing TB2 (active TB). Diabetes is a critical risk factor for TB3 and is associated with higher mortality and poorer treatment outcomes to TB4. Importantly, prediabetes is higher in TB patients5 and TB diagnosis often highlights changes in glucose homeostasis with hyperglycaemia and insulin resistance being recorded6-7. Indeed, many TB patients have abnormal fasting glucose trajectories or transient hyperglycaemia during treatment4. These observations raise the question: To what extent does infection with Mtb interfere with glucose metabolism and metabolic homeostasis?  In the progression to type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance is the first sign of disrupted glucose metabolism, prediabetes is insulin resistance accompanied by glucose intolerance and this becomes diabetes when glucose blood levels remain high8. In this WP we will define how Mtb infection impacts glucose metabolism and metabolic homeostasis. We will use mouse models to define cellular and molecular pathways within a defined and manipulatable model system. We will integrate these data with focused experimental studies in latently infected subjects as well as those with active TB.

Project Title: Evaluating the regional implementation of the Passport to my Health and Well-being across primary care, mental health and cancer services
Project Description:
Middlesbrough and Stockton Mind in partnership with Macmillan have been exploring the experiences of people who live with mental health conditions and are subsequently affected by cancer. Based on information gathered from people with lived experience of mental health conditions and cancer, their carers and health professionals, a passport has been co-produced by members of the Macmillan Mental Health Cancer Co-production Group. The Passport is designed to help people with mental health conditions who are subsequently affected by cancer or a long term health condition to cope with attending appointments and treatment. It enables patients to record and share important information about their feelings, their cancer diagnosis and treatment with their healthcare team and support networks. In addition, the Passport provides patients with practical support, help and guidance on their cancer journey. 

This project aims to evaluate the implementation of the ‘Passport to my Health and Well-being’ across primary care, mental health and cancer services within the Cumbria and North East region to understand the impact it has on the experiences of people living with pre-existing mental health conditions and who subsequently are affected by cancer. In so doing the objectives are:

•	To understand the barriers and facilitators to implementation 
•	To identify the optimal setting for the adoption of the passport 
•	To assess the impact of implementing the passport on workforce and service integration
•	To explore patients’ and carers views and experiences of using the passport 
•	To explore the potential use of a digital version of the passport across services

Project Title: Workshop for Analysis of Planetary Materials within Containment
Project Description:
We will hold a 1.5 day workshop at Space Park Leicester to inform and gather ideas about technology for analysis of planetary materials within containment. In particular, we will introduce the Double Walled Isolator (DWI) as a Class III bio-safety cabinet and demonstrate its instrument box concept that we have been collaborating on with the JPL-NASA team. This development is currently funded by ESA.
The 1.5 day workshop during May11-12th 2023 will include a discussion led by Olsson-Francis about current astrobiology and related COSPAR regulations.

Project Title: 3D recoverable and reconfigurable functional  Electronic  Assemblies
Project Description: The vision of this project (Fig. 1) is to develop a sustainability-driven circuit assembly paradigm which co-integrates functionality, design for informed disassembly, that provide an immediate solution to reducing emissions and elevated e-waste problem (Gen 2) whilst providing a longer-term sustainable solution where Design for Deconstruction and Dematerialisation is embedded within the design process (Gen 3). VERTICAL will therefore experiment with a range of creative combinations to discover and demonstrate the most suitable choices as sub-solutions/sub-systems to solve the complex System of Systems challenges posed for sustainable electronics and ICT manufacture. The transition to a fully sustainable manufacturing model requires a step change integrated strategy, that both disrupts the traditional linear electronics manufacturing flow, while incrementally transforming the industry’s approach to electronic design, preserving backward compatibility and upskilling future designers. VERTICAL uses circuit assemblies, moving from solely being an interconnect, as a functional and active platform which allows electronic systems to be designed and disassembled sustainably, and linking this to the creation of new supply chain actors engaged in the circular economy.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C

Project Title: NIHR Development and Skills Enhancement Award
Project Description:
The National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Academy is launching the next competition for the Development and Skills Enhancement (DSE) award as part of the NIHR Fellowship Programme, funded by the Department of Health and Social Care.

The DSE Award is a post-doctoral level funding opportunity aimed at supporting early to mid-career researchers in gaining specific skills and experience to underpin the next phase of their research career. Examples of this include:

- enhancing knowledge of clinical trials by spending time at a Clinical Trials Unit
- building collaborations with industry
- expanding academic networks and collaborations
- formal training courses, or
- any other development of skills or experience which would benefit future applications and longer-term career plans.

Project Title: Does the epigenetic clock regulate early life environmental exposures' effects on lifespan and healthspan?
Project Description:
This project will help understand the proximate causes of life history evolution by establishing the effect of larval diapause on insect epigenetic ageing. This extends our discovery of epigenetics’s role in several insect life history traits (1). Why individuals and species age so differently is one of the biggest unanswered questions in evolutionary biology (2).
Environments can be variable and organisms can be selected to sense the state of their environ- ment early in life and to adaptively adjust their life history in response to these changes (3). The ability of one genotype to produce different life-histories depending on the environment is known as a life-history polyphenism (3). We ask could epigenetics and specifially the epigenetic clock be a proximate mechanism of these life-history polyphenisms.
An epigenetic clock is a biochemical test based on measuring the accumulation of chemical marks (DNA methylation) to DNA molecules (4). There is evidence epigenetic age mirrors true biological age and its associated morbidity and mortality better than chronological age (5). The rate at which an epigenetic clock ticks is strongly affected by the environment. This seems especially true in the early stages of life (6). This gives rise to the idea that an epigenetic clock can be developmentally tuned as part of an adaptive response to environmental variables experienced during development (6).
Aging is a complex process influenced by many environmental and genetic components. The effects of these components influence each other making them difficult to investigate, especially in complex mammalian models. Therefore, a large body of ageing research is based on simple model invertebrate organisms (7, 8). Advantages include easy and cheap to keep in a laboratory, short lifespan, genetic and molecular tools available, and a sequenced genome. However, the current invertebrate models of ageing (Drosophila (9) and C. elegans (10)) do not possess detectable DNA methylation, reducing their generality.
The jewel wasp, Nasonia vitripennis, an emerging model system (11) has a functional methylation system (12) making it an ideal system to investigate the epigenetics of ageing. We therefore mea- sured chronological ageing and changes in the epigenome using whole genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) in order to discover if Nasonia vitripennis possessed an epigenetic clock. The epigenetic age of each replicate is the weighted average of each genes’ methylation state. This epigenetic age does indeed correlate with chronological age (13). This is similar to results found in many vertebrates (6). However, this is the first time an epigenetic clock has been discovered in a tractable insect model.
An example of a life-history polyphenism in Nasonia is larval diapause, an overwintering stage where development is arrested and adult lifespan is increased (14). DNA methylation is involved in Nasonia diapause (15). Using published RNA-seq datasets (16), we have found an increase in the expression of DMNT1a (the enzyme responsible for DNA methylation maintenance) and a decrease in TET (the enzyme that removes methylation) in diapaused versus non-diapaused larvae. This suggests a maintenance of DNA methylation during diapause.

Project Title: Genome control by cohesin ligands
Project Description:
It has been proposed that DNA folding by ‘loop extrusion’ is a central organising principle of genome conformation. This process involves SMC complexes such as cohesin that by reeling DNA into loops
can bring distant loci into proximity, with important consequences for DNA-based processes. We recently discovered that cohesin is controlled by interaction with ligands such as CTCF. These interactions are essential for control of cohesin function during specific genome transactions such as formation of TADs. CTCF binds cohesin using a specific peptide motif that is present in regulators of replication, transcription, and other fundamental genome functions. We hypothesize that each of these chromosomal regulators represents a ‘cohesin ligand’ that through a universal mechanism directs cohesin to control a different genomic process. We propose an interdisciplinary project involving structural biology, analyses in cells and model organisms, and integrative imaging across scales. Our goals are to understand (1) How cellular ligands control cohesin function. (2) Requirements of chromatid cohesion & DNA looping and (3), to discover new areas of genome biology in which cohesin-mediated genome folding plays critical roles. We will specifically seek a bottom-up understanding of how one general principle of control contributes to different fundamental aspects of genome biology.

Project Title: Gender-based violence, youth, and the arts: developing creative methods for GBV prevention in the Anglophone Caribbean
Project Description:
The term gender-based violence (GBV) refers to forms of violence – physical or psychological – that are rooted in gender inequality. A 2021 World Health Organisation study presents GBV as a major public health crisis affecting nearly one in three women globally. Data compiled by UN Women and the UNODC indicates that GBV continues to be a critical issue in the Caribbean region. For decades, GBV has been a central concern in Caribbean feminist scholarship and activism, and in recent years Caribbean governments have launched programmes dedicated to combatting gender-based violence. Projects aimed at eliminating violence against women and girls, facilitated by the UN/EU Spotlight Initiative (2020-2023), have generated a renewed focus on this issue across the region. 
This project will address the ongoing problem of persistent high levels of GBV in the region by exploring culturally sensitive strategies for youth-focused GBV prevention using literature and the performing arts. Arts-based methods have been used in GBV research for some time. However, this research has focused primarily on the Global North, and as a result there is a limited evidence base for such methods in other parts of the world. Since GBV has culturally specific dynamics, GBV prevention initiatives need to be culturally relevant. Arts-based approaches to GBV should therefore ideally engage with art forms that speak to and resonate with the communities where the intervention is taking place. With this in mind, our project will develop and evaluate an arts-based methodology that draws upon the Caribbean region’s distinctive literary and performance cultures.
Caribbean literary and oral forms such as poetry, spoken word and community theatre have long been entwined with social and political protest. The link between creative practice and activism remains strong in the contemporary cultural moment: young people across the region are using these creative modes to tackle social justice issues such as gender equality and GBV. We aim in this project to channel the transformative power of these cultural forms through a series of activities that will connect young people with youth leaders, creative practitioners and GBV activists. To achieve this aim, the project has the following objectives:  

-	To co-create a youth-focused and arts-based methodology for GBV prevention that is grounded in and responsive to the social and cultural specifics of GBV in the Caribbean region

-	To facilitate knowledge exchange between researchers, creative practitioners and NGOs about GBV and the arts

-	To build capacity within youth organisations for longer-term, sustainable programmes to prevent GBV through arts-based youth engagement
	
This project will enhance GBV education in the region by (1) training youth leaders in Jamaica and Guyana to facilitate a programme of performing arts workshops focused on GBV prevention, working with 200 young people aged 13-17; (2) curating an open access digital resource  that will showcase creative material from the workshops alongside other project outputs; (3) running a poetry and spoken word competition for young people aged 18-25 across the Anglophone Caribbean where entries will focus on GBV, and publishing an e-anthology containing the shortlisted pieces; (4) presenting an end-of-project policy brief to ministers representing gender affairs in each country. The project will develop a model of youth-led, peer education while raising the profile of the region’s literary and performance cultures in public debate on GBV.
Name of Call: Developing innovative approaches to gender-based violence
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Born in Babylon, made in Egypt; modes and mechanisms for transmitting ideas in the Ancient Near East, 3100-539 BCE
Project Description:
This project writes a history of the transmission of ideas from the cuneiform world (Mesopotamia and the Levant) to Ancient Egypt, from the rise of the world’s oldest scripts (3100BCE) to the Persian hegemony (marked by the 539BCE fall of Babylon). As new ideas from non-Egyptian cultures transformed Egypt’s social and cultural fabric, the project will revolutionise our understanding of multiculturalism in arguably the world’s oldest polity. The first of its two key research directions asks what ideas were transmitted, with four key categories of idea: artistic, ideological, scholarly, and technological. The second looks at how transmission occurred, assessing four main mechanisms: diplomacy, migration, trade, and warfare. 

Previous scholarship notes an eastern Mediterranean ‘international age’ in the late second millennium BCE, but it has so far mostly focused on the Amarna Letters (14th century BCE), which span only a few decades of a millennia-long multicultural dialogue. Mesopotamian motifs exist in Egyptian art as early as 3100BCE, while Egypt’s ensuing commercial expansion towards Lebanon deepened international contacts. The second millennium BCE saw Egypt often fighting various Levantine peoples, its armies reaching the Euphrates and diplomatic relations extending to lands as 
diverse as Anatolia, Cyprus and Babylon. In various ways, this international outlook lasted until the Persian conquest. This project illuminates which ideas travelled, and how, in this enduring, interlinked world. 

The wide-ranging dataset encompasses both texts and objects, including written mentions of foreign ideas and people in Egyptian and cuneiform sources as well as material culture analysis, like the identification of foreign workmanship on ceramics and stelae. Public engagement will feature throughout, with project updates accessible through a YouTube channel, an online database and an overarching website. There will also be a dedicated ‘early multiculturalism’ resource for schools.
Funder: UKRI UK Research and Innovation UKRI

Project Title: Very preterm babies primary care needs (methods call)
Project Description:
The incidence of preterm birth in the UK is increasing and more infants, born more prematurely, are surviving to discharge home after specialist neonatal care. After hospital discharge, parents are advised that their GP should be their first port of call if they have any concerns about their baby’s health. However, little is known about healthcare seeking behaviours after neonatal discharge. Previous research has concentrated on readmissions to paediatric intensive care, but use of primary healthcare services, and hospital services other than intensive care, is poorly understood. There is also little contemporary UK evidence on parents’ healthcare needs and resource use after preterm birth. Our proposed study (to be conducted at the University of Nottingham) will address 3 broad aims:
1)	Identify a cohort of children (and their parents) born preterm who are registered in the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and establish the representativeness of this cohort in comparison to all preterm infants discharged home from neonatal care in England and Wales.
2)	Describe ex-preterm children’s medium and longer-term morbidity and healthcare resource use after discharge home from hospital and compare this to a cohort of healthy infants born at term.
3)	Describe morbidity and healthcare resource use in parents of preterm infants and compare this to parents of healthy infants born at term
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: The Antiplatelet therapy in spontaneous coronary artery dissection Trial (APT-SCAD Trial)
Project Description: BHF GCRFF Multinational Clinical Trial   -  Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) is an increasingly recognized condition where a dissection of the coronary artery by an intramural hematoma results in myocardial ischemia. Choice of treatment for these, mostly female, patients remains challenging since randomized trials in this disease entity are lacking. The mode of antiplatelet treatment (APT - single [SAPT] vs. dual antiplatelet therapy [DAPT]) and length of treatment is an area of controversy. Recent observations even suggest potential adverse effects of DAPT. From a pathophysiological point of view, prolonged bleeding time due to intensive APT could lead to propagation of the intramural hematoma accompanied by an increased rate of non-coronary bleeding. However, some clinical recommendations advocate the use of a more intensive DAPT strategy, which remains the most commonly utilized APT strategy despite the lack of evidence for benefit. We hypothesize that a moderate APT strategy using SAPT for 3 months followed by the cessation of any APT will be superior to an intensive APT regimen using 3 month DAPT followed by 9 months of SAPT on cardiovascular and bleeding events in conservatively managed SCAD patients. This trial will establish evidence for treatment in these patients, aiming to improve outcomes and reduce the global CVD burden.

Project Title: Autonomous Search And Rescue Intelligent Unmanned System (ASARIUS)
Project Description:
This industry-led project will bring together Sky Drones (UK lead), BT (UK), Oblivion Aerial (Switzerland) and University of Leicester together to work on enhancing navigation and control as well as connectivity for beyond visual line of sight (BVLOS) operation of drone missions.  University of Leicester will focus on the navigation and control methods and algorithms, including the obstacle avoidance challenges. BT will support the evaluation and development of methods and systems for enhanced connectivity for BVLOS operation.  Autonomous obstacle detection and avoidance will be possible by using  avionics platfroms and further enhancing AI and mission/navigation methods and software from Sky Drones to enhance the provision of services and applications such as aerial photography and search and rescue, which will be the focus of Swiss company Oblivion Aerial.

Drones autonomy and intelligence is a field where Sky Drones (the lead) is one of the leading companies in the UK and globally, having developed the Airlink for a multitude of drone platforms, currently considered to be the most advanced small UAV AI enabled civilian avionics platforms. Airlink stands for Artificial Intelligence & Remote Link. The unit includes a cutting-edge drone autopilot, AI mission computer and a 4G LTE or 5G connectivity unit. Support from BT will be important for the beyond line of sight  4G and 5G connectivity.

There will be opportunities for Sky Drones to evaluate the feasibility of autonomous path planning and following and obstacle avoidance algorithms, which can be done on their Airlink avionics platforms for example, with application to drone based aerial imaging, including search and rescue.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes:
This is an industry-led bid. Led by UK SME Sky-Drones.

Project Title: Specifically targeted smart synthetic antibody drug release system for a pre-clinical in-vivo mouse model of Diffuse Midline Gliomas (DMG)
Project Description: DMG is an extremely aggressive cancer, and surgical resection or chemotherapy are not possible for the most DMG. The reasons of failure are the deep embedment of cancer cells into the brain, and the challenge of delivering sufficient doses of chemotherapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Specific drug delivery using nanotechnology like synthetic antibodies to DMG is an extremely promising treatment approach. Our strategy will be based on polyamine-blocking therapy using difluoromethylornithine (DMFO) and polyamine transport inhibitor AMXT-1501, the well-known and the most promising therapy against DMG for preclinical applications.

Project Title: ChroNiC - Unlocking the potential for combined green recovery of Nickel from laterite ores and the permanent sequestration of CO2 and Chromium(VI)
Project Description:
Society relies on mining, especially for the critical metals required for clean energy technologies. These technologies will play a vital role in the mitigation of CO2 emissions and achieving global net zero carbon. Despite their international importance, mining and metal extraction still contribute significantly to the release of CO2 and potentially toxic elements and can have a negative impact on the environment and society. Nickel is an essential metal for lithium-ion batteries used in clean energy technologies and electric vehicles, and as a result nickel demand is forecast to double by 2050. However, nickel mining and extraction is associated with the release of hexavalent chromium, a carcinogenic pollutant made famous by the story of Erin Brockovich. Our challenge is therefore to urgently find ways to minimise the release of both hexavalent chromium and CO2 whilst mining and extracting the nickel we require.

Our project ChroNiC (representing chromium, nickel and carbon) brings together experts from across the disciplines of geoscience, sustainable resource extraction, and chemical and process engineering with world leading analytical facilities. We will take a cross-disciplinary approach to tackling environmental challenges associated with the mining of nickel. We aim to integrate our exciting recent research developments in the recovery of nickel using novel, environmentally benign solvents, with simultaneous removal, or sequestration, of both CO2 and hexavalent chromium into solid carbonate minerals so that they are safely stored. ChroNiC will achieve this through four objectives: 1). Utilise natural laboratories in Oman and the Philippines that offer unique opportunities to study how these pollutants have been naturally locked-up over geological time. 2). This knowledge will then be transferred into the laboratory, where we will accelerate the natural processes of mineral dissolution and crystallisation, ultimately aiming at the formation of chromium-bearing carbonate minerals, whilst simultaneously extracting the nickel in a low energy process. The successful delivery of ChroNiC will rely on the formation of carbonate minerals that are stable at the Earth surface and will not release the contaminants back to the biosphere. 3). We will thus, invest significant experimental and analytical effort to understand the underlying mechanisms behind carbonate formation from our environment-friendly solvents, and iteratively tailor the process to produce the best materials. 4). Finally, we will use experimental techniques to analyse and optimise the stability of these minerals to ensure that they will provide long-term sequestration of carbonate and chromium.

This is novel, cutting-edge, and adventurous science that will be underpinned by high resolution micro- and nano-scale data obtained from a globally unique experimental setup at the Diamond Synchrotron Light Source, developed by ChroNiC team members at the University of Leeds.  Collectively, we will provide whole system understanding of the potential for simultaneous recovery of nickel together with the sequestration of CO2 and hexavalent chromium, creating the foundations for a process that can be scaled up to industrial applications. ChroNiC will offer a transformative step-change in the science underpinning sustainable, carbon- and hexavalent chromium-neutral processing of nickel ores globally, thus leading to a cleaner safer future for society.
