Project Title: Aiden Smith NIHR Doctoral Research Fellowship Application
Project Description:
Aims of the Research: 

This project is looking at how information is used to predict how individuals may develop a given disease. These are known as "clinical prediction models" (CPMs). The objectives of the project are: 

O1. To see how poor data quality affects CPMs and to develop methods to address this. 

O2. To assess if CPMs used to inform clinical decisions are accurate and they work for everyone, including minority groups. 

O3. To see how disease risk using CPMs is affected if the person also has other health conditions – as these can affect both disease risk and survival.  

O4. To improve how personalized disease risk is communicated. An online webtool will be developed to enable the public to enter their own information and calculate their risk of developing bowel cancer, with a view to increasing uptake of the bowel cancer screening program. 

Background: 

CPMs are used by health professionals, particularly clinicians, to estimate the chance of a patient developing a given health problem. They help clinicians to decide on care/treatment options and resources needed for a given patient. It is important that estimates from CPMs are accurate and unbiased because: 

Inaccurate estimates can lead to incorrect treatment decisions, potentially causing harm to the patient. 

Valuable healthcare resources can be targeted where they are needed most. 

Unbiased estimates ensure fairness in healthcare. CPMs should not discriminate against certain groups, such as by ethnicity or socioeconomic groups.  

There are currently no clear guidelines for addressing data quality issues when developing CPMs such as missing data and they are not always tested to see if they work on different groups of individuals – such as different ethnic groups. This project will help to develop methods that will ensure accurate model estimates. It will also promote these methods widely; such that other researchers can produce high quality research to improve clinical practice.   

Methods: 

To achieve these objectives: 

M1. I will search published literature to identify current methods that address data quality issues. I will conduct a simulation study to identify the impact of different proportions of missing data on the model estimates.  

M2. I will develop methods to handle scenarios where missing data is different between the data the models are developed on and the data which the models are validated on. This will improve the use of the CPM for different populations or countries. 

M3.  I will investigate how pre-existing health conditions impact upon CPM estimates by defining an optimal lookback window for comorbidity inclusion, and whether sicker patients with more up to date information influence model outcomes.  

M4. Following the development of the CPM, I will quantify the impact that failing to consider varying mortality rates over time has on survival predictions.  

M5. I will develop a user-friendly webtool to provide personalized risk estimates for bowel cancer, and public facing materials to encourage uptake of bowel cancer screening in high-risk patient groups. 

Patient and Public Involvement (PPI): 

I have identified a PPI lead for the PPI advisory panel who has been involved in the development of this project and reviewing of this Plain English Summary. Existing PPI networks will help to recruit PPI panel members who will be utilized to ensure patient-focused outcomes throughout the project. The panels' experiences as patients and service users will continue to shape the direction of the project throughout. 

Dissemination: 

I will present my findings at international conferences and by publishing them in scientific journals. I will host a workshop upon completion of the project for researchers, clinicians and patients to attend. I also intend to create online resources that will be made available through social media networks.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: Are early life environments effects on ageing mediated by the epigenetic clock?
Project Description:
This project will help understand the proximate causes of life history evolution by establishing the effect of larval diapause on insect epigenetic ageing. This extends our discovery of epigenetics’s role in several insect life history traits (1). Why individuals and species age so differently is one of the biggest unanswered questions in evolutionary biology (2).
Environments can be variable and organisms can be selected to sense the state of their environ- ment early in life and to adaptively adjust their life history in response to these changes (3). The ability of one genotype to produce different life-histories depending on the environment is known as a life-history polyphenism (3). We ask could epigenetics and specifially the epigenetic clock be a proximate mechanism of these life-history polyphenisms.
An epigenetic clock is a biochemical test based on measuring the accumulation of chemical marks (DNA methylation) to DNA molecules (4). There is evidence epigenetic age mirrors true biological age and its associated morbidity and mortality better than chronological age (5). The rate at which an epigenetic clock ticks is strongly affected by the environment. This seems especially true in the early stages of life (6). This gives rise to the idea that an epigenetic clock can be developmentally tuned as part of an adaptive response to environmental variables experienced during development (6).
Aging is a complex process influenced by many environmental and genetic components. The effects of these components influence each other making them difficult to investigate, especially in complex mammalian models. Therefore, a large body of ageing research is based on simple model invertebrate organisms (7, 8). Advantages include easy and cheap to keep in a laboratory, short lifespan, genetic and molecular tools available, and a sequenced genome. However, the current invertebrate models of ageing (Drosophila (9) and C. elegans (10)) do not possess detectable DNA methylation, reducing their generality.
The jewel wasp, Nasonia vitripennis, an emerging model system (11) has a functional methylation system (12) making it an ideal system to investigate the epigenetics of ageing. We therefore mea- sured chronological ageing and changes in the epigenome using whole genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) in order to discover if Nasonia vitripennis possessed an epigenetic clock. The epigenetic age of each replicate is the weighted average of each genes’ methylation state. This epigenetic age does indeed correlate with chronological age (13). This is similar to results found in many vertebrates (6). However, this is the first time an epigenetic clock has been discovered in a tractable insect model.
An example of a life-history polyphenism in Nasonia is larval diapause, an overwintering stage where development is arrested and adult lifespan is increased (14). DNA methylation is involved in Nasonia diapause (15). Using published RNA-seq datasets (16), we have found an increase in the expression of DMNT1a (the enzyme responsible for DNA methylation maintenance) and a decrease in TET (the enzyme that removes methylation) in diapaused versus non-diapaused larvae. This suggests a maintenance of DNA methylation during diapause.

Project Title: A multidisciplinary approach to monitoring efficiency of cancer treatment using a novel tumour microenvironment multiparameter measurement system
Project Description: The vision of this multidisciplinary proposal is to create an innovative multiparameter measurement system for in vivo intra-tumoural monitoring of delivered drug and intra-tumoural recording of biomarkers of anti-tumour responses to treatment. The system is based on sensitive optical fibre sensors integrated with specific receptors (molecularly imprinted polymers – MIPs). The team combines expertise of world-leading groups in engineering, polymer chemistry and materials for solving major analytical problem of real time molecular monitoring of the tumour microenvironment. This will enable better understanding of drug delivery, response and resistance and so improve efficacy of the treatment by delivering personalised drug dosage, scheduling and timing.

Project Title: An implementation study to promote antimicrobial stewardship programs in oncology settings
Project Description:
Aims:
Antibacterial resistance (ABR) is a threat to cancer therapy success. Inappropriate antibiotic use is a major
risk factor for ABR and a common form of low-value healthcare in oncology settings. Though antimicrobial
stewardship (AMS) programs optimize antibiotic use, curb ABR and decrease healthcare costs, cancer
patients are often excluded. Hence, this project aims to describe, compare, and explain variations in AMS
program implementation in oncology settings and create an organizational toolkit to advance AMS program
implementation
Research methods
This is a multi-stage Type II Hybrid Implementation-Clinical effectiveness study using quantitative and
qualitative methods.
• Identify the evidence-practice gap
Patterns and trends of antibiotic use and ABR: Quarterly data on antibiotic use and ABR from oncology
departments at general hospitals and cancer hospitals covered by the Center for Antibacterial Surveillance
(CAS) and China Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (CARSS) (2013-2023) will be collected.
Antibiotic use and ABR will be described using defined daily doses per 100 patient-days and resistant
proportion, respectively. Trends will be assessed by linear regression.
AMS program implementation: A questionnaire will be designed based on a literature review and Delphi
expert consultations. Oncology departments at general hospitals and cancer hospitals in CAS and/or
CARSS will be surveyed.
• Excavate barriers and facilitators
Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research (CFIR) will be used to develop a semi-structure
interview guide to identify barriers and facilitators. Deductive and inductive content analyses will be
conducted on interview data. Guided by Normalization Process Theory, nominal group technique will be
conducted through a meeting to identify the seven most critical determinants for AMS program
implementation.
• Establish an organizational toolkit and verify the effectiveness
A focus group discussion will be organized to create the toolkit based on Capability-Opportunity-
Motivation Behavior model and CFIR-ERIC (Expert Recommendations for Implementing Change)
Implementation Strategy Matching Tool. A quais-experimental multicenter study will be conducted over
24 months with an intervention period of 12 months. The RE-AIM Framework will guide the evaluation,
with interrupted time-series regression analysis used for comparison before and after the intervention.
Expected outcomes:
This study is expected to generate high-quality evidence to advance AMS program implementation in oncology
settings by leveraging implementation science. At least three high-impact papers and a report providing
evidence-based recommendations for policy making are expected.
Potential implications:
This project could accelerate optimal AMS program implementation in oncology settings, improve appropriate
antibiotic use in cancer patients, and promote the achievement of the goal of Global Action Plan on ABR.

Project Description:

•	Which multisystemic factors enable or constrain resilience to mental ill health for children and adolescents experiencing health inequalities resulting from forced migration or slavery? If you agree I will consult with CAMHS and the literature to establish the most frequently occurring – my gut instinct is that it will be depression for all of the obvious reasons).
•	Which combination of resources, at which level (individual, family, community, build/natural environment) have been most impactful in mitigating against mental ill health for children and adolescents experiencing health inequalities resulting from forced migration or slavery?

Project Title: Information Operations Research Capability in the Home Office Disinformation Analysis Team
Project Description:
Background
 
The Home Office’s Disinformation Analysis Team (DAT) leads government’s work to understand the domestic national security implications of disinformation and other forms of information operation. It delivers this work through a hybrid insight model combining an expert internal open-source investigative capability with partnership working with expert external research teams from across a range of disciplines such as open source and social media analysis; data and internet sciences; and, audience research, including primary work in UK communities.
 
Purpose 
 
The purpose of this event will be to;
 
•	Inform suppliers of DAT’s external research and analysis requirement
•	Help define the requirement
•	Help provide a better understanding of the feasibility of the requirement
•	Understand the best approach
•	Understand the capacity of the market to deliver and possible risks involved
and 
•	Provide the market with an opportunity to ask questions, raise queries and any issues to be addressed at an early stage
 
The Requirement
 
The requirement is for a research and insight service into information operations targeting the UK. The key outputs for the service are:
 
•	Online Media Monitoring Service: Analysing the open-source information environment at scale to inform a weekly report.
•	Deep Dive Reporting: Longer form research projects into actors, platforms and issues of interest.
•	Surge Capacity: A capability to provide ad hoc, time-sensitive open-source investigative reporting within 24 hours of a commission
•	Research: Design and conduct primary research into both emerging and novel issues relating to information operations.
 
We are considering a contract with a two-year length extendable for up to two further years to make a maximum of four in total. 
 
The expected contract value will be in the region of £2M per annum. This is the maximum value, with an expectation that the actual cost will be lower.
 
The Event
 
The event will be held virtually on Tuesday 25th July 2023 at 10.00am.
 
You have been selected as a potentially suitable supplier from the CCS DPS Framework RM6126 Research and Insights.
 
How to Attend
 
If you wish to attend the supplier event you will need to sign the attached Non Disclosure Agreement (NDA) and return this by 4pm on Thursday 20th July confirming names of attendees and one email address for your meeting invite to be sent to.
 
After you have signed the NDA for your organisation and confirmed attendance you will be sent a link to join the Microsoft Teams call.
Signing the NDA is compulsory to join the supplier event.
 
If you do not wish to attend or the requirement is not of interest please reply and say either “NOT ATTENDING” or “NOT OF INTEREST” in your reply.
 
Please issue all correspondence via the mailbox for this requirement which is HOSProcurement@homeoffice.gov.uk 
 
Further engagement
 
We are considering offering one-to-one sessions to further inform our requirements. The one-to-one sessions are not compulsory and attendance will not provide an advantage or disadvantage to any tender that may subsequently be held. If held, these will be on a first come first served basis and will be used by the Home Office to refine our requirements.
 
Statements
 
You do not have to attend this event to submit a tender and you do not have to attend this event if this requirement is not of interest.
 
By holding this market engagement event the Home Office is not committing to run a tender.
 
Tendering
 
Once market engagement activities have concluded, any tender activity will be conducted using Jaggaer, the Home Office e-sourcing tendering platform and managed by the Home Office.
 
Kind regards
 
Tina Smith
 
Tina Smith MCIPS
Commercial Manager
Homeland Security Commercial Team
Commercial Directorate | Corporate and Delivery | Home Office
 
2 Marsham Street | London SW1P 4DF
 
 
 
OFFICIAL

Project Title: Understanding how Integrated Care Boards implement patient choice and monitor inequalities in elective treatment in order to improve patient utilisation and access equality
Project Description:
The Health and Care Act 2022 brought about some fundamental changes to how the NHS is organised in England. The 106 Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) were dissolved in July 2022 and replaced with 42 Integrated Care Systems comprised of Integrated Care Boards (ICBs) and Integrated Care Partnerships. Since July 2022, ICBs have had the statutory responsibility to plan and fund most NHS services in the area covered by the ICS. ICBs have statutory duties under the 2022 Act to “act with a view to enabling patients to make choices with respect to aspects of health services provided to them” and to “reduce inequalities between persons with respect to their ability to access health services”. 

Since 2002 in England, patient choice has been inextricably linked to market reforms with a large increase in the role of the private sector to deliver NHS funded care. Patient choice of provider combined with payment by results and practice-based commissioning has created a market driven competitive environment in the NHS with choice linked to encouraging competition between providers. Research by members of this team has found that waiting times for those living in the most deprived areas of England improved relative to patients in the least deprived areas between 1997 and 2002 but then worsened thereafter.

Scotland however had the opposite experience with worsening inequality to the detriment of patients in the most deprived areas prior to 2002 but a decrease in levels of inequality between 2002 and 2010. The obvious difference between the two countries was the way they implemented competition and provider choice since 2002 and the way they used the private sector to provide NHS funded treatment. Patient choice can exist independently of provider competition and the operationalising of patient choice of provider was very different in England than in Scotland. Scotland has had a much more limited form of patient choice with no internal market or national system to facilitate choice.

This research will investigate how ICBs are planning to meet their duties under the Health and Care Act 2022 with regards to patient choice and equity of access.  A mixed-method study design will be employed including analysing routinely available data, surveying ICBs and conducting qualitative research among key stakeholders. Elective primary hip and knee replacement will be used to analyse inequality. Hip and knee replacements are high volume NHS funded procedures which since 2002 have increasingly been performed in ISTCs and other private hospitals as NHS funded procedures.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: Creative collaborations to investigate and address health disparities in Leicester
Project Description:
Leicester is the country’s most diverse city and one of the first to have minority majorities. The Centre for Ethnic Health Research (CEHR) and Leicester Diabetes Centre (LDC) are instrumental in highlighting ethnic health disparities in the city and have a strong record of co-creating initiatives to reduce health inequalities, engaging underserved communities using innovative methods that harness social capital.  The University of Leicester’s Heritage Hub is a pioneering initiative, working with civic partners and communities to facilitate cross-disciplinary and cross-sector collaborations, investigating and reducing barriers to participation and ensuring people’s heritage is recognised and celebrated.
This project brings together researchers from the Heritage Hub, CEHR and LDC to form a multi-disciplinary team of academics working across health, social sciences, humanities, arts and environmental sciences.  The team will work directly and equitably with underserved community members, community leaders, public health and social care providers, teams managing community assets, public and third-sector providers of diverse arts, culture and heritage programmes across the city as well as the NHS integrated care board. 
The project encompasses over 30 public sector community-based facilities including faith centres, museums and galleries, green spaces, and university, NHS and community venues including local pharmacies. It will audit and evaluate collective infrastructure, programmes and expertise, mapping the current care systems and pathways, and investigating the barriers and facilitators to engagement with community assets and community health and wellbeing initiatives. It will develop integrated, strategic and replicable approaches to understanding complex intersecting inequalities and proactively and creatively address these through collaborative working.
Name of Call: Collaborative community research to tackle health inequalities
Co-Investigator(s): John Maltby (JM148),Gregory Maniatopoulos (GM369),Gemma Hughes (GH218),Kamlesh Khunti (KK22),Martin Phillips (MPP2),Nuala Morse (NMM15)

Project Title: Proposal for collaboration: Identifying gaps in drowning data collection in low- and middle-income countries (LMIC) and the actors addressing them
Project Description:
1.	Conduct a review of how drowning data has been collected in LMIC settings, identifying both the opportunities and challenges of the processes employed. This would be based on case studies from Bangladesh, Thailand, Vietnam, South Africa, and Uganda. Where possible, the review would include a comparison of the data collection tools used and the minimum parameters collected.
2.	Conduct a review of organisations or individuals whose work has identified challenges and opportunities in using verbal autopsy to collect context specific risk factors for injury deaths in LMIC settings. 
3.	Develop a proposal to produce the minimum dataset and collection guidance required to improve data collection on risk factors for drowning deaths in LMICs.

Project Title: Genetic and molecular evolution of insect audition
Project Description: This grant will understand how specialised auditory organs “ears” evolved in insects. Insects have evolved a variety of unique ear types at least 19 separate times. Firstly, we wish to understand if insects solved the problem of sensitive hearing in the same or different ways. Insects’ ears evolved from “proprioceptive” organs that detect leg joint angles and are essential for locomotion. Secondly, we wish to understand the specialisations of the proprioceptive organs as they evolved into dedicated auditory organs. We will use state-of-the-art genetic techniques to isolate gene expression patterns in each type of cell in proprioceptive and auditory organs.
Funder: THE LEVERHULME TRUST The Leverhulme Trust

Project Title: Advanced Multidisciplinary Research for Antimicrobial Resistance
Project Description: We are proposing a 4-year program of knowledge transfer and networking between academic institutions [University of Leicester (UK), University of Valencia (Spain), International Iberian Nanotechnology Lab (Portugal), University of Bologna (Italy), University of Aveiro (Portugal), Fudan University (China), and Alfred University (USA)] and industrial partners [Teer Coatings Ltd (UK)].  The objective of the proposed joint exchange programme is to establish long-term stable research cooperation between the partners with interdisciplinary expertise and knowledge to develop Advanced Multidisciplinary Research for Antimicrobial Resistance (AMRAMR), including the development of novel antibacterial nanomaterials and nanostrucutres, novel antibacterial thin films coatings, upconversion technology for AMR applications, photonics technology for AMR application, and evaluation of the antibacterial performance and antimicrobial resistance; the synergetic effect for the above approaches to understanding antimicrobial resistance.

Project Title: Magnetic fields in cosmic explosions
Project Description: Gamma-ray bursts signal the birth of a neutron star or black hole, which power immensely luminous, short-lived transient events seen throughout our Universe. This luminosity is likely created at shock fronts within a high-speed, narrowly jetted outflow. Both the emission mechanism and the jet composition are unknown, holding back progress in understanding our variable night sky. Taking advantage of new observational capabilities, combining rapid-response low-frequency radio imaging with X-ray observations from space, I will observe and model these catastrophic events, revealing what drives their jets and what happens at the shock fronts to produce the light that we see.

Project Title: Model Transformation Language Tutorial(s)
Project Description:
Model transformation languages (MTLs) are a crucial aspect of Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) and hold great significance in the broader field of software engineering. MTLs enable the systematic manipulation and conversion of models, which are representations of the system's architecture, behavior, and requirements. In essence, they serve as a bridge between different models, facilitating seamless integration and providing a foundation for model-based development.

In the context of MDE, model transformations play a vital role in generating code, refining models, synchronizing different models, and performing validation and verification tasks. Consequently, MTLs are indispensable for leveraging the full potential of MDE practices, which ultimately contribute to reduced development costs, increased productivity, and enhanced software quality.

However, despite their importance, MTLs like YAMTL and ETL often suffer from a lack of comprehensive documentation. Insufficient learning resources can hinder the adoption of MTLs and limit their effectiveness in real-world software engineering projects. To address this issue, it is essential to improve learning resources and develop comprehensive, accessible materials that demonstrate the power and versatility of these languages.

By preparing educational resources for YAMTL and ETL, we will support a growing platform at KCL dedicated to showcasing these tools. The project's objectives include:

Learning YAMTL and ETL: Although the documentation for these research MTLs varies from scarce to moderately available, it is crucial to become proficient in them to develop high-quality educational resources.
Developing resources for three levels of transformation complexity: To cater to a broad audience, we will create resources for an introductory example, an example showcasing MTL features, and a real-world example with higher complexity.
Creating a static web page: Using a static web generator, we will build a well-organized and easily accessible documentation page that offers a user-friendly experience.
Organizing resources for integration with the education platform: To ensure seamless integration with the KCL platform, the resources will be structured in a way that enables easy access and incorporation into the platform.
Over the course of 10 weeks (likely to be after the exams in May), this full-time project will not only improve the visibility and adoption of YAMTL and ETL but also empower software engineers and students to leverage these powerful MTLs more effectively. By investing in better learning resources, we can unlock the full potential of MDE and make a meaningful impact on the software engineering landscape.

This is a collaboration with colleagues from the University of York and the University of Ulm to develop open-source learning resources on MDE technologies. The project aims to create a repository of learning materials focused on model transformations, which will be used to contribute to an education platform on MDE being developed at KCL in collaboration with Leicester and York. We plan to use YAMTL, a tool developed at Leicester that is attracting international attention in the MDE community, as well as other tools developed at York.

My colleagues and I are interested in this project for the following reasons:

Firstly, by developing open-source learning resources focused on model transformations in MDE, this collaboration can contribute to the wider dissemination of knowledge in this field. This may lead to increased use of MDE technologies, including those developed at Leicester, by industry and academia, improving the efficiency and effectiveness of software development. This could lead to future collaborations with industry partners, resulting in further research impact.
Secondly, disseminating these resources via the EPSRC network MDENet has the potential to enhance the visibility of Leicester and its MDE technologies, both in the UK and internationally. This could lead to further collaborations with other universities and industry partners, resulting in new research projects and the development of new MDE technologies.
These collaborations could result in increased citation rates of Leicester's research publications, which may improve the institution's research ranking and funding opportunities. The open-source nature of the learning resources also means that they can be used and adapted by other researchers, potentially leading to new publications and collaborations.
Open Call, but next deadline/panel meeting for applications is 31/05/23

Project Title: Early  treatment  of  Atrial  fibrillation  for  Stroke  prevention Trial in acute STROKE (EAST-STROKE
Project Description: EAST-STROKE is an investigator-initiated, prospective, randomized, open, blinded endpoint assessment (PROBE)interventional multicentre trial to test whether rhythm control treatment effectively prevents recurrent stroke and major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in patients with a recent (<4 weeks) ischemic stroke. This proposal tackles three highly prevalent conditions related to circulatory health: atrial fibrillation (AF), stroke, and cardiovascular disease (e.g., myocardial infarction, heart failure), and aligns with CIHR-ICRH goals.  Compared to other stroke etiologies, AF-related strokes are among the most severe, are associated with large-volume brain infarcts, generate severe disability, and have higher mortality, and short- and long-term recurrence rates. The annual cost of stroke is $ 3.6 billion in Canada.14 AF-related strokes generate 50%higher direct acute care costs than non-AF-related strokes. One in every nine first-ever ischemic stroke patients without known cardiovascular comorbidities experience a MACE in the first year post-stroke.  AF is a strong and consistent marker of MACE risk. Furthermore, ischemic stroke patients with pre-existing AF have a particularly high risk of experiencing other cardiovascular complications. Total yearly costs of patients who experience an incident MACE are threefold higher than patients who do not have cardiovascular complications. Stroke and MACE in AF patients are a significant clinical problem that is only partly solved with anticoagulation. Given the suboptimal recurrent stroke and MACE prevention performance of oral anticoagulants in stroke patients, new strategies are needed. Based on the results of the EAST-AFNET 4 trial in patients with AF (Kirchhof, N Engl J Med 2020; 383:1305-1316)rhythm control therapy is a promising and novel approach that can potentially reduce stroke recurrence and MACE in stroke patients. Rhythm control therapy is a current standard of care for patients with AF but has not yet been adopted for stroke patients because of the lack of specific evidence for this population. If the results of EAST-STROKE show that rhythm control therapy can prevent recurrent stroke and MACE, millions of patients with AF and stroke worldwide will have a new therapeutic option to reduce the residual risk of major cardiovascular events.

Project Title: Early Atrial Fibrillation Ablation For Stroke Prevention In Patients With high Comorbidity Burden. The EASThigh-AFNET 11 trial
Project Description: The EASThigh-AFNET 11 trial is an investigator-driven, prospective, parallel-group, randomised, open, blinded outcome assessment (PROBE), multi-centre, superiority study with two groups with 1:1 randomisation (Theray Strategy Trial) evaluating the effectiveness and safety of early AF ablation in patients with recently diagnosed AF and a high comorbidity burden compared to usual care. All therapies and procedures (first-line AF ablation or usual care) are approved and will be applied in their clinical indications. EASThigh-AFNET 11 will be conducted in several countries in Europe, Canada and Australia. The study is event-driven with a planned number of randomised and treated patients of n=2318 and a fixed number of primary endpoint events (n=527) to be observed for testing superiority. Study patients will be randomized to one of two parallel therapy strategy in a 1:1 ratio, designated as “Early AF Ablation” and “Usual Care” group. Randomisation will be done as stratified per study site in blocks of variable size to minimise selection bias. We expect a recruitment phase of 36 months and a median follow-up period of 44 months. All patients will be followed up until global end of the study.

Project Title: Sophie Frost FLF - Hidden Digital Labour?    Exploring the role and impact of technology on the future of cultural work
Project Description:
Digital labour is an underexplored phenomenon across the non-profit arts and cultural sectors both in the UK and internationally, with little attention placed on how emerging practices of digital labour are impacting lived experiences of cultural work, nor how they are irreversibly changing future cultural employment. Further, there is little known about the distinctive nature of digital labour in different artform contexts. 

Over 7 years, this project presents a multi-layered research plan, combining a programme of independent research in diverse cultural environments, innovative academic collaboration, the forging of a new, public-facing network of critical thinkers from different sectors, partnership working with the USA, and planned development opportunities. It seeks to position the researcher as an established leader on sustainable, equitable, and empathetic digital labour practices in our national and international cultural sectors. 

Embedded within the Institute for Digital Culture at the University of Leicester (UK) and jointly mentored by two leading academics from the fields of Digital Heritage and Employment Studies, this project proposes to establish a novel set of research partnerships to provide a richer perspective on the phenomenon in question.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes: The Fellow and Applicant is Dr Sophie Frost - Honorary Research Fellow in the Institute for Digital Culture.

Project Title: Mapping ancient Egypt: the relationship between Egyptology and cartography
Project Description: My project will provide the first analysis of the relationship between the disciplinary traditions of Egyptology and cartography, 1740-1939: from topographical antiquarianism to excavation. Currently, maps produced by Egyptologists are viewed simply as straightforward reflections of regions at a particular time, and are virtually never contextualised. Recent work on visual culture has shown that maps were often manipulated for political purposes, notably for imperial ambitions. My project will show how western knowledge production in proto-colonial and colonial settings was not neutral and demonstrated similar techniques of selectivity, even whilst it was posited as an objective method for catalysing disciplinary formation

Project Title: Big Data and the Roman Dead: Archaeological Explorations around Age and Agency
Project Description:
This project identifies who created public responses to the Roman Empire in Northern European communities
BCE 250–400 CE. The research builds on the current big-data moment in Archaeology by bringing together
methodologies from demography and identity studies to deepen and improve our understanding of societies along
the Empire’s northernmost frontier. Critical aspects of the now-available information, namely, the ages of corpses
in cemeteries, their delineation within that space, and the commemoration of age in other, related contexts, can
show how societies reacted to long-term occupation, and shed innovative new light on group agency and the
expression of different life-stages.

Project Title: Experimental Tests of Rational Decision Making
Project Description: Rational decision making under risk/uncertainty and over time is central to economic analysis, and it is natural that experimentalists should want to test both (older) mainstream and (newer) behavioural models of choice within these contexts. Generally speaking, many experiments to-date have collected a relatively small number of decisions from each subject, with these problems somewhat narrowly tailored to refute particular theories (or components of those theories). The emphasis in our research is to present subjects with problems that are representative (in a statistical and economic sense) in order to provide a better positive account of preferences. In order to do this, we develop tests which are (a) comprehensive (in the sense that they apply to each model taken as a whole) and (b) nonparametric (in the sense that they avoid making auxiliary functional form assumptions). We then apply our tests to rich individual-level data which are amenable to statistical analysis.

Project Title: DevelopmEnt of Seaweed-based biofuels To aId eNergy trAnsiTION
Project Description:
DESTINATION will be centred around a 500-square meter test farm, located in the Freeport of Saldanha, South Africa, in which pond-based farming of salt water seaweed is combined with anaerobic digestion, optimised for circularity of the separate processes to minimise process energy demand and maximise nutrient recovery. This programme will be supported by research and development in the UK and Cape Town, by improving components of the test farm and evaluating lifecycles as global potential.

The operation of the test farm itself will directly create 3 permanent jobs in a vulnerable community of colour, with the job specs being designed to ascertain equitable opportunity, for women, youth and people caring for others. 

A successful conclusion of the project will unlock investment into a full scale application of the project, in the West Coast of South Africa, which suffers from severe unemployment in disenfranchised fishing communities of colour, creating in excess of 1000 jobs per full scale plant.

Whilst algae to fuel is being tried in many variations, this is the only project we identified were seaweed is farmed to produce fuels, via anaerobic digestion in a circular fashion, rather than trying to extract lipids from micro algae or anaerobic digestion of beach cast seaweed, both of which struggling to reach profitability.

At 'DESTINATION' shore based raceway ponds – or paddlewheel ponds- are used to farm ulva armoricana (sea lettuce) as feedstock for a continuous mixing anaerobic digester, producing biogas. Whilst the amounts of biogas that DESTINATION will produce will be small, they will serve to analyse the gas for composition and its potential to be split into CH4 and CO2, whereas the CH4 will be liquefied and used as shipping fuel and the CO2 will be used in the food and beverage industry at first and eventually enable the emerging green hydrogen industry to lengthen the value chain, by synthesising GH2 with the CO2 in a Fisher-Tropsch to produce e-enhanced biomehtanol or sustainable aviation fuels.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes: TECHNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS LTD. (Lead)

Project Title: Design and test of galactose analogues to treat pneumococcal infections
Project Description:
Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus, Spn) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, responsible for an estimated with estimations of ~1.2 million deaths and ~197 million episodes of pneumococcal pneumonia annually, and one of the commonest agents of meningitis. The critical need to develop anti-Spn therapies is complicated by two key factors. First, the emergence of multi-drug resistant (MDR) strains, resulting in Spn’s inclusion on the WHO priority pathogens list for R&D of new antibiotics. Second, in chronic infections, Spn adopts a biofilm mode of growth that is recalcitrant to antibiotics and can exhibit minimal inhibitory concentrations (MICS) 10-100 fold higher than the same strain in planktonic mode of growth. Existing antibiotics impede a narrow set of cellular processes: DNA replication, protein synthesis, and cell wall biosynthesis. With the global increase in drug resistance, there is an enormous interest in the investigation of alternate essential cellular processes, including bacterial central metabolic pathways, as a future drug target.
The development of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has made treatment of these infections increasingly difficult, resulting in the inclusion of pneumococcus on the WHO priority pathogens list for R&D of new antibiotics. Furthermore, despite the introduction of vaccines there is continued circulation of vaccine serotypes and increased invasive disease caused by non-vaccine serotypes.  There is therefore an urgent need for the development of new treatments for pneumococcal disease and to reduce the development of AMR . Research carried out by our groups has shown that galactose, the predominant carbohydrate in the respiratory tract, is essential for pneumococcal survival in host and regulation of its virulence. We also show that galactose metabolism can be selectively targeted. Here we propose to develop antiinfectives Targeting targeting pneumococcal galactose metabolism therefore represents an attractive target for the development of novel therapeutics, and an innovative strategy for targeting bacterial infection.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C

Project Title: Targeting the hearing loss following bacterial meningitis with toxin inhibitors
Project Description:
Objective
We will test four recently identified low-molecular weight inhibitors of the pneumococcal toxin, pneumolysin, for efficacy in prevention of pneumococcal-induced hearing loss. Two are pro-drugs and two are the active components of the pro-drugs.

Background
Permanent loss of hearing is a frequent long-term pathological consequence for survivors of meningitis due to Streptococcus pneumoniae [1]. Many studies have shown that the cochlear hair cells and the spiral ganglion neurons are damaged [see2]. Various pneumococcal factors may contribute to its virulence, but overwhelmingly the evidence points to pneumolysin being the cause of the hearing loss. For example, many in vivo and ex vivo experiments show that damage is abolished in infection with mutated pneumococci that lack the ply gene [see2]. 
Pneumolysin is produced by virtually all strains in the cytoplasm but is released when the bacterium lyses naturally, or under the effect of lytic antibiotics, when a large bolus of toxin is released. Thus, even if antibiotics successfully clear the bacteria, the release of the toxin occurs and can cause long-term consequences. The impact of pneumolysin can be its direct toxicity to host cells and indirectly by inducing a vigorous host inflammatory response [3,4]. In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that: inhibition of the toxin would protect from the bacterial and host mediated hearing loss. 
To improve prognosis, adjunctive therapy has been used to support antimicrobial therapy. However, so far use of adjunctives has sought to reduce morbidity by reducing host inflammatory responses rather than by combating direct toxicity. The most common current adjunctive is dexamethasone but even when used, significant mortality and morbidity is seen, and its use is debated due to non-specific effects limiting clinical impact and, in some cases, increasing neuronal apoptosis [5,6].
Twin platforms for combatting any bacterial infectious disease are vaccination and treatment and both must be employed to maximise protection. Nevertheless, there are some that advocate that new treatments for pneumococcal diseases are not necessary because vaccines will solve the problems. This is mis-guided. Even though the new conjugate vaccines have shown success in some circumstances, two huge problems with a vaccine-only approach are the occurrence of over ninety pneumococcal serotypes (the best new vaccines only target thirteen), plus the phenomenon of serotype replacement within pneumococci. These factors prevent reliable prediction of the wider impact of conjugate vaccines [7].
Data on the impact of conjugate vaccines on hearing loss in England and Wales are lacking but a recent study of children [8] found that pneumococcal vaccination reduced the incidence of invasive pneumococcal disease but death still occurred in 4.8% but, significantly, most of the deaths were due to pneumococcal serotypes not covered in the vaccines. Data from the USA [9] showed a decrease (72%) in meningitis by serotypes covered by the conjugate vaccine but a rise (46%) in disease by non-vaccine serotypes. Hearing loss was documented in 29% of the children, but there was no significant difference in the proportion of children who developed sequelae according to immunisation status. A later study [10] found that pneumococcal meningitis did not change after the PCV13 replaced PCV7, and there were no significant differences in complications or death. The authors also found similar sequelae rates among survivors of PCV13 and non-PCV13 meningitis.
The weight of evidence for the importance of pneumolysin in hearing loss led us to the conclusion that pneumolysin constitutes a potential new therapeutic target. Previous research showed the ability of cholesterol to inhibit pneumolysin, but this is merely due to the fact that cholesterol is a natural cellular receptor of pneumolysin, that is important for the pore formation in the target cell membrane. Cholesterol is not considered as a therapy for pneumococcal diseases and has not been clinically used in patients. Another compound, allicin, has been reported to inhibit pneumolysin haemolytic activity in vitro but it is a cysteine inhibitor. Compounds exhibiting such a property are unfavourable as drug candidates because of their potential off-target effects. In an original take on this issue, we surmised that a better approach was to identify low-molecular weight, non-thiol dependent, pneumolysin inhibitors with classical drug-like properties. 
We envisaged that the drug would be given as an adjunctive simultaneously with the first doses of antibiotics. Discovery of a drug with a good safety profile, and because of the frequency of the pneumococcus as the cause of bacterial meningitis, would be compatible with empirical administration. Consequently, we undertook research to develop such a product. Using our high-throughput assay and a set of well-established in vitro, ex vivo and in vitro assays, we screened 250,000 compounds and identified five leads that inhibited toxin activity in vivo and in vitro. Then we undertook a medicinal chemistry programme to optimise pneumolysin-inhibiting lead compounds in which over 900 derivatives of the leads were synthesised to optimise their physicochemical properties, key absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion (ADME) properties, in vivo pharmacokinetics (PK) properties and maximise the in vivo potency (PD) of derivatives. The synthesised compounds were tested in a cascade of in vitro, ex vivo and in vivo assays. In the mouse and rat, these preclinical candidates have strong biological efficacy (IC50 0.15µM in vitro and in vivo), favourable ADME and safety profile, attractive physicochemical properties compatible with parenteral formulation and are amenable to large scale production.

Project Title: Contrast-free evaluation of scarring within the heart using cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging
Project Description:
Heart disease costs the NHS over £9billion annually.  Each year, over 100,000 people suffer a heart attack, resulting in permanent scarring of their heart. Survivors are at increased risk of sudden death or developing heart failure, a debilitating condition. Currently, doctors do not have very good tools to predict who will and will not develop complications.   

Pictures of ‘scarring’ within the heart can be obtained using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), after giving patients a ‘dye’ (a gadolinium compound). This provides an accurate method to identify even small heart attacks. However, giving this dye adds cost, and it is not safe in some people (with advanced kidney disease or allergic reactions); its long-term effects are also currently unknown. Moving ‘cine’ images of the heart are routinely acquired, and do not require any dye to be given. Hence, it would be advantageous to use these dye-free images to identify scar. This project aims to develop and test a fully automatic computer program using artificial intelligence (AI) to ‘convert’ the dye-free images into scar images. Hence, a new method to identify scarring within the heart will be developed and validated.

Project Title: Regulation of the X chromosome in pluripotency, development and disease
Project Description:
Successful development requires a unique regulation of gene expression on the X chromosome due to the different number of X chromosomes between males and females. In placental mammals, X chromosome dosage compensation occurs by X chromosome inactivation (XCI), which transcriptionally silences most genes on one of the two X chromosomes in females and thereby equalizes X-linked gene expression with XY males. The silenced state of the inactive X (Xi) will be remembered by daughter cells and play a crucial role in cell physiology. Its dysregulation is involved in over 500 X-linked diseases including immune diseases, cancer and during ageing. In the blastocyst, the long non-coding RNA XIST is expressed from one of the two active X chromosomes to trigger and mediate XCI. XIST functions by recruiting dozens of effectors proteins. In the mouse, I recently showed that XIST functions by seeding large macromolecular assemblies of silencing proteins. I also revealed that perturbations in protein-protein interactions within XIST assemblies leads to partial or complete X chromosome reactivation (XCR). 

hPSCs are critical to cell therapies and modelling gene regulation in early human embryonic development, which is vital to understanding what is required for a healthy pregnancy. Naïve and primed hPSCs, correspond to the pluripotency states of pre- and post-implantation epiblasts. XCI is essential to cell identity and physiology and the epigenetic instability of the Xi in female human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), owing to partial XCR occurring with prolonged culturing, generates a huge obstacle for their applicability in regenerative medicine. The formation, composition and regulation of XIST assemblies in hPSCs and what are the differences between naïve and primed hPSCs remain unknown. Furthermore, we still lack knowledge on how we can completely reprogram primed to naïve hPSCs to revert XIST expression and reactivate a wild-type X chromosome in diseases where a mutant X is active, for example in the Rett syndrome.

Project Title: HWO-EES: Habitable Worlds Observatory - Early Engagement Support
Project Description: The Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) has been selected by NASA as its next flagship space astronomy mission, following on from Hubble, Webb and Rubin telescopes. A principal scientific goal of HWO is to search for Earth-like planets in nearby interstellar space (within a few 10s of parsecs) and characterise their surfaces and/or atmospheres through direct spectroscopic observations in the search for evidence of life processes. This programme will answer the question “Are We Alone?”, one of the most exciting and fundamental in modern science. If no direct evidence for life is found, by surveying a sufficiently large population of objects, it will be possible to provide important and interesting constraints on the presence of life in the Galaxy. Like Hubble and Webb, HWO will also be a general-purpose observatory able to provide revolutionary capability in many areas of astrophysics and planetary science. As with Hubble and Webb before, the timescale for development, build and launch of HWO is measured in decades, with an expected launch in the early 2040s (although it is hoped to accelerate work to bring this forward). HWO is currently planned to be a 6-m aperture UVOIR telescope. Detailed design of the mission, examination of its science goals and development of instrumentation is beginning now, with key meetings already organised this year.

Project Title: Matching Skills: Capabilities, Organisations And Institutions
Project Description: he Skills2Capability project is about understanding how skill systems across Europe can reduce the level of skills mismatch in their labour markets. It is recognised that future labour markets will be more mobile with more people moving between jobs, employers, and sectors more often. This poses a problem for training systems insofar as employers may be much less willing than in the past to fund and provide training because their chances of appropriating the return will have been reduced. The study is concerned with understanding how skill systems can better respond to meeting skill demands in a more fluid labour market environment. The starting point is that of considering whether there is a need to provide individuals with a wider range of capabilities to weather a greater range of labour market challenges than those faced by their counterparts from previous generations. Some countries have been able to use their skills systems to deliver more of these capabilities than others, though the impact of this on labour market transitions is uncertain (something the current study addresses). If skills systems are to confer skills on individuals which provide them with increased resilience and capability, then there is a need to know what those capabilities or skills are in practice. The research addresses this from both a demand side (what are the skills which are currently in demand and are likely to be so in the future?) and a supply side (to what extent are these capabilities reflected in VET programmes) perspective. The research will provide decision makers in government and education authorities with information which allows them to obtain a better understanding of how emerging skill needs - which meet the needs of both economy and society - can be met (essentially providing a methodology and a tool), along with detailed information about the content of those emerging skill needs and capabilities (i.e. detailed data on demand and supply).
Funder: EPSRC HEG EPSRC - Horizon Europe Guarantee

Project Title: Partnership Agreement with The Office for National Statistics (ONS)
Project Description:
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) and the University of Leicester (UoL) have established strong collaborative links during the COVID-19 pandemic. These collaborations have led to numerous high impact academic outputs that have impacted UK policy and the wider Government response to the COVID-19 pandemic. 
Examples of policy impacts include targeted vaccination campaigns due to evidencing that minority ethnic groups report lower vaccination uptake. These policy driven outputs were instrumental in advancing our understanding of the pandemic's impact on health and wellbeing.
In March 2023, the University of Leicester approached the Office for National Statistics with a proposal to expand the existing collaboration beyond the pandemic through a formal partnership agreement. This would allow both parties to leverage their respective strengths in public health research and data analysis to tackle a range of pressing health challenges, contributing significantly to health and social care research in the UK.

Project Title: MS3: AI based Microsatellite Stability Screening of Colorectal and Endometrial Cancers
Project Description:
In the UK, the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) and Royal College of Pathologists (RCPath) guidelines mandate that all colorectal cancer (CRC) and endometrial cancer (EC) samples must be tested for deficient Mismatch Repair (dMMR) system in order to detect Lynch Syndrom (LS), a genetic disorder that puts patients and their relatives at high risk of developing other cancers, and to provide prognostically useful information and key data that may be used to guide therapy for sporadic CRC and EC patients that have Microsatellite Instability (MSI). Similarly, the European ESMO guidelines and the CAP guidelines in the USA mandate MSI testing for CRCs and ECs. The current Standard of Care (SoC) for dMMR/MSI testing of all CRC and EC tumours involves performing either immunohistochemistry (IHC) with 4 antibodies against the mismatch repair proteins MLH1, MSH2, MSH6 and PMS2 (MMR-IHC) or molecular pathology testing by PCR amplification of a panel of microsatellite markers (PCRMSI) in tumour DNA or both, although next generation sequencing (NGS) based solutions for MSI testing are also becoming popular. The SoC testing is slow (up to 3 weeks per case) and expensive in terms of antibody costs, laboratory staining, IHC or PCR processing, technician and pathologist times for interpreting results and reporting.
This large multi-disciplinary project will build on our existing proof-of-principle artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm that has already demonstrated state-of-the-art results for discrimination between MSI/dMMR and Microsatellite Stable (MSS) tumours from digitised high-resolution microscopic images of routine diagnostic Haematoxylin & Eosin (H&E) sections, by leveraging the power of billions of raw pixels per image. By further incorporating interpretable AI technology recently developed by our group, we aim to achieve 70% specificity at 99% sensitivity. The proposed MS3 tool will be refined, optimised, tested for its robustness and finally validated on a large number of CRC and EC cases (totalling >14,000, consisting of both resections and biopsies) from 5 NHS sites and 6 non-UK hospital sites. The project will produce definitive evidence for efficiency and accuracy of the MS3 tool, paving the way for its deployment in the UK and beyond. If successfully validated and implemented, the MS3 tool will serve as a diagnostic triaging tool (rather than replacing the SoC) and is expected to screen out 70-80% of CRC/EC cases that are highly likely to be MSS without any additional testing required, leading to testing efficiency, patient benefits and NHS cost savings.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Partner(s): University Hospitals Coventry &,University of Cambridge,UNIVERSITY OF EDINBURGH,University of Leeds

Project Title: CtF: Curating the Future: uncovering and sharing cultures of space between UK and Indian communities
Project Description: Curating the Future supports the development of a global cultural history of space by exploring narratives of space history across two locations in the UK and India. The research will look beyond nationalistic accounts of space history to build a more equitable approach to uncovering narratives in the history of space. In particular, the research will co-develop an understanding of space activity across the UK and India, to ensure we not only develop transnational narratives of space exploration, but that these narratives reflect a public history of space through local space activities.

Project Title: The Politics of Antibiotics: Who Should Govern Antimicrobial Resistance? (SRC)
Project Description:
International collaboration to investigate who bears the responsibility to govern antimicrobial resistance. 

We are interested in three aspects of (political) responsibility  - the who, what, and how, this will allow us to examine the following three questions that are rudimentary to politics: who should do it (govern or steer); what (substance) should be done; and how (procedure) should that be realized.

Empirical research will include surveys, experiments and interviews, conducted mainly in Sweden in Spain.

Project Title: Improving dysphagia identification and management in hospital (IDIAMH): A feasibility study
Project Description:
Background
Problems with swallowing are very common in older people. When food, liquids and medicines accidentally go into a patient’s lungs, they take bacteria and viruses with them and these can cause pneumonia. This is either the main or second most common cause of death in people with dementia, stroke and Parkinson’s.  Swallowing problems are very high in these patient groups and there is a strong link between swallowing problems and death due to pneumonia.  
Older people with swallowing problems in hospital have also been shown to be at much greater risk of medication errors because nurses are often expected to give medicines such as tablets and capsules, to patients who cannot safely take them.  These patients need a medication review to ensure that medicines are only given by mouth if needed and the best type of medicine e.g. liquid, patch is used for them. 

It is therefore important that swallowing problems in older people are quickly identified to ensure that all swallowing is made as safe as possible. Swallowing problems are, however, frequently not identified or reported in hospital. There is evidence that improving identification of swallowing problems can improve patient quality of life and reduce length of stay. A new way to improve how we identify and care for older people with swallowing problems in hospital is therefore required. 

Aims
To develop an approach which encourages nurses to identify swallowing problems as part of usual practice and refer to speech and language therapists and pharmacists to increase the likelihood of a safe swallow and reduce the likelihood of medication errors.

Methods
We will work with hospital-based nurses on care of the older person wards, speech and language therapists and pharmacists to develop an approach to improving how swallowing problems are identified and then referred for review to ensure a safe swallow and medicines-related practices. We will use theory to underpin the design of our approach to improve how well it works.

We will then test the approach in a small number of older peoples’ wards to see if it is acceptable and feasible and to inform the design of a study to test it. 

Patient & Public Involvement
Patients and public have been involved in the design of the research project and will be involved throughout: design, collection of information, analysis, writing papers and reports and working in partnership with the team to present the results. 
Dissemination

As a feasibility study, we will publish what we have learned from others about the problem we are trying to address and how to test an approach effectively in relevant healthcare journals.  This can be used to develop approaches to improving care for people with swallowing problems in hospital.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research
Name of Call: Under-represented discipline and specialisms highlight notice: Nurses and Midwives call

Project Title: Exploring the mechanisms of exercise-induced cardiovascular remodelling in haemodialysis patients: the role of microRNAs
Project Description: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in haemodialysis patients. Current clinical management is limited to reducing traditional risk factors, which unfortunately has little effect on outcomes as CVD is driven by different factors in this population. Currently no other treatment options are available. Recently our group has shown six-months of intradialytic cycling resulted in cardiac remodelling and reduced left ventricular mass (CYCLE-HD study). Whilst this provides a potential therapy for those able and willing to exercise, a large proportion of the population is not medically stable, or have other barriers preventing their participation. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms through which exercise provided these cardioprotective benefits is vital in the development of other therapies that may be more accessible. Given the incredibly low exercise intensities patients were able to achieve, this study will investigate a novel hypothesis that exosomal microRNA’s released from contracting skeletal muscle may have played a role in cardiac remodelling seen in CYCLE-HD. This will be explored in stored samples from the CYCLE-HD study. This study has the potential to guide the development of new therapies to reduce cardiovascular risk in the haemodialysis population.

Project Title: Assembled, Disassembled, Reassembled: Britain’s Assembly Rooms, 1660-1880
Project Description: This digital history project provides a new history of British urban sociability through the cultural institution of the assembly room from 1660 to 1880. This interdisciplinary research interrogates spatial, social, architectural, gendered, regional, and colonial identities facilitated by the assembly rooms that were constructed across the British Isles and empire. The project maps the rise and decline of the assembly rooms, contributing to burgeoning literature on associational culture and urban development, and reshaping understandings of British sociability.

Project Title: Museums of Minjian: Chinese Social Remembrance from the 'People's Sphere'
Project Description: The development of minjian museum initiatives marks a salient trend in China's ongoing 'museum boom'. Conceived and sustained in the non-official 'people's sphere' (minjian), these initiatives create memory spaces that communicate the historical narratives of communities and individuals that are distinctive from official practices. The establishment and maintenance of these projects are often entangled with overlapping and conflicting moral, political and commercial objectives of state authorities. The project explores this emerging phenomenon of minjian museum-making in China and pursues a critical understanding of the shifting social role of museums and the moral and political implications of museum-making in general.

Project Title: Emotion, Ideological Power, and the Cult of the Saints in the Latin West
Project Description: My project aims to provide a new explanation for clerics' ideological power during the fragmentation of the Roman Empire in the West into ‘barbarian’ kingdoms; it proposes a close analysis of the emotional dynamics in narratives written by clerics drawing upon the popular cult of the saints. The hypothesis is that clerics used such narratives to invert emotions, presenting themselves as expert interpreters of emotion as a basis for their élite ideological power. This analysis is used to offer a fresh approach to explaining the surprising survival and flourishing of the Church as a powerful institution in the post-Roman world.

Project Title: Francophone African Fiction Through the Prism of Russian Translation
Project Description: Situated not only at the intersection between Francophone and Russian studies, but also between postcolonial studies and African studies, this project examines how contemporary African Francophone literature by women and men is translated in Post-Soviet Russia. In doing so, it seeks to raise new questions specific to postcolonial African texts in French-Russian translation as there remains much work to be done in translation studies scholarship since current discussions generally concentrate on translations from Russian either into or out of English. Through detailed textual analysis, I will examine how Francophone African novels are translated in Russia. My aim is to reveal whether the Russian translations challenge orientalist stereotypes and translate Africans as subjects of their own history.

Project Title: Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship: Gertrude Stein's Sacred Spaces
Project Description: This fellowship will explore Gertrude Stein’s interest in a variety of sacred forms and will combine dynamic readings of lesser-known texts with a detailed historical and archival investigation. It will build a comprehensive history of Stein’s relationship to sacred spaces, combined with a thorough consideration of the religious texts she composed during her lifetime. Considering Stein's religious writings, this fellowship will situate her work within a larger religious tradition in the modern period, contemplating her works alongside the meditations of William James, the transcendental nature writing of Ralph Waldo Emerson, and the sublime sacred poetry of T. S. Eliot.

Project Title: Feelings in the past: emotions in late prehistoric southern Iberia
Project Description:
Emotions shape, and are in turn shaped, by the societies and beings experiencing them. Emotions play a key role
in how humans conceptualise themselves and other beings, and in how we engage and interact with reality. And
yet, Archaeology has traditionally struggle to explore prehistoric emotions, as we lack written sources or
informants. This project will develop a new methodology, based on the concepts of ‘emotional regime’ and
‘emotional community’ and in the use of psychological anthropology, to explore emotions in the Late prehistoric
societies of Southern Iberia (3300-1500 BC).

Project Title: Places of change: territorialising landscapes in Crete and the Peloponnese
Project Description: This project presents a new way of understanding the Greek city-state, focusing on the city-states in two richly documented regions. Central to the self-definition of communities, territories have been primarily interpreted as political and governmental groupings. My project reconceptualises them not as stable units but as complex entities bound together by a series of connections and relationships. Combining a wide range of evidence (texts, inscriptions, archaeological surveys), this project will reconceptualise and re-envisage how Greek communities functioned; it will also achieve a deeper understanding of how pre-industrial societies in Greece and elsewhere structured, situated and maintained themselves in rural territories.

Project Title: Children’s Perspectives on Disaster Relief and Recovery in Turkey: Lessons from the 2023 Turkey-Syria Earthquake
Project Description: Disasters have a devastating impact on thousands of people, with children being one of the most vulnerable groups. In the aftermath of a disaster, it is vital to understand the specific needs of children to improve the effective prevention and recovery approaches, minimize the challenges of disasters and create a better future for them. However, despite the significance of involving children in the recovery process, there is little research that emphasises children’s active participation in sharing their experiences. This work fills a gap in investigating children’s perspectives on disaster relief and recovery in the aftermath of the 2023 Turkey-Syria earthquake in Turkey. A qualitative research design will be used to investigate the experiences of children, their families and the first responders. This will provide context to learn more about the experiences and difficulties that children face after a disaster and how these difficulties can be overcome more effectively in the future. This work also aims to highlight the difficulties of families and first responders when supporting children, difficulties that have not been investigated before. The findings will offer valuable insights for practitioners, stakeholders and policymakers in disaster relief and recovery to support children effectively. Moreover, it will help children’s voices and needs be heard in times of crisis.

Project Title: "Owning our roots": An ethnographic and historical inquiry into the ongoing construction of Egyptian Anglicanism
Project Description: This project investigates the recent postcolonial development of the Episcopal/Anglican Church in Egypt and the lived realities of its members. Having recently renounced many of its ties with the English 'Mother Church,' and facing pressure on a variety of fronts, the Egyptian Episcopal/Anglican Church is experiencing turbulent times. Recently upgraded from a diocese to a province, it is also flourishing, with a growing membership. This project explores how the Episcopal/Anglican Church has changed in recent years and the degree to which a new discourse of Egyptian Anglicanism – as an indigenous expression of an ancient form of Christianity – has taken root within a range of settings. The methodology involves training local interviewers to to gather information from fellow church members across this community. Permission for interviews has been granted by the current Archbishop of the Episcopal/Anglican Province of Alexandria. The project aims to fill a gap in the literature regarding the workings of the contemporary, postcolonial Episcopal/Anglican Church in Egypt.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy

Project Title: Defining the effects of telomere length on coronary artery disease
Project Description: ​​Telomere length (TL), a marker of cellular age, is causally associated with coronary artery disease (CAD), however, the underlying genetic and mechanistic interaction remains ill-defined. TeloPlaq aims to elucidate the overlapping genetics between TL and CAD, investigate the regulatory gene networks associated with TL, and study the interaction with (environmental) risk factors and sex. Finally, TeloPlaq aims to develop methods to interrogate TL at cellular resolution in situ and will study the role of TL and prospective key target genes in vitro and in vivo on vascular and circulatory cell behaviour and atherosclerosis. The output of these efforts will provide an explanation of the contribution of TL to CAD risk with the potential to inform future treatment strategies.

Project Title: Specifically targeted smart nano-pills based on synthetic antibodies for treatment of DMG on a mouse model
Project Description:
Specific drug delivery using nanotechnology to fatal paediatric brain tumours such as DMG is an extremely promising treatment approach. DMG is an extremely aggressive cancer, and surgical resection or chemotherapy are not possible for the most DMG. The primary reasons of failure are the deep embedment of cancer cells into the brain, and the challenge of delivering sufficient doses of chemotherapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). 
PEGylated-molecularly-imprinted nanosized synthetic antibodies (SA-NPs) will be developed to achieve nontoxic and actively targeted delivery to the interleukin 13 receptor alpha-2 on the DMG cells. Our strategy will be based on polyamine-blocking therapy, the well-known and most promising therapy against DMG for preclinical applications. The SA-NPs will be loaded with a synergetic combination of ornithine decarboxylase 1 inhibitor difluoromethylornithine (DMFO) and polyamine transport inhibitor AMXT-1501. Also, we will prepare the reduction-responsive delivery system based on glutathione, which is overexpressed in tumour tissue, to obtain tumour-specific drug release. We will test these novel nanotechnology-based combined therapeutic strategies, in an advanced pre-clinic in-vivo mouse model of DMG.

Project Title: Human Rights Law and Health: Future Directions (workshop 2)
Project Description:
We seek funding for a second workshop as part of our collaborative project on human rights law and health, which will culminate in the publication of a Research Handbook on Human Rights Law and Health, to be published by Elgar in 2025. Our vision for this project is not only to engage with the varied elements of human rights law in the context of health, but also to reflect current debates which challenge traditional perspectives of rights such as decolonisation, feminism and social models of disability, and seek to identify the future directions of human rights and health. This is funding application for a workshop that will follow our launch workshop in which invited collaborators will test their ideas in a series of mini presentations, and round-table discussions.

This second workshop aims to create a space for contributors to the collection to present first drafts of their papers, which will allow a smoother editing procedure. It will also allow an exchange on future directions for the project, and allow participants to exchange on possible funding applications and/ or further publication

Project Title: Insular Manuscripts in the Age of Charlemagne
Project Description:
Between c.600–900CE manuscripts were made in Ireland and England using ‘insular’ styles of writing, decoration and membrane that are distinctive and diagnostic. Insular manuscripts and bookmaking methods were also taken to the continent by scholars and missionaries from the islands and were used by them and their students in Francia. Around 850 insular manuscripts survive in modern libraries. By deploying an innovative digital toolkit and breakthrough biocodicological methods (aDNA/proteomics), alongside foundational palaeographical, codicological and art historical tools, INSULAR will analyse the complete corpus of these manuscripts for the first time, to identify differences between manuscripts written on the islands and those made in Francia, and
investigate in new ways the contribution of the islands of Britain and Ireland to the intellectual and material culture of early medieval Europe in the Age of Charlemagne.

We will do this by: producing a comprehensive, open access database of all items in insular script made before c.900; refining methods for distinguishing between insular manuscripts made on the islands from those made in Francia; analysing membrane through visual analysis, photometric stereo recording and biocodicological methods to study methods of making membrane, distinguish between sheep and calfskin, and ‘postcode’ manuscripts made of calfskin; exploring graphic and chronological dynamics between insular and caroline
minuscule, particularly in continental scriptoria; exploring readers’ engagement with books containing insular script.

We aim to transform understanding of the influence of scripts, scribes and scholars from Britain and Ireland in post-Roman Europe through interdisciplinary investigations of INSULAR manuscripts that are both qualitative and quantitative, and which combine new forms of evidence captured by innovative digital and biomolecular technologies alongside well-established scientific tools and principles.
HESA Funder Category: EU Government Bodies (inc European Commission but not UK)
