Project Title: Understanding Solastalgia, Environmental Restoration and Sustainability
Project Description:
The project will explore the social and environmental processes framing  place-based experiences of sustainability by analysing two interrelated processes: 
- the emergence of solastalgia in relation to overtourism and industrial development; and
-  the deployment of environmental and social restorative justice initiatives through rewilding and other community-based initiatives.

Solastalgia is the mental health distress produced by environmental change and affecting people while they are directly connected to their home environment. 

Ecological Restoration refers to the process of supporting the recovery of a damaged environment in ways that reflect both its intrinsic ecological value and its social and cultural value for local populations.

The project will compare different local experiences of compromised social and environmental sustainability in relation to two key economic forces threatening contemporary socio-environmental settings: tourism  and industrial development.

More specifically, it will compare under-researched overtourism-related aspects of solastalgia and environmental change with more mainstream studies focusing on the impact of industrial developments on people’s belonging, relationship and attachment to place. 

The research aims to identify socially sustainable solutions and interventions that reduce environmental damage and avoid the associated health, social and economic costs by adopting a strategic interdisciplinary, participatory and co-creative method. 

It combines collaborative filmmaking and citizen science approaches in the fields of green criminology, biology and psychology to create interdisciplinary communities of academic and community-based researchers identifying, analysing and representing environmental problems and solutions in their own terms.

Project Title: Structural studies of misfolded and polymeric alpha1-antitrypsin in ERQC and ERLAD
Project Description:
Lay Abstract from LoI: 
Genetic mutations in the gene that encodes the protein alpha1-antitrypsin, such as the so-called Z variant, cause disease (termed alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency, A1ATD) via their effects upon the three-dimensional structure of the protein that determines its function and fate.   After synthesis, the Z variant alpha1-antitrypsin protein folds to the optimal structure inefficiently. This has a number of direct consequences at the molecular level.  A1AT folding occurs in a part of the cell known as the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The majority of the protein produced fails to progress beyond ER quality control steps involving other proteins known as PDI and EDEM (that work together to help undo misfolding and signal when there is persistent misfolding).  Protein molecules that fail to fold correctly in this process may be broken down in a process outside the ER known as ER-associated degradation. Alternatively a protein called UGGT1 may recycle misfolded protein for further rounds of attempted refolding (Fig. 2).  However excessive protein misfolding, as for a high abundance protein like A1AT, can predispose to deleterious stress in the cells that have to accommodate it.

A proportion of the Z variant folds with less dramatic structural effects but is still sufficiently destabilised to allow neighbouring A1AT molecules to modify their structure and for each molecule to swap some structural features into equivalent regions of the next.  This links individual A1AT molecules together into a chain or 'polymer' that is harder to remove from the cell than individual misfolded proteins. Accumulation of Z A1AT polymers triggers an  abnormal cellular response.  They can be cleared by a general cell component turnover system known as autophagy, or by a more specific process known as ER-lysosome associated degradation (ERLAD).  Remarkably UGGT1 appears to play a different but important role here too - interacting with polymers to facilitate their movement from the ER into a separate part of the cell (the lysosome) where they are broken down.

We hypothesise that these processes relate to the predisposition to disease in people with Z variant A1AT, and that obtaining a detailed understanding of how polymeric or more poorly-folded species interact with PDI and EDEM, or UGGT1 opens the way to understanding how to increase or reduce these interactions to help treat A1ATD.  We aim to do this using cutting-edge methods to extract the interacting molecules from cells and study them to near atomic detail.  To understand whether each interaction is beneficial or harmful in A1AT-associated liver fibrosis we will study the effects of boosting or reducing levels of PDI, EDEM and UGGT1 on relevant experimental readouts.

Project Title: LSTM MISSION PERFORMANCE CONSOLIDATION STUDY
Project Description:
ESA is currently planning the development of six new missions that may form part of the expansion of the Space Component of the European Union Copernicus Program. One of these missions is a Land Surface Temperature Monitoring (LSTM) mission to support agriculture, hydrology and food security. 
This consultancy project is to delivery a LSTM Mission Performance Consolidation Study to:
OBJ-1: Create a database of series of tools in a software environment to enable the analysis of the various instrument effects on the performance of the LSTM mission.

OBJ-2: Conduct the review and refinement of several reference scenes to be used in testing

OBJ-3: To provide updates and analysis of the MRD requirements

OBJ-4: To provide a review of the methodologies and practises of the OPSI activities relating to the scientific performance

OBJ-5: To support and develop an End-To-End processor using updated reference scenes.

Part of the work will be subcontracted to Rutherford Appleton Laboratories and some to the University of Valencia.

Project Title: Developing physical activity, exercise, and lifestyle informative ‘infographics’ for people living with kidney disease
Project Description:
In 2022, the first ever UK clinical practice guidelines for physical activity, exercise, and lifestyle were published for people living with kidney disease (Baker et al, BMC Nephrology, 2022). These guidelines, supported by the UK Kidney Association, were developed by experts and researchers in the fields of kidney disease and physical activity. This work has already been cited (included in other medical research articles) 39 times (as of 16/5/2023) showing the widespread impact of this work on other researchers and healthcare professionals. The guidelines make up a significant component of a recent educational programme developed by the Global Renal Exercise Network (GREX) for healthcare professionals.

However, despite being widely circulated across the research community, many people living with kidney disease may not be aware these guidelines exist. Indeed, a recent survey of rehabilitation provisions for kidney disease suggested many renal units are not aware of the guidelines either. 

Guidance from the Chief Medical Officers in the UK on the amount and type of physical activity people should be doing to improve their health can be found on the UK government webpages (https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/physical-activity-guidelines). To help the general population understand this information better, the Department of Health and Social Care have created easy-to-understand infographics for these guidelines. 

Infographics are visual representations of information, data, or knowledge intended to present information quickly and clearly. These infographics support the guidelines and can be shared online, via social media, or printed out as posters and displayed in healthcare settings.

To help promote our UK and kidney-specific physical activity and exercise guidelines to people living with kidney disease, we want to create some visually appealing and informative infographics. We want to create three infographics for each of the stages of kidney disease covered in the guidelines – non-dialysis kidney disease, transplantation, and dialysis.

Project Title: NIHR RfPB Courage of Compassion ‘into’ practice: implementation, acceptability and feasibility for nurses and midwives’ psychological wellbeing in the English NHS.
Project Description:
Study Title: 
Courage of Compassion ‘into’ practice: implementation, acceptability and feasibility for nurses and midwives’ psychological wellbeing in the English NHS.  
Background:
Psychological wellbeing of the healthcare workforce is critical for staff retention and patient safety; poor workforce wellbeing affects levels of compassion and staff and patient experiences and outcomes (The Kings Fund, 2020). Many interventions designed to support wellbeing target individuals instead of system wide issues, although the latter are known to significantly impact staff experiences and improve wellbeing (Kinman et al, 2020). Individual ‘solutions’ to systemic, organisational issues (e.g., poor working conditions, excessive workload) can actually be more damaging for staff psychological wellbeing (Edwards and Cowper, 2022).  
The Kings Fund published system-level recommendations specifically for nurse and midwife wellbeing in its ‘Courage of Compassion’ report (2020). To date, although Compassionate Leadership (underpinning the report) has been ‘adopted’ by the NHS, no work has been undertaken to understand how these recommendations might effectively be implemented and evaluated in practice. 
Problem formulation:
We will use qualitative methods to a) explore how existing and new wellbeing interventions could help organisations meet The Kings Fund recommendations and b) understand how feasible and acceptable these recommendations / interventions would be to managers, and clinicians in the NHS and policy makers. The findings will inform future research which would seek to implement and evaluate the recommendations in practice.
Project aims:
1.	Identify NHS stakeholder participants
2.	Scope literature and map existing interventions to report recommendations
3.	Identify gaps in existing intervention provision barriers (e.g., system, resource) to meet the report recommendations
4.	Determine stakeholders’ experiences and perceptions of acceptability and feasibility relating to form, content and delivery of interventions identified
5.	Determine the acceptability and feasibility to recipients and deliverers of any proposed interventions 
6.	Synthesise findings (from WP1 and WP2) and align with patient / staff outcome measures (for pathway to impact)
7.	Develop future research (large scale grant / proposal) implementing and evaluating interventions in practice
Methods:
Two acute NHS hospital Trust case studies:
Work Package 1: Development phase (aims 1, 2 and 3) 
Thirty semi-structured interviews and 2 focus groups with key NHS stakeholders (clinicians, managers, policy makers). 
Work Package 2: Acceptability and feasibility phase (aims 4 and 5)
Thirty semi-structured interviews and 1 co-production event with potential intervention recipients and deliverers (clinical and managerial). 
Work Package 3: Synthesis and pathway to impact: (aim 6 and 7)
Synthesise findings (WP1 and 2); make recommendations; develop large mixed methodology grant application and determine pathway to impact.
*The ‘theoretical framework of acceptability’ (Sekhon et al, 2017) will be used in WP1 and WP2 to inform decisions about the form, content, and delivery mode of ‘operationalising’ report recommendations relating to staff wellbeing and on the acceptability of both the proposed intervention content and the means of delivery.
Lead and Key partners:
Dr Kate Kirk (PI)
Professor Jill Maben (Co-I)
Dr Nici Mackintosh (Co-I)
The Kings Fund 
The Florence Nightingale Foundation 
NHSE/I CNO Policy and Strategy Unit
PPI Stakeholder Steering Group
Local Trust Wellbeing Leads

Project Title: Towards the understanding of vein graft disease in women.
Project Description:
Women undergoing coronary artery bypass grafts (CABG) develop accelerated vein graft disease and experience worse long-term outcomes compared to men for reasons that are unclear. In preliminary work we have demonstrated sex differences in the transcriptional response of venous endothelial cells to arterial shear, a key initiator of vein graft disease. The aim of the current study was to identify specific genes and pathways that lead to accelerated vein graft disease in women with a view to the development of precision therapeutics. 
Methods: Applied informatics analysis will use spatial cell sequencing data from an established ex-vivo model of vein graft disease to identify differentially expressed genes and pathways in males and females. Candidate genes and pathways will be validated using targeted RNA sequencing and protein quantification in an established external bioresource. Potential causality will be determined using causal inference analysis in UK Biobank.

Project Title: Frailty in European emergency departments
Project Description:
Frailty requires different care models and approaches to be considered, and yet its prevalence within emergency care populations remains poorly understood. Similarities and variations between emergency care service users’ age and frailty, and the unscheduled healthcare facilities available to them, have not previously been compared at the European level.

This cross-sectional study will describe the prevalence of frailty and methods for its assessment in European emergency departments. This knowledge will inform population-attuned configuration of healthcare services and education.

A flash mob design will rapidly gather a large volume of data from many sites across Europe. Site co-ordinators will be identified through the European Taskforce on Geriatric Emergency Medicine collaboration and invited to report their system characteristics and services using a structured form. Over a twenty-four-hour period, demographic and outcome data will be collected for all adults attending the participating departments, including age, Clinical Frailty Scale, modes of attendance and departure, first vital signs, and duration of ED visit.

Analysis will compare and contrast local, national, and European epidemiology and immediate emergency care outcomes of ageing and frailty. Service characteristics will be evaluated to identify best practice and to inform policy standardisation and workforce development.

Project Title: Logistics for Bacteria: Spatial-temporal coordination of multiple cell-cell communication systems
Project Description:
Streptococcus pneumoniae (Spn) is a major human
pathogen and its cell-cell communication systems are key determinants of whether the microbe
colonizes as a harmless commensal or acts as an invasive pathogen. Many studies have focused on
streptococcal cell-cell communication systems, from diverse families, extensively broadening our
understanding of their regulation, machinery and function. However, little is known about temporal
coordination and inter-dependence across families, since they have been studied independently. This
diminishes the understanding of the intricacies of pneumococcal biology occurring due to the emergent
properties conferred by the complex regulatory interactions, and reduces the likelihood of their potential
exploitation as anti-infective targets. We found that the ABC transporter, PptAB, provides a molecular
link between two diverse families of cell-cell signaling systems, the Rgg/SHP and TprA/PhrA systems.
Specifically, PptAB is required to activate signaling from the Rgg/SHP family, and we find that it also
decreases signaling from the TprA/PhrA system. In Aim 1, we will dissect the molecular mechanism by
which PptAB dampened TprA/PhrA signaling. We will investigate the involvement of the Eep
metalloprotease, identify the molecular target of PptAB, and test for binding sites and direct interactions
between PptAB and relevant components of the TprA/PhrA pathway. In Aim 2, we focus on generating
a temporal map of two cell-cell communications systems in vivo and measuring the temporal
progression of each signaling system in vitro using microfluidics to visualize cell signaling at the singlecell level in high-parallel. In Aim 3 we explore how PptAB and the coordination of cell-cell
communication systems influences virulence-associated phenotypes such as capsule levels, biofilm
formation, and adherence to host cells. Our studies will integrate information from two signaling
systems, that represent diverse families of communication systems to establish how these systems are
coordinated both in vitro and in vivo, and the relevance of this coordination to disease processes. The
findings have the potential to provide a framework, in which to overlay current and new knowledge of
signaling pathways, to generate a more integrated view of cell-cell signaling and how its phenotypic
changes are coordinated to control pathogenic potential. Understanding the coordination among
different cell-cell communication systems may allow more efficient targeting of multiple pathways, as
well as reveal new targets.

Project Title: Understanding the secondary mechanisms by which SGLT2i's influence sarcopenia in those with T2DM
Project Description: Sodium-glucose transport protein 2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) have provided a step change in the way in which we treat and manage those with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) through their role in the manipulation of glucose reabsorption. There is also growing evidence for their use in other associated long term conditions (LTCs). As such understanding the wider implications of their use is paramount to inform their use in clinical practice. Loss of skeletal muscle mass and function is common in individuals living with T2DM and other LTCs. SGLT2i have been shown to significantly influence body mass and as such, understanding the link between the use of SGLT2i and skeletal muscle health is vital to ensure appropriate measures are taken when prescribing SGLT2i, in particularly in those at risk from a loss of muscle mass and function. This project will use cutting edge proteomic techniques in order to investigate how SGLT2i's manipulate the systemic and skeletal muscle proteome. Having this understanding will be the first step in developing complex interventions which will look to offset the detrimental effects of SGLT2i's on skeletal muscle health, whilst maintainng the life changing benifits ofr SGLT2i's in those with T2DM.

Project Title: Analysis of Paediatric Medulloblastoma cellular heterogeneity using Single-cell multi-omic profiling for improved therapeutic strategies.
Project Description:
Brain tumours are the leading cause of cancer-related death in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant paediatric brain tumour with a third of all patients metastatic at diagnosis. Group3 subtype (G3) predominates in infants and young children and has the lowest survival rate. Current standard-of-care treatment is multi-modal and highly aggressive, leaving young survivors with severe long-term cognitive dysfunction, growth impairments, and secondary malignancies. The advancement of G3 therapies for improved treatment solutions has been restricted by the paucity of appropriate cell models that recapitulate G3 microenvironment and the ability to understand the molecular composition defining G3 cellular architecture that result in varied treatment efficiency. Therefore, the aims of this project are to:
1.	To apply cutting-edge single-cell technology to characterise the clonal landscape and regulatory networks that drive G3 metastasis, chemosensitivity and relapse in next-generation 3D preclinical tumour models.
2.	Identify predictive biomarkers and gene targets for improved G3 clinical treatment.

Project Title: Super-resolution microscopy approaches to understand gene regulation in early female human development
Project Description:
The 46th chromosome in XX female mammals, the second X, has to be switched off. That way females equalize their gene expression dosage with males, who have an X and a Y chromosome. X-inactivation is a fascinating mechanism of whole chromosome silencing which initiates during early embryonic development and is maintained for life in somatic tissues thereafter. Female embryos do not survive without inactivating the X, while the importance of robust regulation of X-inactivation is evident by over 500 X-linked diseases, including severe female-bias to immune diseases due to the richness of immune-related genes on the X. 

In the mouse, I showed that X-inactivation progresses by changes in diffraction-limited ribonucleoprotein assemblies. While mouse models are very useful to elucidate basic principles of mammalian gene regulation, there are critical differences to humans, including gestation length and the timing of X-inactivation. Therefore studying X-inactivation in human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) or induced hPSCs reprogrammed from somatic cells is essential to understand fundamental gene-regulatory events of early human development. Naïve and primed hPSCs correspond to pre- and post-implantation, a time of human development we know very little about and when X-inactivation occurs. With this project I aim at developing for the first time single-cell quantitative super-resolution microscopy investigations to study the configuration and epigenetic changes occurring to the inactivating X in humans using hPSCs as model systems. These studies will offer an unprecedented view to gene-regulatory events occurring during this critical timepoint that will increase our understanding of peri-implantation in humans, which is when most pregnancies are terminated.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Characterising kinase-dependent and -independent functions of PRPF4B
Project Description: Genes are essential players in the process of life as they contain the information needed for the production of proteins, which act as the cell’s workhorse. Genes do not directly produce proteins as they are first expressed into RNA molecules, which are in turn translated into proteins. In humans, each RNA molecule producing proteins require a preliminary removal of major portions of the RNA molecule, a process known as RNA splicing, before the subsequent correct translation into proteins. RNA splicing is a highly complex process requiring the coordination of numerous RNA molecules and proteins. While the players involved in RNA splicing are becoming well-known, it is far less clear how these players are regulated and how RNA splicing is coordinated with other processes, such as transcription which is the mechanism producing an RNA molecule from a gene. I am proposing to investigate the functions of a protein, called PRPF4B, which is involved in RNA splicing and, in a less known manner, in other cellular processes. Importantly, PRPF4B has been found to be critical for cell migration and metastasis formation in breast cancers. It is therefore essential to understand what are the cellular functions of PRPF4B and whether inhibiting its activities or degrading the cellular PRPF4B proteins could represent a possible therapeutic approach for breast cancer, but also potentially for other cancers.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy

Project Title: IP-TEM EPSRC Strategic Equipment
Project Description: IP-TEM is a user-friendly atomic resolution platform perfect for multi-users, which will not only satisfy the need of most users for structural and elemental/chemical analysis, but also create new research capabilities for the UK in the study of fundamental dynamic processes at the nanoscale. Key features include: 1) highest beam energy to minimize scattering and information loss of thick samples; 2) large specimen holder dimensions to accept a range of in-situ environmental holders; 3) a combination of IDES Relativity system and a Celeritas detector to enable dynamic image acquisition across 10-3–10-6 s range (up to 87,000 fps); 4) combined with state-of-the-art environmental holders, including gas, liquid dual flow, electrochemical and optical holders. IP-TEM will serve as a platform to cross-fertilize multidisciplinary collaborations between new and existing sciences and will be the only electron microscope in the UK that can study chemical vapor phase deposition (CVD) and photochemistry in situ and in operando at such a high temporal resolution.

Project Title: New vaccine technology for inducing robust mucosal immunity
Project Description:
There is a consensus that a mucosal vaccine would be highly beneficial against many infectious diseases, including TB, Covid-19 and dengue, with large proportion of human population already  having some, but sub-optimal immunity from prior exposure or vaccination. A mucosal vaccine has the potential to boost the overall immunity levels (systemic and mucosal) but importantly also to induce faster-acting immunity at the site of pathogenic challenge (i.e., TB and SARS-CoV2). However, mucosal vaccination has its own challenges and despite a sustained interest over many decades, only a few mucosal vaccines have ever been approved, and mostly involving live attenuated organisms. Subunit vaccine approach, while conventionally the most attractive, faces the challenge of the paucity of adjuvants suitable for mucosal application. The major aim of the proposed study is therefore to address that challenge by circumventing the use of exogenous adjuvants altogether, in a mucosal vaccine.

We developed a proof-of-concept approach that is based on molecular engineering of adjuvanticity in a vaccine, and specifically intended for mucosal vaccination. Our new vaccine technology is based on a single polypeptide that incorporates, alongside the antigen of interest, two molecular adjuvants, that is, the cholera toxin non-toxic B subunit and the Immunoglobulin G Fc fragment. The first is a well-known mucosal immunomodulator while the second facilitates vaccine uptake by infiltrating antigen-presenting cells (APC), resulting in robust vaccine-induced mucosal immunity. We have preliminarily tested this vaccine technology and obtained strongly promising results but now need to test this concept in pathogen-specific animal models of infection and with human tissues. Therefore, the main objective of this proposal is to test the protective potential and the mechanisms involved of this vaccine technology to move it to next level (TLR5) of readiness (with PCT application already in place). Our vaccines will be tested in the mouse models of TB, dengue and SARS-CoV2 infection, in which we will model mucosal boosting in hosts that have some pre-existing but insufficient systemic immunity. We will then specifically study the mechanisms of mucosally-induced protective immunity, including virus-neutralising potential of mucosal antibodies (SARS-CoV2, dengue) and capacity of lung tissue resident B and T cells to confer improved protection, by passive transfer to naïve hosts. We will also validate immunogenicity of our vaccines using sera and blood cells from pathogen exposed or vaccinated human hosts. The outcomes of this study will then demonstrate the feasibility of this new vaccine technology to be translated towards human application, as a boost vaccine against these and possibly other pathogens.
Objectives of the current study

The overall aim of the study is to advance our new vaccine technology from the current proof of concept stage to late pre-clinical phase, by validating it in the relevant animal models of infection and with human tissues. The 'PCF' technology is designed for mucosal application and intended as an adjuvant-free boost vaccination approach in hosts with pre-existing but insufficiently protective systemic or mucosal immunity. We will therefore model this in animals and determine the capacity of our vaccines to raise the immunity levels overall, and most specifically in the respiratory tissues, i.e. the lungs. The important objective in this study will therefore be to identify the protective immune mechanisms following mucosal vaccination and establish the role for humoral of cellular immune components (i.e. tissue resident cells) in dedicated passive-transfer animal experiments. Three infectious diseases (TB, dengue, and Covid-19) will be focused on as the initial exemplifications of the utility of this new vaccine technology to induce robust mucosal immunity, with further applications envisaged following a successful demonstration.
To test the PCF vaccine technology, we have set up the following specific objectives: 

1.	To test in mice the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of the novel PCF vaccine delivery platform, using TB, dengue and SARS-CoV2 as examples
2.	To test mucosal and systemic antibodies neutralising potential (dengue, SARS-CoV2) in vitro and evaluate the role of lung BRM and TRM in protective immunity (dengue, 
        SARS-CoV2 and TB) by passive transfer in mice
3.	To test vaccine immunoreactivity in human PBMC and sera of TB, dengue or SARS-CoV2 exposed individuals

We believe that by achieving these objectives we will have demonstrated the vaccine potential of our technology to be translated toward human phase of research and 
development.
Name of Call: Infection and Immunity Board Investigator initiated research

Project Title: Aural Diversity: Transdisciplinary Transformations
Project Description:
Aural Diversity is an inherently transdisciplinary idea that can only exist across, above and beyond hearing-related disciplines. It arises from the apparently simple observation that everybody hears differently. However, disciplinary fields concerned with hearing are generally founded on a tacit assumption of “otological normalcy’, that we all possess undifferentiated pairs of ears. We may well ask: whose ears are standard? whose ear has primacy? A fuller discussion of Aural Diversity may be found at http://auraldiversity.org where an infographic sets out the field’s scope.

The AD:TT project is led by Professor Andrew Hugill and will actively combine the disciplines: music and sound studies, acoustics and engineering, hearing sciences and audiology, architecture and design.

Project Title: Through Their Eyes: Understanding Attention and Engagement in People with Dementia using Eye-Tracking
Project Description: Our digital good project aims to develop better measures of attention in people living with dementia. We will use eye-tracking technology to measure people's gaze in real-time, which will inform us about their level of attention and engagement with their surroundings. This project aims to improve the quality of life of people with dementia and their carers by providing insights that are directly usable in care homes and other settings.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Gaming AI inspired design of durable omniphobic surface morphologies (SurfGame)
Project Description: Durable omniphobic anti-fouling morphologies are of great importance for their broad applications e.g. anti-fouling coatings will maintain high power output of solar panels, and greatly reduce energy consumptions and CO2 emission due to marine fouling in shipping industry. To achieve the best anti-fouling performance, the major competition is to design durable omniphobic morphologies to repel liquids with lower and lower surface tensions. The challenge is: morphology design is a highly complex and open-ended question with few clues to follow, hence it requires comprehensive and multidisciplinary techniques to manufacture designed morphologies in micro and nano scale. This project will develop a conceptually new methodology in designing omniphobic morphologies via inspiration of winning a video game (SurfGame). We will exploit deep reinforcement learning AI techniques to simulate the biological evolution of omniphobic morphologies (self-trained AI player) and validate SurfGame predictions in the real world to develop mechanically durable surface morphologies that repel liquids with the lowest surface tensions. This interdisciplinary research will deliver new insights into multiple research fields such as wetting, surface engineering, AI, functional materials, and even bio-evolution.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C

Project Title: ESTABLISH
Project Description:
ESTAbLIsh – Endovascular versus Surgical Treatment for Acute Limb Ischaemia 

Background to the research: 
One in five people above 55 years have narrowings or blockages in their leg arteries. A sudden blockage of the leg arteries is called acute limb ischaemia. This is a serious emergency. Without good blood supply, the leg will not receive oxygen, with the nerves, muscles, and skin eventually dying. If blood supply is not restored, the artery blockage can lead to amputation or death. Leg artery blockages are the most common cause of amputation in the NHS, impacting  greatly on people’s quality of life and the NHS health services. 
 
In people  with a sudden blockage of the leg arteries, urgent treatment is required to prevent amputation or. The usual treatment involves blood thinning medications and a surgical operation. The operation requires an incision to the skin (cut) to open the artery and trawl out the blockage. For some people, this surgical operation can be too invasive for their overall health and recovery. Keyhole artery procedures have now been developed, which can be used instead of the open surgical operation to unblock arteries. These keyhole procedures can be done without a general anaesthetic and do not require big skin incisions. The keyhole procedures are now routinely available in the NHS and used for some patients. However, no one has compared the open surgery to the keyhole procedure. This creates uncertainty for the patients and healthcare professionals. It might also be leading to more amputations, deaths, and higher costs to the NHS and taxpayer.

Aim of the research: 
The aim of this research is to compare keyhole procedures to unblock leg arteries head-to-head with open surgery, the usual treatment. We will look at which procedure (keyhole or open surgery) is best at preventing amputation and death in those with a sudden leg artery blockage, the two things that these people told us mattered the most to them when we were designing this research. 

Design  and methods used: 
People with a sudden loss of blood supply to the leg will be invited to take part. They will be randomly (by chance) offered open surgery or a keyhole procedure to see if the keyhole procedure can match the open surgery in terms of preventing amputation and death. People who take part will be followed-up for two years. We will also compare quality of life between the two groups, complications, and costs of people’s NHS care.

Patient and Public involvement:
Hundreds of patients and NHS staff took part in a national survey in 2021 to find out which are the most important research questions for people with blocked leg arteries. This study addresses many of these questions, such as “how can we improve results in people with artery blockages, who need surgery?”.  The study was designed with the help and feedback of people with artery diseases, who shaped the design of the research and our key questions. Two patients will be formal members of the research team. They will develop study documents and take part in all meetings. An independent patient advisory group will also meet every six months to advise the research team. 

Dissemination:
This will be the first study to compare keyhole procedures to open surgery in this setting, leading to a change in how these people are treated. We will share findings with both lay and expert audiences, with the support of our patient team members. We will prepare plain English summaries (including videos, and graphics) of our findings during the study and when it is completed. These will be shared with patients and via social as well as traditional media and a study website. Final results will be published in medical journals, shared at conferences, and sent to all relevant healthcare and NHS societies.
Funder: NIHR National Institute of Health Research

Project Title: BioClocks UK: supporting the biological rhythm research community to deliver impact
Project Description: BioClocks UK represents UK researchers whose interests predominantly lie in the study of biological rhythms.  Due to the goodwill and hard work of a few volunteers from various universities, BioClocks UK has recently developed a website to support the UK clock community and to foster outreach, training and to stimulate impact.  We propose to place BioClocks UK on a firmer footing by employing a coordination officer who will unlock our communication potential to relevant stake holders and raise awareness of the translatability of clock research into the educational, medical, commercial and national policy environments.  The officer will coordinate networks of UK chronobiology groups by arranging meetings to identify mutual research interests and define priorities for further collaborative funding.  In addition, the officer will develop training elements in data management, policy engagement, media interactions and maintain the BioClocks UK web resources.

Project Title: Identifying species-specific genetic markers in gibbons
Project Description:
Some gibbon species are difficult to distinguish phenotypically, especially infants and juveniles, and some are able to produce viable hybrid offspring. This poses significant challenges for the management of captive gibbons. In the context of conservation breeding programmes, cryptic hybrids and incorrectly identified individuals threaten the genetic integrity of breeding populations. In rescue centres in species range countries, uncertainty of the provenance of individuals hinders release efforts. The ability to reliably genetically identify gibbon species would greatly aid conservation efforts, and the management and welfare of these endangered animals in captivity. With a panel of species-specific markers, testing of individuals, using non-invasively collected samples (hair, faeces) can be performed with simple PCR and gel electrophoresis technology. This makes the approach cost-effective and accessible to stakeholders (zoos, conservation organisations) with only basic molecular biological laboratory facilities. A key research area of my PhD thesis was to identify species-specific L1 insertions for this purpose. This work demonstrated proof-of-concept, and that species-specific L1 insertions are present in gibbons. These findings were independently validated by our collaborator, Dr Kazunari Matsudaira, on samples held at the University of Tokyo.

We are now preparing a research grant proposal to continue and expand upon this work, in order to identify markers in as many species as possible. This project will involve collaborators in numerous countries, including the USA, Australia, Germany, Japan, and also gibbon range countries.

Upon completion, the marker panel will provide a cost-effective tool for zoos to establish the genetic background of the animals in their collections. For centres in range countries, this will fulfil an urgent need to confidently identify species and hybrids, in order to make appropriate decisions regarding pairing, breeding, and release of rescued animals. This will significantly contribute to the conservation management of gibbons, both in- and ex-situ.
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Introversion, Identity and Rights: Is there no Right to be Quiet?
Project Description: The so-called ‘Quiet revolution’ spearheaded by the writer Susan Cain drew public attention to a value system that Cain labels an ‘extravert ideal’. It is estimated that introverts make up at least one third of society but are disadvantaged by a society that discriminates against those who fail to live up to this ideal. Drawing upon psychological and legal theory, this project will be the first to investigate how human rights law engages with the personality trait of introversion and determine whether there is an extravert ideal also embedded within the law.
Funder: THE LEVERHULME TRUST The Leverhulme Trust
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: WP2.3 Bridging Spaces of Exception - Experimentations in New Approaches to Solidarity, Representation and Resistance
Project Description: This WP (work package of an ESRC Research Centre bid) studies experimentation in the organisation of workers who exist at the boundaries of in-work-poverty. Regulatory and policy enclosures, along with changes in the labour process, have created workplaces as ‘spaces of exception’, where employer discretion dictates conditions and workers may be isolated by employer-landlord networks, low wages, poor conditions and limited access to remedy. In researching such workplaces, the challenge is to understand how, by what means, and to what extent, the commoning of nascent solidarities can emerge, so that ‘hope can become possible’ for workers.     We will create comparative case studies of garment workers in the UK, Turkey India and Pakistan. Our theoretical framework will rely on mobilisation theory  in the context of the fragmented nature of contemporary capitalism.
Name of Call: ESRC Research Centre (re-application for WISERD, Cardiff University)

Project Title: FUSE Internship
Project Description: The electrification revolution is advancing very rapidly but its apparent complexity can confuse consumers and slow down adoption. The popularity of social media provides an opportunity to create a broadcast series informing the general public and other stakeholders of the background to electrification. The aim of this FUSE proposal is to train an undergraduate student how to script and make podcasts. It will train them in the general areas of what batteries are, how they are made and recycled and what are the latest developments in the field. They will get very good transferrable skills and clear outputs with at least 6 podcasts. It will provide the Faraday Institution with a good communication tool and allow us to bring in experts from around the project as well as international contributions. The training of other Faraday researchers will ensure that the project is self sustaining.

Project Title: Beyond RNA polymerase II kinases: phosphatases in transcription, transcription-associated processes, and development
Project Description: Transcription of eukaryotic protein-coding genes is coupled to co-transcriptional processes, including mRNA capping, pre-mRNA splicing, mRNA cleavage and polyadenylation. Transcription also causes the formation of R-loops, RNA/DNA hybrids that are associated with DNA damage if left unresolved. Phosphorylation of the RNA polymerase II carboxyl-terminal domain (CTD) plays a critical role in the coordination of transcription with these critical processes. The role of specific kinases in transcription, including CDK7 or P-TEFb, are well studied. In contrast, the mechanism of phosphatases in transcription are much less well understood and represent a major unanswered question in the field. Furthermore, phosphatases active in transcription are frequently dysregulated in cancer, participating in aberrant gene expression programs, and could represent important therapeutic targets. We will use interdisciplinary cutting-edge approaches, including targeted protein degradation, genomics, and (phospho-)proteomics to determine the targets and functions of phosphatases in transcription, pre-mRNA splicing, and R-loop biology. Several phosphatases involved in transcription, including Ctdp1, Ctdspl2, and Ssu72, are essential for mouse development. We will generate mouse embryonic organoids to understand which cellular pathways these phosphatases participate in during development. Altogether, this work will lead to a significant shift in our understanding of phosphatases functions in transcription and development.

Project Title: Genetic prediction of common diseases in African populations
Project Description:
It is becoming increasingly feasible to use a person’s DNA sequence to predict their risk of developing diseases such as diabetes and heart disease.  However most research to date has been conducted in European ancestry populations, and studies in other populations, particularly those of African ancestry, have been less encouraging.  In order to address this discrepancy, it is necessary to both increase the amount of research data available from African populations, and to understand and address the fundamental reasons why results from European ancestry do not translate well to the African setting.

This project will use newly collected data from thousands of people in several African countries including Uganda, Malawi, South Africa and Nigeria.  We will evaluate risk predictors developed in European ancestries across different African populations to understand the factors driving their accuracy, with a focus on cardiovascular traits and kidney disease.  We will explore the use of predictors developed from African diaspora, especially African Americans, and compare their usefulness between different African populations.  We will develop and apply methods to combine information across multiple ancestries to obtain prediction models with global relevance.  In so doing we will establish prospects and guidelines for achieving equitable applications of genetic risk prediction.

Project Title: Consultancy for Lisa Cunningham with Aston University-- analysis of TEF data
Project Description:
Leicester shall arrange for its employee Lisa Cunningham, to analyse and present the key metrics from the publicly available datasets for the Teaching Excellence Framework (TEF), as more fully described below. The analysis will attempt to reveal the areas of strength and weakness in the datasets to help inform the Client’s written TEF submission and drive the narrative.
Leicester will obtain the base dataset from the OfS website. The data processing and transformation software, Alteryx, will be used to reshape and calculate information on student outcome and experience. The data will then be exported to Excel for final presentation. The analysis will attempt to reveal the difference between the actual performance and expected benchmark for each metric split. The difference will then be translated into a likely TEF rating based on the OfS technical specification and rules around statistical certainty. In the final presentation of the data the volume of students impacted by each split will be provided to assess relative risk and weighting of the various metrics.
A total of one day will be spent on the Services.

Project Title: Copy of The Politics of Antibiotics: Who Should Govern Antimicrobial Resistance? (FORTE)
Project Description:
International collaboration to investigate who bears the responsibility to govern antimicrobial resistance. 

We are interested in three aspects of (political) responsibility  - the who, what, and how, this will allow us to examine the following three questions that are rudimentary to politics: who should do it (govern or steer); what (substance) should be done; and how (procedure) should that be realized.

Empirical research will include surveys, experiments and interviews, conducted mainly in Sweden in Spain.
Funder: FORTE Swedish Research Council for Health, Working life and Welfare

Project Title: Us-uk joint RESearch in innovative contoured nozzles for cold SPRAYing high-performance materials
Project Description: A joint US-UK collaboration aims to further develop translational technology from aerospace to material processing by adapting a design workflow for advanced cold spray nozzles developed at the University of Leicester by Dr Rona and Dr Zavalan to deposit high performance coatings. Project Title: COMMA: Conservative and Optimised Mesh-free Modelling of Aerodynamics
Project Description:
Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) has become a basic and essential tool supporting broad scientific and engineering areas. It has unlocked enormous technical and economic advantages over the past decades. Improved CFD capabilities are critical for the UK to meet current and upcoming major challenges including the energy crisis, green aviation, and Net Zero 2050. However, our current CFD capabilities struggle to handle these complex challenges, mainly due to restrictions of the strong mesh dependency. 

Modern CFD's strong mesh dependency is a significant bottleneck in the workflow. It restricts CFD’s ability to handle complex problems, and engineering applications such as human sneezing are often considerably simplified for meshing feasibility. The meshing process also requires intensive user interactions and is a major source of uncertainty. In industrial applications, e.g., novel aircraft designs, it is common that more than 70% of the overall analysis time would be spent on manually creating and adjusting meshes. Therefore, reducing CFD’s mesh dependency is important and urgent to prepare us with more reliable, flexible, and automated modelling capabilities, to enable timely and innovative research and applications to meet upcoming challenges.  

Combining the PI’s unique background in advanced CFD methods, adjoint formulations, and meshing, this project proposes research on advanced mesh-free CFD methods integrated with adjoint-based error estimation and optimisation. This challenging idea can effectively reduce the mesh dependency in the numerical schemes and deliver case-optimised modelling results at reduced cost, time, and difficulty. Relevant research on this novel idea is scarce in the UK and abroad. The key outcome of this project is a series of methodology innovations amounting to a novel mesh-free CFD workflow, capable of case-optimised modelling at drastically reduced mesh dependency, costs, and difficulty. 

This project addresses forefront research challenges in the EPSRC topics of Fluid Mechanics and Numerical Analysis. This project first proposes an innovative multi-level virtual geometry concept to address the lack of flow conservation in current mesh-free schemes. The novel Automatic Differentiation (AD) techniques will be adopted to derive and implement the adjoint form of complex and discrete systems. The enabled adjoint-based error analysis will further improve our understanding of mesh-free schemes. Finally, the developed mesh-free schemes and adjoint forms will be integrated through gradient-based optimisation methods for case-optimised modelling. 

This research will help maintain the UK excellence in Fluid Mechanics and CFD and will transform our current CFD capability leading to further economic/technical advantages. By engaging actively with the UK Vertical Lift Network, the advanced modelling capabilities of the mesh-free CFD workflow of this project will be demonstrated with practical and complex rotor/turbine designs to support the emerging Urban Air Mobility (UAM) industry. Wider scientific and engineering applications will be extended to broad disciplines including aerospace, renewable energy, and environment through planned impact activities in the UK and globally. The outcomes of this project are planned to be progressively published in top-quality journals and disseminated in well-received workshops/conferences to key academic/industrial beneficiaries.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: AgTelligence Agricultural Innovation with Earth Observation
Project Description:
The area of interest is about 100 hectares in the UK, and I'll send the GeoJSON.

Challenge 1: Time series analysis of bare soil/soil cover
(Enhanced Modified Bare Soil Index)
This variable must be normalised to transform the values between 0-1. High values indicate a strong spectral signature that reflects the typical soil response, whereas low values indicate less exposed soil land cover.

Challenge 2: Tillage Practices
Spatial distribution and percentage of tilled and no-tilled arable land using Sentinel-1 (S1) & Sentinel-2 (S2) data.

Challenge 3: Spectral Diversity
To measure habitats at a different scale. The greater spectral diversity across a field represents a greater variety of habitats.

Project Title: Support International Medical Graduates (IMGs) to Thrive at UHL
Project Description:
The NHS increasingly rely on International Medical Grades (IMGs).
In 2021, almost 50% of joiners’ doctors were IMGs, their number has increased by 40% over the last five years while the number of UK graduates has increased just by 10% over the same period (GMC, 2022). However, the 'voice', employment conditions and wellbeing of this group has  been concerning. The vast majority was forced to balance job insecurity (visa-constraint), higher career barriers and instability in their life. Some are on the verge of homeless or jobless if not secured a trust grade doctor post. This certainly can have a repercussion on patient safety. This strand of research is scant.  University Hospitals Leicester would like to take the lead to support its 500 IMGs to thrive. We seek to collaborate and to apply for a grant from the Leicestershire Academic Health Partners Funded Projects

Project Title: Beginning Decolonisation
Project Description: This short but foundational project will provide a road map for New Walk to begin its decolonisation journey. Two consultants will be appointed who have a proven track records of decolonisation work in a range of contexts. The consultants will explore the museum’s collections, speak to staff and consider internal discussions and progress so far. The consultants will draw from their own experience to identify opportunities, outline potential benefits, challenges and options for taking decolonising work forward. The first phase will be an exploration phase, thinking through current practice, strengths, feelings about decolonisation and training requirements. The consultants will produce a short, practical report which summarises findings, makes the case for doing this work within New Walk’s unique context, considers the scope and nature of museum collections and makes recommendations for next steps. The project will be managed by Professor Corinne Fowler and Dr. Katy Bunning from the School of Museum Studies at the University of Leicester.

Project Title: ASTeRN: Advanced Surface Temperature Radiometer and Development of Global Network
Project Description: The project will design and manufacture radiometers with the capability for measuring sea and land surface temperatures with high accuracy and precision. The design would be based on a recent study funded by ESA and performed by RAL and the University of Southampton. The radiometers will be calibrated to standards traceable to SI realised by NPL standards. The team will also undertake a leadership role in the newly proposed CEOS land temperature network, ensuring that global traceability and governance will have significant UK influence, ensuring that any potential loss from Copernicus will be countered through the broader international community.

Project Title: Are transcriptional kinases and phosphatases also involved in pre-mRNA splicing?
Project Description: Production of mature mRNAs in eukaryotes requires both transcription by RNA polymerase II and RNA processing, including mRNA capping, pre-mRNA splicing, and mRNA cleavage and polyadenylation. Removal of introns by the spliceosome is a highly coordinated process based on RNA-RNA, RNA-protein, and protein-protein interactions. Protein phosphorylation has been found to play important roles in regulating RNA-protein and protein-protein interactions of splicing factors and the activity and of the spliceosome. Protein phosphorylation also regulates RNA polymerase II transcription and is mediated by several kinases, including cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK)7, CDK9, and CDK12, and protein phosphatase (PP)1 and PP2A. Interestingly, several of these kinases and phosphatases have been found to (de)phosphorylate splicing factors but it remains unclear whether pre-mRNA splicing is affected because of the transcriptional defects associated with the inhibition of these kinases and phosphatases. To overcome this hurdle, I am proposing to use an approach combining an in vitro transcribed but unspliced transcript and nuclear extracts treated or not with kinase or phosphatase inhibitors. The use of an in vitro transcribed transcript will bypass the issue of transcriptional defects associated with the inhibition of these kinases and phosphatases and will allow their characterisation in pre-mRNA splicing. As pre-mRNA splicing and several kinases and phosphatases involved in transcription are frequently co-dysregulated in cancer, this project will provide important insights for future research.
HESA Funder Category: UK Charities (Open Competition & External Peer Review)

Project Title: WEarable Biomarker and ACcelerometery Unit – WEBACU: a development project  - EPSRC
Project Description:
Tendon and Joint pain are the two most common lower limb disorders impacting the nation. Management of these conditions is through physical activity and exercise, however we know that many people fail rehab and 1 in 5 still have pain 10 years later.  Rehabilitation fails due to poor adherence, commonly related to increased pain. Clinicians and Patients need to be able to monitor and adjust rehabilitation in light of individual responses. 
Our Ambition is to improve rehabilitation adherence and success, through the development of a wearable (smart patch) sensor capable of providing real time feedback related to relevant biomarkers associated with pain and physical activity from individual patients to clinical staff.
The project will utilise 3 work packages, WP1 will be an experimental study using commercial accelerometers to ascertain which lower limb anatomical sites are suitable for measuring physical activity levels BUT importantly link to common sites for tendon or joint pain. WP2 is a scoping review to determine which biomarkers have been identified and the anatomical site they have been identified. WP3 is a patient, public and stakeholder series of workshops in order to determine the acceptability of wearing such a device and to understand the core requirements of such a device. 
The project comprises of three work packages that will be used to develop knowledge required for a larger EPSRC grant submission. These projects are critical to the long term ambition of the work group and the project directly came from the RTN event in January 2023.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C
Visibility: Only people involved in this project
Notes: This is a joint project with collabs from Loughborough University and Nottingham NHS trust

Project Title: NLP for FDA Biomarkers Pilot Study
Project Description:
Utilise deep learning and natural language processing algorithms to identify relevant associations between FDA PGX oncology biomarkers and medical publications.

Ultimately, the aim is that this could be used to help a clinician to identify/prioritise mutations in a patient's sample with respect to diagnosis and/or ongoing monitoring, by providing strong evidence of a relationship between a mutation and medical and research publications.

This pilot study is a collaboration between Nonacus and the University of Leicester to determine the applicability of current state-of-the-art text analytics to this use case, and to evaluate the viability of extending this approach into additional use cases through a PhD Studentship.

Project Title: Reading the Material Features of Women’s Letters in Samuel Richardson’s Correspondence
Project Description: This will be the first study of women’s autograph letters as physical objects in Samuel Richardson’s extensive letter corpus at the Victoria and Albert Museum, London. As well as advancing our knowledge of correspondence archive formation in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, my project examines how women’s manuscript letters circulated and were transformed into print to offer new insights on gender, social authorship, book history, and manuscript studies.

Project Title: Causal discovery and Machine Learning based analysis of wearable sensor data for people with breathlessness
Project Description:
The project will employ causal discovery and machine learning techniques on data derived from the Respeck sensor worn by patients with Long Covid or COPD to measure continuously (at 1­minute
resolution) respiratory rate/effort, and the intensity and type of physical activity in ongoing observational studies in Leicester. 
There are in the UK alone over 1.5 million people living with Long Covid, with over one ­half experiencing a limitation in their day ­to day acti­vities. For other long term conditions, programmes of
rehabilitation, with exercise as a core component, are clinically cost­effective. Exercise is very challenging for people with Long Covid and there are concerns that it is harmful in some people because of post-exertional symptom exacerbation (PECE). Breathlessness is a highly prevalent and distressing symptom for people with Long Covid and a common symptom of PESE alongside fatigue and brain-fog. The underlying mechanisms of PESE are unknown and under-­researched despite it being a common symptom experienced by people with Myalgic encephalomyelitis/Chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS). 
Using the Respeck device, we will investigate the relationship between prior physical activity and PESE (using a symptom tracker on the device) underpinned by a biological objective measure of quiet tidal breathing. We will assess the relationship over days and weeks. The results would directly inform pacing regimes by understanding how much physical activity and rest is required to avoid PESE. 
Exacerbations and hospital admissions are a major healthcare cost to the NHS with over 160,000 hospitalisations for COPD patients per annum. The RCP/BTS national audit highlights a hospital
admission from COPD is associated with a 45% readmission rate and 12% mortality at 3 months. Population studies in COPD have suggested that by the second hospitalisation patients are on a
significant downward trajectory of repeated exacerbations. Patients with COPD frequently report disabling breathlessness and it is hard for patients and GPs to distinguish day­to­day variability in symptoms from an exacerbation requiring treatment with medication ­ this is particularly difficult post-hospitalisation. Repeated course of antibiotics and steroids have negative side ­effects. Understanding
whether there is a change in tidal breathing at rest may help reduce unnecessary treatments or enable
earlier intervention. 
We will investigate the relationship between physical activity, symptoms and a biological objective measurement of tidal breathing using the Respeck device. Patients will be recruited as part of an existing observational study at Leicester BRC.
Funder: UKRI UK Research and Innovation UKRI

Project Title: Developing In Situ Resource Utilisation Production Technology (DISRUPT-2)
Project Description:
The principal aim of this project is to improve the In-Situ Resource Utilisation (ISRU) system
performance by using Artificial Intelligence to select areas of Lunar regolith that are optimal for
subsequent processing in the Fray-Farthing-Chen (FFC) reactor. It is proposed that a novel X-ray
diffraction (XRD)/X-ray fluorescence (XRF) instrument will be used to sense the regolith composition,
and this will provide the primary input to the AI. The AI and XRD/XRF instrument will therefore form part
of the Regolith Acquisition Sub-system design, with the instrument installed externally on the platform.

Project Title: Blueprinting AI for Science at Exascale - Phase II (BASE-II)
Project Description:
The purpose of this funding is to fund a PDRA/RSE position at Leicester to deliver work package 2 of the EPSRC-funded ExCALIBUR project "BASE-II".

The funds have been awarded to STFC-RAL and will be transferred from there to Leicester.  

The full description of the project (taken from the objectives section of the associated JeS form) is: 
The main objectives of this proposal, underpinned by various scoping activities in Phase I (BASE-I), in decreasing order of priority, are:

* Develop a software suite and designs for supporting exascale computing from the AI point of view - (hence blueprinting AI for Science at Exascale).
* Ensure that the software stack and relevant designs cover the challenges around five of the key areas of AI, identified as part of Phase I, namely, AI Benchmarking, AI in HPC, hardware-software co-design, learning from large-scale datasets, and tools, frameworks, and workflows.
* Collaborate with a number of communities, such as, academia, scientific disciplines, industries, and public sector research establishments (PSREs, such as, national laboratories), for accommodating their steer and inputs, not only to ensure that the resulting stack addresses the challenges stated above, but also remains highly relevant to various communities. 
* Actively engage with other ExCALIBUR funded cross cutting projects to ensure relevant developments from those projects are enhanced, integrated, and leveraged within our project to ensure better functionality and completeness. 
* Support the knowledge exchange activities of other ExCALIBUR funded projects.
* Engage with relevant international projects (e.g., Exascale Computing Project in the US) to ensure that international communities work together in the development of exascale software solutions and for better knowledge exchange.
* Ensure that the program overcomes the barriers and exploits the opportunities for knowledge exchange across a range of target groups and communities, including different scientific domains, research software engineering, AI communities, academia, PSREs, international organisations and industries.
* Provide means for the training and upskilling of researchers and RSEs to ensure that they are prepared for exascale software, designs and relevant architectures, using carefully designed hands-on training programmes, and in-field placements.
* Engage in various knowledge exchange activities with relevant communities (see above) through a set of carefully designed knowledge exchange programmes. 
* While retaining specific cases and code examples, generalise the key cases, as design patterns, so it can be applied to different domains of science.
* Ensure that the software and design deliverables are relevant to the evolving UKRI's e-Infrastructures, such as Science Clouds, IRIS science platform and exascale-cloud middleware, with direct benefits to our science, climate, and fusion programmes. 
* Ensure proper data and code retention mechanisms and support for maintenance are in place beyond the life of this project. 
* Work with relevant communities to increase the awareness of the BASE-2 work, and of the ExCALIBUR programme.
Funder: EPSRC EPSRC ENG.& PHYS.SCIENCES R C
Name of Call: Investigate high priority use cases for exascale software

Notes: The funding was peer reviewed by EPSRC in 2022. All funds award to STFC-RAL, but Leicester were explicitly named in the JeS form.

Project Title: Targeted bacteriophage metagenomics
Project Description:
Bacteriophages are the most abundant biological entities on the planet with 1031 in the biosphere. They drive the evolution of their bacterial hosts by mediating horizontal gene transfer, facilitating the spread of antimicrobial resistance and virulence genes. Despite being abundant, we have only begun to understand their diversity through culture-independent methods (eg viral metagenomics). Although viral metagenomics has expanded our understanding of phage diversity, critically it does not link the bacteriophage with its host. The range of hosts a bacteriophage can infect is traditionally based on the use of plaque assays that allows the visualisation of a plaque, should the infection result in a productive infection. However, there are many issues with this method. 1) if the bacteriophage is temperate in nature, it may not produce plaques. 2) the bacteriophage may be able to attach and inject its DNA (also transferring genes) but not be able to actively replicate due to host anti-phage systems. Thus, traditional plaque assays do not allow to determine the full host range of bacteriophages and viral metagenomics does not link bacteriophages to their hosts.
In this work, we will assess if mini-cells of bacteria could be used to selectively separate host-specific phages from complex natural bacteriophage communities. Mini-cells are "mini" bacterial cells that are produced as a result of the asymmetric division of min mutant strains. They contain no chromosomal DNA but crucially contain membrane receptors for bacteriophage attachment. We hypothesise that it is possible to infect mini-cells with only host-specific bacteriophages from an environment. Utilising metagenomics to sequence only the viral DNA contained within minicells. Thus, enabling direct linking of bacteriophages to their hosts. The approach would revolutionise our understanding of bacteriophage-host interactions, by allowing for the first time high-throughput identification of which bacteriophages can infect a particular host.
Proposed work:
Objective 1: Produce mini-cells of E. coli and Vibrio natriegens
Objective 2:  Test and optimise with a defined cocktail of bacteriophages, with known host ranges, the limits of detection of mini-cells combined with metagenomics to identify host specific interactions.
Objective 3: Apply the use of mini-cells to produce host specific metagenomes from sewage or animal slurries (E. coli) and aquaculture (Vibrio)
Objective 4: Apply the use of mini-cells to identify the extent to which phages mediate horizontal gene transfer
Potential Impact: Unlike traditional viral metagenomics, this research offers the crucial ability to directly link bacteriophages with the hosts they can infect. Furthermore, it will provide a high-throughput way to identify the extent to which bacteriophages can mediate the horizontal transfer of genes. The successful completion of this project will result in the development of a novel methodology enabling to assess and study host-specific phage metagenomes, substantially increasing research capacity of scientists working on bacteriophage biology, microbiome, antimicrobial resistance, horizontal gene transfer. Thus, this project has the clear potential to transform our understanding of microbial life and therefore it is fully aligned with the BBSRC’s priority area ‘Frontier bioscience: understanding the rules of life’.
Name of Call: Pioneer awards: early-stage frontier bioscience research
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

This is the second stage application. Costing for the preliminary stage has already been approved (Costing No:45895)
J Mogra has agreed to submit for stage 2 with stage 1 Estates and Indirects, hence they have been amended on this project

Project Title: Insect-inspired stereoscopic visual information processing for accurate collision detection (MANTIS)
Project Description:
Stereoscopic vision is critical for autonomous robots, autonomous vehicles and many other autonomous mobile machines, however it is still a huge technical challenge to the current technology. On the other hand, invertebrates with tiny brains such as praying mantis, its stereo vision uses a fundamentally different computational algorithm compared to vertebrate stereopsis – it focuses on luminance changes rather than comparing luminance in the two eyes directly. This strategy makes it computationally efficient and robust to poor image resolution against complex backgrounds, and even outperforms humans at judging stereoscopic distances. With a significantly less number of neurons involved in invertebrate stereopsis compared to vertebrates, it could be an ideal model for constructing new stereopsis algorithms that excel in efficiency, reliability and convenience for miniaturisation.

Inspired by insect stereopsis, this consortium proposes an innovative stereoscopic vision system for robots to accurately locate and handle household items timely. It aims to build computational models utilising the mechanisms underlying the insect stereoscopic vision, test the algorithms with robots for catching physical moving objects, and explore the optimal realisation and miniaturisation methods for massive production. Fulfil this aim demands multidisciplinary expertise in neurobiology, computer science, circuit design and robotics. This breadth of expertise is not readily possessed within one institution. The market potential of the new stereoscopic system could not be well exploited, unless by dedicated partners from industry. This consortium is designed to bring together leading neurobiologists, neural system modellers, chip designers, robotics researchers and engineers from Europe, the East of Asia and South America to complement each other’s strengths via staff secondments, jointly organised workshops and conferences. The European partners will build up strong expertise and market leadership in this emerging area.  


Six work packages (WPs) are designed to achieve the objectives of the project: 

WP1: Visual information processing models inspired by insects’ stereopsis for depth perception
WP2: Implementation of stereopsis algorithms to robotics systems for collision detection
WP3: Optimal hardware realisation and miniaturisation
WP4: System integration, verification and demonstration
WP5: Joint workshops, training seminar, conferences and dissemination
WP6: Project management and market exploitation

Project Title: OPTimising FORest management decisions for a low-carbon, climate resilient future in EUrope
Project Description:
Significant reductions in anthropogenic emissions and increases in CO2 sinks are needed to meet the 1.5 centigrades threshold for
global warming set out in the Paris Agreement and reach the climate-neutrality goal of the European Green Deal by 2050. The CO2
sink provided by forests, including old-growth forests, partially offsets the rise in anthropogenic CO2 emissions, providing a largescale
buffer to climate change. Depending on their characteristics and local circumstances, such as management practices or
ecosystem services, forests may range from net CO2 sinks to sources. The project 'OPTimising FORest management decisions for a
low-carbon, climate resilient future in Europe (OptFor-EU)' will build a Decision Support System (DSS) to provide forest managers and
other relevant stakeholders with tailored options for optimising decarbonisation and other Forest Ecosystem Services (FES) across
Europe. Based on exploitation of existing data sources, use of novel Essential Forest Mitigation Indicators and relationships between
climate drivers, forest responses and ecosystem services, OptFor-EU has five specific objectives: (1) Provide an improved
characterisation of the Forest-Climate Nexus and FES; (2) Utilise end-user focused process modelling; (3) Empower forest end-users to
make informed decisions to enhance forest resilience and decarbonisation; (4) Provide a novel DSS service; and (5) Bridging different
EU strategic priorities, robust science, and stakeholders in the forest and forest-based sectors. Based on a supply-demand approach,
the methodology combines an iterative process of data consolidation, modelling, and co-development of solutions alongside forest
managers and other practice stakeholders in all European Forest Types. The DSS will be designed and tested at 8 case study areas, to
provide a ready-to-use service, near to operational (TRL7) at European level, while a user adoption and up-take plan will maximise the societal and business impact.

Project Title: Using social spiders to untangle the molecular web of social evolution
Project Description: The switch from solitary living to social living is described as one of the biggest leaps in species evolution. This switch involves vast changes in behaviour which are encoded within an organism’s genetic makeup. Epigenetic mechanisms (chemical changes which affect DNA) are proposed to drive these initial evolutionary switches. However, the role of epigenetics in social evolution currently remains unknown. I will utilise three independent transitions to sociality (found in spiders) to test the contribution of epigenetic mechanisms to the evolution of sociality. This project has the potential to reshape our understanding of the evolution of complex behaviours.

Project Title: Consultancy Services for the National Fire Chiefs Council
Project Description: The project aims to utilise people and community-centric approach in conjunction with literature review of published reports in identifying emerging risks in transport-based services (rail and airport) in the case e.g. of fire and collision by not just focusing on existing available data (e.g. through published literature) but also on ‘missing data’. The project will engage Subject-Matter Experts and -if possible- public communities (e.g. F&R services at Leicester, local companies on location-based monitoring technology for tracking plumes and other stakeholders as guided by NFCC) to elicit insights as to what emerging risk ‘missing data’ is that is necessary to build more robust and more ‘holistic’ risk models. This will allow identifying and defining recommendations for inclusion in risk framework to support FRSs that will be more holistic and inclusive of the emerging needs.
Scheme: Funder not listed - Commercial Default Scheme
Name of Call: Developing National Risk Frameworks for UK FRS
Visibility: Only people involved in this project

Project Title: Understanding how digital minimalism reproduces social inequality
Project Description: Digital access has long been viewed as a field in which social inequality is reproduced, for example, the gap between the upper and the lower SES has been widened by the ‘digital divide’ of unequal access to modern information and communications technology (Bonfadelli, 2002). However, this may have changed in today’s society in which digital communications technology is prevalent despite its negative effects (LaRose et al., 2014). Thus, social inequality may be reproduced less by the capability to access digital technology and more by the capability and resources to limit such access. For example, restricting smartphone usage has been argued as an efficient way to improve child social mobility in the UK (12 March 2022, The Guardian). The proposed project will use mixed methods to (1) develop validated measurements to empirically examine digital minimalism and its downstreat effects, and (2) investigate how SES-based (dis)advantages are reproduced in digital minimalism.
HESA Funder Category: Research Councils (BEIS) - Roy Society and Brit Academy
